description:
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has signed into law yet another one of the restrictive voting rights measures in the nation, all in an effort to navigate the Republican party's politics of not angering former President Donald Trump -- and keep DeSantis' own 2024 presidential prospects alive. In the latest episode of The Point, CNN’s Chris Cillizza discusses DeSantis’ Trump-driven political maneuvers as he leads the pack of GOP presidential hopefuls in 2024.

About me: 
I was named "best dressed" in 7th grade. That, along with being CNN's editor at large and author of the daily "Point" newsletter are my proudest achievements. Look for me here every Tuesday and Thursday to find out what’s really going down in politics.

description:
Whew, crisis averted: Snoop Dogg and Eminem have reconciled ahead of their performance at the Super Bowl next year. Of course, not all celebrity feuds end with mutual respect. Celebrity beefs are as old as Hollywood itself. CNN’s “Pop Off” hosts go back to Bette Davis and Joan Crawford to talk about the OG celebrity feud. Then, of course, there’s feud magnets Nicki Minaj and Taylor Swift. Of course, there’s the serious lack of friendship between Kim Cattrall and Sarah Jessica Parker of “Sex and the City” fame. And you can’t forget Vin Diesel and The Rock! So much delicious drama to dish on in this week’s episode. 

Watch “Pop Off" with Lisa for a sassy, no-nonsense take on entertainment and real life's biggest issues every Saturday morning on CNN’s YouTube channel.
tags: latest News, Happening Now, CNN
title: Celebrity feuds are as old as Hollywood itself

description:
Forty years after their last studio album, Abba have made one of the most anticipated comebacks in music with the release of their new record, Voyage.

But the 10-track album has divided opinion among critics.

Benny Andersson isn't worried. "I don't think we're taking a risk because if people think that we were better 40 years ago, fine."

He said he thinks Voyage will be the quartet's swansong and told BBC entertainment correspondent Colin Paterson: "I don't want to do another Abba album."

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#Abba #BBCNews
tags: bbc, bbc news, news, ABBA
title: Abba on new album Voyage: 'We don't need to prove anything' - BBC News

description:
The Royal Navy's aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth is on its way home from its first deployment, which has taken the warship halfway around the world.

It's already attracted the interest of both the Russian and Chinese militaries as it sailed to the Pacific, where it has also been exercising with allies.

Watch Able Rating William Augustine, who deals with the ship's payroll, as he takes the BBC around to show us what life is like on board.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews
tags: bbc, bbc news, news, royalnavy, navy
title: Life on board HMS Queen Elizabeth - BBC News

description:
At least eight people have died and scores of people have been hurt after a crowd surge on the opening night of a music festival in Houston, Texas.

Panic broke out after the crowd began to press towards the front of the stage at rapper Travis Scott's Astroworld Festival, emergency officials said.

Eleven people were taken to hospitals in cardiac arrest and eight died. Some casualties are aged as young as 10.

Some 50,000 people attended the outdoor event, which has been cancelled.

Lina Hidalgo, the county judge of Harris County, described what had happened as an "extremely tragic night".

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews
tags: bbc, bbc news, news, Astroworld, Travis Scott, US, Texas, music festival, festival, crowd surge
title: Eight killed after crowd surge at US music festival - BBC News

description:
Millions of people in Afghanistan are facing starvation in what’s fast becoming the worst humanitarian crisis on earth.  That’s the warning from the United Nations. 

The head of the World Food Programme says the country faces being turned into “hell on earth” following drought and the withdrawal of coalition and US troops. 

Sophie Raworth presents BBC News at Ten reporting by world affairs editor John Simpson.

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

#BBCNews
tags: bbc, bbc news, news
title: Millions face starvation in Afghanistan as UN warns of "hell on earth" - BBC News

description:
Engineer and inventor Rod Read has created flying turbine technology, using spinning kites to generate electricity. 

His experiments have generated enough electricity to charge an electric car and still have power left to boil the kettle for a cup of tea. 

Rod says that his kites, run continuously, could power an average home and that the technology could scale up to take more advantage of the wind than traditional wind mills currently do. 

Please subscribe HERE http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

 #BBCNews
tags: bbc, bbc news, news
title: How spinning kites could power your home - BBC News

description:
The impact of climate change is already very real for villagers on an island in northern Alaska.  

They’re being forced out of their homes because of rising sea levels.

Alaska is home to rapidly retreating glaciers where the rate of melting is among the fastest on the planet.

description:
Near the Pakistan border thousands of Afghans are turning to people smugglers to escape Afghanistan and its new Taliban government.

People traffickers have always operated on this border but where they once bribed corrupt officials to let them through they now pay a fee to the Taliban government 

Most are young men with no passport or visa who hope to go from Pakistan on to Iran and from there to Turkey or other countries to find work. 

But there are also families hoping to leave Afghanistan. Many worked for the previous government and were civil servants, teachers or soldiers.  They say they have no choice but to leave with the Taliban in power.

description:
There's a human cost to factory-processed chicken.

Subscribe to our channel! http://goo.gl/0bsAjO

In the 1960s, the US began a love affair with chicken, and poultry workers paid the cost. Over the past few decades, poultry processing line speeds have increased to meet demand. But that’s happened in tandem with the decline of unions and deregulation of the industry. The result is a high rate of workplace injuries and repetitive motion disorders, with gaps in workplace safety oversight. 

For this video, we contacted Tyson Foods Inc. and the National Chicken Council for comment. The NCC, the poultry industry lobby that has repeatedly requested increases in line speeds, wrote that faster line speeds do not affect the pace of work because plants will add additional staff and lines to accommodate speed increases. Through our reporting, we weren’t able to substantiate this claim, and the NCC did not respond when we asked for an example or for any evidence that this is the industry standard. 

The NCC also mentioned that other countries run poultry line speeds as fast as, if not faster than, the US. It’s difficult to do an apples-to-apples comparison with other countries. Claire Kelloway, reporter and researcher for OpenMarkets, noted that in Europe, for example, factories are typically smaller than US plants, and have higher rates of unionization and more industry safety regulation. The regulating agencies enforce longer breaks and switching up job roles to avoid repetition. Even so, working conditions in poultry plants are still criticized there. 

While the NCC cited a decline in workplace injuries, advocates and experts say that this data is unreliable. It relies on workers reporting injuries to the government agency that regulates workplace safety, OSHA. There are a number of reasons a poultry worker might not report an injury or illness, including language barriers or fears over their citizenship status. Worker and advocate-led surveys show high levels of injury, here are examples: 

https://www.splcenter.org/sites/default/files/d6_legacy_files/downloads/publication/Unsafe_at_These_Speeds_web.pdf

https://foodchainworkers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/Hands-That-Feed-Us-Report.pdf

https://www.uusc.org/sites/default/files/wages_and_working_conditions_in_arkansas_poultry_plants.pdf

Tyson disputes, without evidence, the petition that Magaly Licolli presented on behalf of the workers at the Berry Street poultry plant in Springdale, Arkansas. The company said it was misrepresented to those who signed it and that there were duplicate signatures. Tyson also noted that it offered raises to poultry workers in 2021 amid a labor shortage. 

We also contacted OSHA for comment. They noted that they issue citations or fines to any workplace found by federal inspectors to have violated their safety standards, but confirmed that it is under the jurisdiction of the USDA to determine line speeds. They also said that they do not track data on the use of the chemicals we mention in the video: chlorine, ammonia, and peracetic acid. 

While reporting this episode I read Christopher Leonard’s The Meat Racket, a deep-dive report into the history of Tyson and the poultry industry: 
https://bookshop.org/books/the-meat-racket-the-secret-takeover-of-america-s-food-business/9781451645835

More reading on poultry plants in Europe: 
https://thefern.org/2020/06/how-did-europe-manage-to-avoid-the-covid-19-catastrophe-ravaging-u-s-meatpacking-plants/

How meat consumption has changed in the past 50 years: 
https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/per-capita-meat-consumption-by-type-kilograms-per-year?country=~OWID_WRL

More coverage of the failed OSHA ergonomics rule: 
https://www.motherjones.com/food/2020/07/labor-eugene-scalia-meatpacking-osha-stress-carpal-tunnel-coronavirus-covid/

Deborah Berkowitz, former OSHA chief of staff and director of the Worker Health & Safety Program of the National Employment Law Project, was a crucial source for this story. Here is her recent congressional testimony on workplace safety: 
https://www.nelp.org/publication/testimony-debbie-berkowitz-health-safety-protections-meatpacking-poultry-agricultural-workers/

Some reporting on whether more automation could help reduce workplace injuries.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/meatpackers-covid-safety-automation-robots-coronavirus-11594303535

More on the history of anti-union politics, specifically in Arkansas:
https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2020/07/20/how-trump-is-helping-tycoons-exploit-the-pandemic

For more about the impact of Upton Sinclair’s The Jungle: 
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/projects/cp/obituaries/archives/upton-sinclair-meat-industry

Watch Episode 1, How 4 companies control the beef industry: https://youtu.be/3_hCLjUrK1E

Watch Episode 3, Hog farming has a massive poop problem: https://youtu.be/WsUNylsiDH8

Watch our full video catalog: http://goo.gl/IZONyE
tags: Vox.com, explain, explainer, meat industry, meat processing industry, poultry plants, poultry processing, vox, tyson meat company, tyson meat plant, meat processing, repetitive motion injury, voxfutureperfect, worker safety, worker union, worker safety union, meat industry worker safety, poultry farming, poultry, unionization, meat production, meat processing plant works, poultry plant operations, poultry plant accidents
title: The chicken industry’s worker safety problem

description: It was a scary moment at a South Carolina restaurant, when a 10-month-old baby started choking on a piece of pancake. Diners rushed to help the distressed family, but the Heimlich maneuver didn’t work. Salvation came in the form of a man named Major Hillard, who retrieved a device called a Lifevac from his car. description: 7-year-old Isadora Rose was exploring a lake when she made quite the discovery - a high-school ring with a red ruby stone. description: A missing teenager from North Carolina used a hand signal she learned on TikTok to alert a passing car that she was in trouble, leading to her rescue. The 16-year-old girl flashed the gesture, which caught the attention of a good Samaritan, who then called 911 as they traveled down the highway in Kentucky. The teen apparently learned the hand signal -putting up your palm, tucking your thumb in and covering it with your fingers - on TikTok, from a woman using it as her abuser stood in the background.

description: A pastor tackled an alleged gunman and his congregation held him until police arrived. Pastor Ezekiel Ndikumana snuck behind the suspect and tackled him to the ground. Church members rushed in to help, taking away the gun and holding the suspect until authorities arrived.
tags: nashville, Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie offbeat, crime, church, tennessee, Nashville Light Mission Pentecostal Church, Dezire Baganda, pastor tackles gunman, pastor saves church, pentecostal church, gunman stopped, viral video
title: Pastor Tackles Alleged Gunman Who Stormed Church Altar

description: Geologist Daniel Robinson has been missing since June 23rd, 2021, and now police say they know more about the car crash that happened before his disappearance. A collision report from San Tan Recon says Daniel’s Jeep Renegade sped up right before a rollover crash into a desert ravine. Police say that collision may "indicate an attempt to drive up the other side of the ravine."
tags: arizona, crime, Inside Edition, inside_edition, IE newsdesk, Daniel Robinson, David Robinson II, missing person, missing geologist, private investigator, missing man, missing people of color, Buckeye Police Department, Arizona, lost in the desert, search
title: Missing Geologist's Jeep Started 40 Times Upside Down

description: Chelsie Gleason was working out at the gym when she got some unwanted attention from a very persistent guy. When he came too close, she exclaimed, “Don’t come near me!” When she posted the video on social media, she was praised for her no-nonsense reaction. The 20-year-old told Inside Edition the guy had been annoying her for weeks, and that she was scared at that moment. But Chelsie is far from the only woman feeling hassled at the gym. So what do you do if you’re being creeped on at the gym?
tags: ie newsdesk, safety, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, creeps at gym, guys checking out women at gym, getting hit on at the gym, harassment, metoo, sexual harassment, gyms, dont come near me
title: Creepy Guys at Gyms Are Making Women Uncomfortable

description: Roxanna Zafar lost her beloved 12-week-old puppy to a bacterial infection, leptospirosis, which is spread by rats. The disease was once rare but is having a resurgence as rats feast on piles of garbage left uncollected on the streets of New York due to a work-slowdown for sanitation workers. Workers have been protesting COVID-19 vaccine mandates in the state. Leptospirosis can also spread to humans. There have been 15 cases reported in New York recently, which is more than the last decade.
tags: new York city
title: Once-Rare Disease Spread by Rats Sees Resurgence

description: Colin Powell was honored with a funeral held at the Washington Cathedral. President Biden and the first lady attended, along with former Presidents Obama and Bush, along with their wives, Michelle and Laura. Hillary Clinton represented former President Clinton, who is still recovering from an infection. Notably absent was former President Trump, who caught heat for his snarky statement after Powell’s death. Beautiful music filled the cathedral, including a rendition of Abba’s “Dancing Queen.”
tags: ie newsdesk, politics, Donald Trump, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, IE Politics, colin powell, cancer, covid-19, complications, blood cancer, secretary of state, joint chiefs of staff, 1st black national security advisor, bush, reagan, trump, funeral, washington cathedral, clin
title: Colin Powell’s Funeral Included ‘Dancing Queen’

description: As we approach Thanksgiving, the cost of the beloved bird is going to be higher than usual, and some popular holiday food items might not even be on the shelves due to stocking issues. Inside Edition visited Double Brook farm in New Jersey, where turkeys will cost double what they did a year ago due to higher demand and lower production, thanks to the disruption of the supply chain. The cost of side dishes will also go up 5%, according to Fox News. So how do you save money on Thanksgiving dinner?
tags: thanksgiving, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, inflation, prices, turkeys, cost of food, increased prices, stew leonard, grocery store, do thanksgiving cheaper
title: How to Save Money on Thanksgiving Dinner

description: The Washington DC Popeyes location made infamous for rats on TikTok has been permanently closed. Besides rat droppings observed “adjacent to the grease bin,” the Health Department inspector found raw chicken held at improper temperatures, and a walk-in freezer with an “ambient air temperature” of 51.8 degrees Fahrenheit. Popeyes said in a statement, “This single restaurant does not reflect our strong food safety and cleanliness standards across Popeyes."
tags: washington dc, Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie offbeat, tiktok, Ricardo Land, popeyes, fast food, chicken, rats in popeyes, gofundme, fired, lost his job, delivery man, health hazard, viral tiktok, popeyes closed
title: Popeyes From Viral Rat TikTok Video Permanently Closed

description: We’re getting our first look at the night home invaders broke into the mansion of “Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” star Dorit Kemsley. Footage shows two men in hoodies and facemasks walking to the back of the house. They stand at the back door for a few minutes, before one of them breaks it, shattering glass everywhere. Kemsley was inside sleeping with her two children; her husband was away in London on business. Kemsley woke up and begged the invaders, “Don’t hurt my babies!"
tags: crime, california, ie celebrity, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, dorit kemsley, real housewives, burglary, burglars, rhobh, beverly hills, thieves, mansion, home invasion, surveillance footage, suspects, stolen goods, pk kemsley
title: How Burglars Ransacked Home of ‘Real Housewives’ Star

description: Lady Gaga is revealing for the first time that the dress she wore to sing the national anthem at President Biden’s inauguration was bulletproof. The singer-songwriter star of “A Star Is Born” revealed the secret of her protective couture with British Vogue. Born Stefani Germanotta, the Italian-American chanteuse will next appear as the infamous socialite Patrizia Reggiani in the film “House of Gucci.”
tags: celebrity, joe biden, politics, washington dc, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie celebrity, ie politics, lady gaga, inauguration, president biden, national anthem, singer, bulletproof vest, couture, bulletproof dress, fashion, vogue
title: Why Lady Gaga Wore a Bulletproof Vest at Inauguration

description: Did you know that you can use balled-up aluminum foil to sharpen dull scissors? This is just one of the useful tricks about household products shared with Inside Edition by lifestyle expert Erica Katz. You can also place foil under your ironing board cover to speed up ironing. Paper towels aren’t just for wiping up, they can also be used as a great wine chiller. Just wet and squeeze out paper towels, wrap them around your wine bottle and throw it in the freezer for 15 minutes.
tags: tips, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, tips and tricks, life hack, lifehack, aluminum foil, scissors, paper towels, wine chiller, ironing board, faster ironing, quickly chill wine, sharpen scissors, lemons, garlic, cereal bag, half empty cereal bag
title: Life Hacks With Common Household Items

description: Doug is perhaps the world’s biggest potato, or at least Colin and Donna Craig-Brown hope to find out. The New Zealand couple said they were simply weeding the garden when they found Doug. The current Guinness record holder for the largest potato is an 11-pound spud from England, while Doug weighs in at 17.4 pounds. The Craig-Browns are waiting to hear if Doug has officially won the title, and while they wait, Doug is chilling in the freezer.
tags: new zealand, guinness world record, Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie offbeat, potato, potato farmer, world’s largest, doug the potato, guinness world records, Donna Craig-Brown, Colin Craig-Brown, Gardener, potato garden, vegetable garden
title: ‘Biggest Potato in the World’ Is Living Its Best Life

description: This child roamed the earth 250,000 years ago. Researchers in South Africa recently found this fossilized skull is from a young Homo naledi. They named her Letimela, which means “the lost one” and they say she was between 4 and 6 years old when she died during the Middle Pleistocene era, which started 335 thousand years ago. The discovery was made in a cave 30 miles away from Johannesburg, where other Homo naledi remains have been found. Inside Edition Digital’s Mara Montalbano has more.
tags: ie science, south africa, nside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, mara montalbano, science, skull, homo naledi, homo naledi skull, paleontologists, ancient human remians
title: 250,000-Year-Old Skull Found in Cave in South Africa

description: Authorities in Missouri say they may have a serial killer in custody. Perez Reed, 25, was arrested on a federal charge of interstate transport of a firearm with the intent to commit a felony.  The FBI says when agents arrested him in Independence, he was carrying a .40-caliber firearm that was consistent with the weapon used in six shootings, four of them fatal, in Missouri and Kansas. Inside Edition Digital’s Mara Montalbano has more.
tags: missouri, kansas, serial killer, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, mara montalbano, kansas city, st louis, missouri shootings, perez reed, fbi, perez reed missouri, crime, forehead tattoo, independence, wesley bell, 40 caliber handgun
title: Forehead Tattoo Helps FBI Arrest Suspected Serial Killer

description: Is this the next Banksy painting to break an art world record? "Trolley Hunters" is going up for auction at Sotheby’s in New York on November 18th. It was created in 2005 and depicts tribal men pointing spears at shopping carts. The famed auction house estimates that it will sell between five and seven million dollars, but their last estimate of a Banksy piece was blown out of the water. Inside Edition Digital’s Mara Montalbano has more.
tags: Banksy, art, new York, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, mara montalbano, banksy, new york, sothebys, sothebys auction banksy, banksy auction, trolley hunters, banksy trolley hunters, banksy art, girl with balloon, love is in the bin
title: Will This Banksy Painting Break Another Art World Record?

description: The late Cameron Boyce was remembered fondly by his co-star Nicole Berger. “He just had a smile that could light up a room,” Berger said on “The Talk.” Boyce and Berger appear in the film “Runt,” which was Boyce’s last. “Runt” was shot in 2018, and was in post-production when Boyce died of an epileptic seizure in July of 2019. The film is dedicated to the young actor, and a portion of its proceeds will support the Cameron Boyce Foundation.
tags: celebrity, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, ie newsdesk, ie celebrity, cameron boyce, runt, nicole berger, the talk, actors, epilepsy, epileptic seizure, cameron boyce foundation, co-star, film, bullying, high school, descendants, sudep, legacy, 1091 pictures
title: Cameron Boyce’s Last Film Helps Keep His Legacy Alive

description: For the first time in 20 months, foreign citizens of at least 30 countries are being admitted to the United States, meaning those with loved ones abroad can be reunited and industries that depend on foreign tourists can begin to rebuild their businesses. Inside Edition was there as the first visitors from London touched down at JFK airport in New York. As the passengers came off the flight, they were not only greeted by cheers, but New York City cookies.
tags: ie newsdesk, travel, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, flight restrictions, international travel, new york, airports, europe, vaccines, vaccinated, rules, hospitality
title: US Eases Travel Restrictions for Vaccinated People

description: Misadventure Vodka has a response to America’s problem with food waste. The San Diego-based distillery gets expired breads and sweets from a food bank. The food can’t be served to people because most of it is past its “use-by” date. But Misadventure, which calls itself the world’s first carbon-negative spirit, says the bread can still be used to make alcohol. The company says, “Each batch of our vodka diverts about 1,000 lbs of food waste from the landfills.”
tags: california, food, ie offbeat, Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, food waste, vodka, bread into vodka, upcycling, Misadventure Vodka, Whit Rigali, vodka distillery, carbon neutral, carbon negative, environmental waste, baked goods, sustainability, san diego
title: Watch This Bread Get Upcycled Into Vodka

description: Homes and luxury dwellings on the island of La Palma have been buried under feet of volcanic ash, courtesy of the volcano known as La Cumbre Vieja. Scenes of everyday life interrupted, including children’s swings and living rooms, look like something out of a post-apocalyptic sci fi movie. La Cumbre Vieja began erupting in September, and volcanologists don’t know when it will stop. Meanwhile, it continues to make the familiar strange.
tags: Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, lava, spain, la palma, cumbre vieja, magma, molten rock, volcano, natural disaster, resort, ash, north africa, geology, evacuations, canary islands, spanish, evacuation, post apocalyptic
title: Ash ‘Eats’ Resort Town

description: A 4-ton chunk of iceberg from Greenland was hauled to the streets of Glasgow, Scotland, by an organization called Arctic Basecamp. Glasgow is currently hosting the United Nations’ COP26 climate summit. A representative from Arctic Basecamp told reporters, “We are trying to remind delegates that the Arctic is in crisis.” A recent report in Nature Communications said that 3.5 trillion tons of Greenland's ice sheet melted in the past decade.
tags: Climate Change, united kingdom, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, ie newsdesk, climate change, scotland, cop26, protest, environmental activists, global warming, glasgow, scottish, greenland, iceberg, arctic basecamp, melting ice caps, gail whiteman, titanic, frozen water, snl, melt
title: Icebergs Are Having a Moment...a Bad Moment

description: A liver donor and her recipient are spreading the word by running the New York City Marathon together. Dave Kane was diagnosed with cancer in the bile ducts of his liver over 4 years ago. Dave’s friend Sara Kate Gillingham volunteered to undergo testing and surgery, ultimately giving 60% of her liver. They are running the 26.2 miles of the New York City Marathon while raising money and awareness for the American Liver Foundation.
tags: new York, Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie heartwarming, marathon, liver transplant, nyc marathon, new york marathon, sara kate gillingham, dave kane, american liver foundation, raising money through marathon, live donor transplants, organ donation
title: Organ Donor and Recipient Running NYC Marathon

description:
Fans of the hit Netflix show set in the 1980s can rejoice. Netflix has opened ‘Stranger
Things’ pop-up stores on both coasts, in New York and Los Angeles on what is known as
‘Stranger Things Day.” The stores opened over the weekend on November 6th, a date
significant to the show (no spoilers!). The immersive experience also includes merch and
will only be open for a limited time. Inside Edition Digital’s Stephanie Officer has the details.
tags: entertainment, new York, los angeles, netflix, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie entertainment, ie offbeat, stranger things, mystery, tv shows, on demand, merch, pop up stores, pop ups, california, new york city, new york, stephanie officer
title: ‘Stranger Things’ Stores Pop up in New York, Los Angeles

description:
Researchers in Brazil say they have successfully artificially inseminated jaguars in an effort
to help protect genetic diversity in the species. After ensuring they are properly
impregnated, they will use the techniques on wild animals in other endangered areas.
Devastating wildfires have killed many jaguars. “They are being killed before we even get to
treat them, so something has to be done," Cristina Harumi Adania, veterinarian at Mata
Ciliar, says. Inside Edition Digital’s Stephanie Officer explains
tags: animals, brazil, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie animal kingdom, jaguars, science, research, pregnant animals, artificial insemination, genetic diversity, nature, big cats, ohio, Stephanie Officer, sao paulo, cincinnati zoo
title: These Jaguars Have Been Artificially Inseminated

description: Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers got slammed big time by NFL commentators for his sketchy claim of “immunization” when asked earlier in the season if he had been vaccinated. TV analysts and former players Terry Bradshaw and Michael Strahan derided Rodgers on national TV, with Strahan saying, “In the grand scheme of things, it’s deceptive and it’s wrong.” Saturday Night Live also took shots at Rodgers, who was portrayed by Pete Davidson.
tags: ie newsdesk, sports, Coronavirus, vaccine, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, Sports, Vaccine, aaron rodgers, Shailene Woodley, anti vax, natural remedy, homeopathic, unvaccinated, green bay packers, nfl, quarterback, pete davidson, snl, saturday night live, sirius
title: Aaron Rodgers Gets Little Sympathy From NFL Commentators

description: It’s a frantic effort to save a man trapped in a burning car. Bodycam footage shows officers rushing to the scene in a Florida parking lot as smoke billows from an SUV. The officers use a fire extinguisher to break the passenger window and unlock the doors, but they can’t tell where the person inside is. As the smoke clears, they see a man trapped in the driver’s seat. They race around to the front of the vehicle and are able to pull the man to safety.
tags: ie newsdesk, police, florida, Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, car fire, rescue, saved, smoke, police officer, cops save, cops rescue
title: Cops Smash Window of Burning Car to Save Man’s Life

description: Young dragons, their forked tongues darting, creep around a zoo enclosure in the city of Surabaya. Enter another effect of climate change: the potential extinction of the Komodo dragon. Experts are now trying to breed more of them to prevent that from happening. Zookeepers say they hope future generations would still be able to see the dragons in real life, not just in pictures. Inside Edition Digital’s Stephanie Officer explains.
tags: asia, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie animal kingdom, komodo dragon, animals, lizards, reptiles, zoo, climate change, cop26, world leaders, breeding, baby animals, dragons, zookeepers, glasgow, scotland, indonesia, Stephanie Officer
title: Why This Zoo Is Breeding Komodo Dragons

description: Stealing a van took too long for this would-be-thief, who police say had to bail out. Miami Dade Police released this video from inside what appears to be an Amazon delivery van. One camera angle caught a car pulling up next to the van. It shows a man get out of that car and into the driver’s seat of the van. Another angle shows the van's driver walking back to the vehicle as the suspect is trying to figure out how to start the van.
tags: Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, ie newsdesk, mara montalbano, crime, miami, florida, miami dade police, amazon, amazon delivery van, van thief, attempted auto theft, crime stoppers, shorts, surveillance camera, surveillance video
title: Attempt at Stealing Delivery Van Foiled When Driver Returns #shorts

description: Picture your wedding day: the invitations, the suit, the dress, and strangers. Dozens of strangers who are also sharing your same wedding date, time, and venue. Would you jump the broom in a mass wedding event? That’s exactly what 30 couples did over the weekend in La Paz, Bolivia, in an effort to cut costs on what can be a hugely expensive event. Inside Edition Digital’s Stephanie Officer explains how it was done.
tags: Bolivia, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, ie offbeat, weddings, marriage, officiate, couples, love, relationships, union, big wedding, la paz, bolivia, Stephanie Officer, south america, latin america, spanish, husband, wife, mass wedding, bolivian
title: Would You Get Married in a Mass Wedding for Cheap?

description: Following the deadly shooting on the set of “Rust,” mandatory prop gun safety training is now part of one school’s curriculum. “Hopefully going forward, this can be a wake-up call and hopefully something positive can come out of this terrible tragedy,” said master armorer Clay Van Sickle. The 18-year veteran of the industry visited students at the theater of arts in Los Angeles for a special session.
tags: california, ie newsdesk, Inside edition, Inside_edition, props, rust, rust movie, rust set, gun safety, acting courses, training
title: Actors Learn Gun Safety Skills Following ‘Rust’ Shooting

description: Students from The Quileute Tribal School are accustomed to living on picturesque land, bordered by the Pacific ocean. Trouble is, the effects of climate change run so deep they threaten the very land the Quileute Tribe calls home, and the community may have to find somewhere else to live. “That's the toughest thing you know? We don't want to give up our land. We signed over so much land to stay here,” Ann Penn Charles told CBS News. Inside Edition Digital’s Stephanie Officer explains.
tags: washington, Climate Change, Inside edition, inside_edition, ie newsdesk, quileute tribe, native american, land, climate change, cop26, pacific ocean, nature, community, school, students, olympic peninsula, la push, Stephanie Officer, indigenous people, national park
title: Climate Change is Eroding Tribal Land

description: Whoa! Nobody saw that one coming! A speeding car avoided hitting the nearby police vehicles, but slammed right into a utility pole. West Palm Beach Florida Police officers who, lucky for this driver, were already on the scene jumped into action. With a fire extinguisher and some muscle, they rescued the person behind the wheel. And despite the fiery crash, authorities say no one was seriously hurt.
tags: Inside Edition, inside_edition, ie shorts, ie offbeat, florida, car crash, west palm beach, fiery crashes, hero cops, near miss, speeding car, car crashes into pole
title: Fiery Car Crash Narrowly Misses Florida Cops #shorts

description: Over the years Inside Edition has had unprecedented access to some of the most iconic women in music. From a sit-down with the Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin, to hanging out backstage with Queen Bey and Solange to shopping with Aaliyah and going to an audition with J.Lo, our cameras have caught it all and then some.
tags: music, celebrity, new York, beyonce, inside edition, inside_edition, ie flashback, ie celebrity, aretha franklin, aaliyah, britney spears, jennifer lopez, jlo, solange, amy winehouse, new york city, detroit, queen bey, motown, queen of soul, singers, pop stars, icons
title: Some of Music’s Most Iconic Women

description: It wasn’t a cat in a tree situation, but these firefighters came to the rescue anyway. A deer was seen treading water in a canal in California. The Sacramento Metro Fire District deployed a raft to give it some help. The deer was resistant at first, especially when a firefighter first tried to wrangle it around the antlers. Then they tied a rope around its neck for the short trip back to land. Inside Edition Digital’s Mara Montalbano has more.
tags: Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, IE Newsdesk, mara montalbano, california, sacramento, sacramento fire department, deer, deer rescue, deer saved from canal, deer saved from drowning, drowning deer, firefighters save deer, shorts, first responders, animals, animal rescue, buck, heroes, sacramento fd, animal wranglers
title: Firefighters Rescue Tired Deer Treading Water in Canal #shorts

description: A little girl was fishing in an Alabama pond when she got a bite. Annie was excited as she reeled in the fish, telling her mother, “I got a big one!” But when she hauled her catch onto shore, it turned out to be to a lot smaller than she anticipated. “This is so tiny,” she complained.
tags: Inside Edition, Inside_Edition, ie newsdesk, little girl, shorts, fishing, fish tale, it’s tiny, viralhog, cute kid, angler, fishing rod, alabama, dothan, pond, catch, mom, mother, disappointment
title: Little Girl Reels in a ‘Big’ Fish #shorts

description: What a mess! A great big St. Bernard puppy named Gigi was captured on camera emptying her family’s inflatable swimming pool. The canine rested its big paws on the edge of the pool, causing a torrent of water to spill over the side. A man yelled, “Gigi, stop!” But the damage was done, as the yard became flooded.

According to a 2020 Brand Keys Consumer Loyalty Engagement Index report, FOX News is the top brand in the country for morning and evening news coverage. A 2019 Suffolk University poll named FOX News as the most trusted source for television news or commentary, while a 2019 Brand Keys Emotion Engagement Analysis survey found that FOX News was the most trusted cable news brand. A 2017 Gallup/Knight Foundation survey also found that among Americans who could name an objective news source, FOX News was the top-cited outlet. Owned by FOX Corporation, FNC is available in nearly 90 million homes and dominates the cable news landscape, routinely notching the top ten programs in the genre.

description:
South Korea is facing a dire shortage of urea that is threatening to halt transport, businesses and industries.
The government is sending a military oil tanker to airlift urea solution from Australia to meet its demands.
Diesel vehicles there – especially transport trucks - cannot run without the chemical compound.  
But its biggest supplier, China, is curbing exports and that could have a huge effect on South Korea's economy.
Al Jazeera's Priyanka Gupta explains.

- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/

description:
Liberia’s government is leading a campaign to get African Americans to come and settle there, offering citizenships and a “chance to reconnect with their roots”.
 
This movement is not new, with freed enslaved people from the US having arrived some 200 years ago to build the colony that became the Republic of Liberia.
 
This set off a troubled period in Liberia’s history as the new arrivals clashed with the Indigenous tribes.
 
Memories of that time, and the lessons they teach, are what local architects want to protect now as they try to stop the destruction of old properties to make way for more new arrivals.
 
 
Al Jazeera's Nicolas Haque reports from the Liberian capital, Monrovia. 

- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/
- Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/
- Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

#Liberia

title: Is Liberia tearing down its history?

President Daniel Ortega has led a months-long crackdown on his opponents as he seeks a controversial fourth term in power.
Al Jazeera's Lucia Newman reports from Alajuela, Costa Rica.

description:
In the city of Juarez, Ana Gonzalez works day in and day out picking up fragments of bullets, glass and samples of blood.

The work is relentless and emotionally exhausting, compounded by cartel violence that comes from being a Mexican city so close to its neighbour, the United States.

As Gonzalez grapples with the sheer volume of homicides in one of the region’s deadliest cities, she and her team undergo a special departmental inspection.

If they pass, Gonzalez’s team will receive crucial support from the US government to help them with their investigations.

description:
For half a century, the International Energy Agency had one goal: to make sure its patrons, the world’s richest nations, had uninterrupted access to oil.

Now, it is warning the world to stop developing new oil and gas fields to avoid a catastrophic rise in temperatures.

Despite that warning, Arctic oil and gas production is expected to increase by 20 percent in the next five years. Reclaim Finance's Alix Mazounie explains which banks are backing big oil.

As Asia deepens its dependence on coal, Carbon Tracker's Catharina Hillenbrand von der Neyen discusses what can be done to reverse the trend.
tags: aljazeera, arctic, banking, climate, countingthecost, gas, oil, climate change, cop26, business and economy
title: The Western banks enabling big oil to exploit the Arctic | Counting the Cost

description:
Hundreds of thousands of people have demonstrated in several Ethiopian cities in support of government forces battling a rebel advance. The largest demonstration was held in the capital, Addis Ababa.
Concern is growing after the year-long conflict against Tigrayan rebels intensified.
The Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) has captured strategic towns along the road to the capital and has threatened to move on Addis Ababa. 
Al Jazeera's Mohammed Adow reports.

description:
Talks and initiatives on the environment are usually driven by the world’s superpowers, but many of the largest economies appear to be failing when it comes to clean energy. Now Chile is trying to have a louder voice.

As recent reports from the United Nations reveal just how much damage human activity has done to our planet, can Chile succeed in becoming a green-energy powerhouse?

The country's Energy Minister, Juan Carlos Jobet, is widely seen as Chile's champion in the fight against climate change. He talks to Al Jazeera.
tags: Interview, Juan Carlos Jobet, chile, climate, climate change, energy, talktoaljazeera
title: Chile’s energy minister: Driving a green hydrogen boom? | Talk to Al Jazeera

description:
On October 25 - just weeks before Sudan's military was supposed to hand over control of the transitional government to the civilian leadership - General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan seized control in a military coup and declared a state of emergency.

The army dissolved the joint civilian-military government and arrested Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok. Protesters have taken to the streets to denounce the coup, but security forces have responded forcefully.

This week on UpFront, Marc Lamont Hill speaks with Sudan’s ambassador to the United States, Nureldin Satti, who says the coup “cannot continue with the mobilisation that we have seen and that we are going to see in the next days and weeks".
tags: Al Jazeera, Sudan, coup, government, military, politics, protests, upfront, Nureldin Satti
title: Can Sudan's military coup survive popular resistance? | UpFront

But illegal mining and construction on the protected mountain range may also be adding to the area’s worsening climate effects.
Al Jazeera's Elizabeth Puranam reports from Kerala, India.

description:
Following weeks of escalating tensions between Sudan’s military and civilian leaders, the country faces yet another political crisis.

The army, led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, took control of the government on October 25.

As tens of thousands of pro-democracy protesters took to the streets, many in the international community condemned the military’s power grab.

Al-Burhan promised to protect the road to democracy in Sudan, but what guarantees are there that he will fulfil his promise?

He has also announced elections in 2023, will he put forward his name as a presidential candidate?

General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, talks to Al Jazeera.

Al Jazeera’s Mike Hanna reports from UN headquarters in New York, the US.

description:
Climate change is fast approaching the point of no return.

From extreme heatwaves, wildfires, and drought in the western part of the United States to deadly floods in Nigeria, climate disasters are forcing people to flee from their homelands in search of safety. Estimates predict hundreds of millions will be forced to migrate by 2050.

How are countries and international institutions going to tackle the issue of protecting climate refugees? This week on UpFront, Filippo Grandi, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, tells Marc Lamont Hill that “in a world that is going towards more displacement ... including because of climate,” the response from rich countries has been “wrong in so many different ways".
tags: Al Jazeera, Migrantion, UNHCR, climate, climate change, cop26, filippo grandi, global warming, refugees, upfront
title: Who will protect people displaced by climate change? | UpFront

description:
Nicaragua's President Daniel Ortega is running for a fourth consecutive term, despite widespread criticism the campaign has been neither free nor fair.
Ortega's administration has overseen a campaign to arrest 40 opposition members and as a result, the incumbent is running virtually unopposed in Sunday's vote.
Human rights groups say Ortega has increasingly clamped down on dissent, especially since protests began against plans to cut pensions and raise taxes in 2018.
Al Jazeera's Latin America Editor Lucia Newman reports from San Jose, Costa Rica.

description:
The Al Jazeera Media Network turns 25 years old this month and looks back at a history marked by obstacles, threats and attacks; none of which deterred it from pursuing its journalism with fairness, accuracy and a focus on telling the world's unheard stories. 

Al Jazeera launched as an Arabic-language satellite news channel in 1996, broadcasting from Qatar's capital Doha, with a mission to challenge the manner in which the dominant international news channels at the time framed global events from a Western perspective.

The first independent news channel in the Arab world, it featured an array of voices, including perspectives from all sides - a policy that drew ire from many. Since then, it has grown into a network of multiple channels and digital platforms, including Al Jazeera English and AJ+.

Al Jazeera has been the news source for several of the biggest stories over the past quarter of a century - the Gulf War, the Arab Spring, multiple conflicts in Gaza, and historic events in the Middle East, Africa and elsewhere. Then US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in 2011 said the state department was getting most of its information on the Arab Spring from Al Jazeera.

"Viewership of Al Jazeera is going up in the United States because it's real news," she said.

In this show, we gather a panel of voices from Al Jazeera Arabic, Al Jazeera English and AJ+ to discuss the highs and lows of the past 25 years and to take questions, and hear thoughts from the network's audience. 


Join the conversation: 
TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream 
FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream 
Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe

description:
The trial of three white men accused of killing a black man in the US State of Georgia last year began on Friday.
Ahmaud Arbery who was out for a jog was shot dead after being chased by the group in pick-up trucks.
Lawyers for the three men argued they had reason to suspect he had committed a crime. But Arbery's prosecutor said the men’s decision was not based on concrete evidence.
But even before Friday's proceedings started, there were accusations of racial bias as the 12-member jury only included one Black person.
Al Jazeera's Andy Gallacher reports.

description:
The UN COP26 climate conference in Glasgow is at its halfway point.

World leaders have been debating ways to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees celcius.

description:

description:
At least nine United Nations staff members and their dependents have been detained in the Ethiopian capital, the world body said.
A UN spokesperson said on Tuesday that the UN had submitted a request to Ethiopia’s foreign ministry to immediately release those detained in Addis Ababa.
UN security officials have visited the detained staff, the spokesperson added.
There was no immediate comment by the Ethiopian government, which has been battling forces from the northern Tigray region for a year.

description:
Former US Secretary of State Colin Powell's family and friends, gathering for his funeral on Friday, poured tributes on the four-star general, calling him a friend and "one of the greatest leaders".
He died last month of complications from COVID-19 at the age of 84.
He was the first Black national security adviser and the first chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
But he will also be remembered for advocating for the US-led war against Iraq in 2003, which he said years later was a "blot on my record".
Al Jazeera's Patty Culhane reports from Washington, DC, the US.

description:
The UN Security Council has for the first time called for an end to the fighting in Ethiopia, but a meeting to discuss the crisis has been postponed until next week.
Ethiopia's year-long conflict with rebels from the northern Tigray region has worsened recently with the Tigrayan People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) forces seizing key cities on a highway that leads towards the capital.
The Oromo Liberation Army and seven other groups from around the country have now joined the TPLF in the fighting.
Al Jazeera's Mike Hanna reports from the United Nations, New York, the US.

description:
The United States and European Union are leading calls to reject the outcome of Nicaragua’s election, along with neighbouring Costa Rica, after President Daniel Ortega won about 76 percent of Sunday’s vote - securing a fourth term.
Most opposition figures have been arrested or barred from running in the last few months while international observers and journalists have been kept at bay.
 
Al Jazeera’s Lucia Newman reports from San Jose, in neighbouring Costa Rica.

description:
As Tigrayan rebels advanced towards the capital Addis Ababa this week, Ethiopia declared a state of emergency with Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed calling on citizens to take up arms and defend the city. 

The conflict - which started a year ago in the northern region of Tigray - has spread to the neighbouring states of Afar and Amhara. Tigrayan fighters are now moving south towards the capital, so far claiming control over two cities north of Addis Ababa.
 
Thousands of people have been killed in the conflict, millions have been displaced and hundreds of thousands are enduring famine conditions, according to the UN.

The war began in November 2020 when Ethiopia's central government launched an offensive against the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), the then ruling party of the Tigray region, in response to what the government said was a TPLF attack an army base. 

All sides in the conflict have committed atrocities that may amount to war crimes and crimes against humanity, according to a report by the UN and Ethiopian government-run Ethiopian Human Rights Commission (EHRC). UN human rights chief Michelle Bachelet said, though, that "the big numbers of violations” were linked to the Ethiopian military and to the Eritrean military, which entered the conflict on the side of the government.

In this episode of The Stream, we’ll discuss the ongoing conflict and its impact on Ethiopians.

description:
The Big Picture: Britain’s True Colours? addresses a singular question: When it came to the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, why did Black and brown people die in disproportionately greater numbers than white people?

The answer, as is revealed, can be traced to two prevailing aspects of the modern UK: racism and neoliberalism. This film examines the roots of these converging forces.

By mixing documentary storytelling with in-depth analysis, three British journalists, writer/director Sanjiev Johal, reporter Flo Phillips, and assistant producer Hanna Adan, allow history to cast new light on the effect of COVID. They show how structural racism, racialised capitalism and neoliberal orthodoxy were not just central to the pandemic experience, but to the shaping of the UK itself.

Charting post-war British history through to the aftermath of the pandemic, this film explains why rampant inequality and racial injustice remains embedded in the UK today.

Contributors:
Kehinde Andrews - Professor of Black studies, Birmingham City University and author of, Resisting Racism
Gargi Bhattacharyya - Research professor, Centre for Migration, Refugees and Belonging, University of East London and author of, Rethinking Racial Capitalism
Lee Jones - Professor in international politics, Queen Mary University of London and author of, Societies Under Siege
Meenal Viz - National Health Service (NHS) doctor
tags: Britain’s True Colours?, Britain, united kingdom, uk, uk racism, al Jazeera live, al Jazeera, al Jazeera English, al Jazeera news, al Jazeera documentary, the big picture, the big picture al Jazeera, big picture, big picture al Jazeera
title: Britain’s True Colours? | The Big Picture

description:
Climate activist Greta Thunberg has branded this year's COP26 summit a "greenwash campaign" at the end of the first week of the UN talks to solve the environmental crisis.
She was addressing young protesters after they marched through central Glasgow, rallying against what they said was global leaders' phlegmatic response to global warming.
Thunberg called for an immediate cut to carbons emissions and berated the event as a PR exercise.
Al Jazeera's Andrew Simmons reports from Glasgow, Scotland.

description:
Americans have been debating the role of the police for decades, but the debate was energised last year during nationwide Black Lives Matter protests.

For many in the white majority, the police must be defended at all costs. If there are proven cases of abuse, they can be resolved on a case-by-case basis. For the rest, the police are seen as the main mechanism that enforces the status quo on society, including racial inequality.

Brooklyn College professor Alex Vitale tells host Steve Clemons that Americans should rethink policing, especially when dealing with schools, the homeless, and mental health cases.
tags: Al Jazeera, Racism, black lives matter, defund police, police, the bottom line, united states, usa
title: What happened to ‘defund the police’? | The Bottom Line

description:
On September 8, 2020, a grass fire started in Ashland, Oregon. In less than three hours it spread to neighboring Talent. A separate ignition added to the blaze, resulting in the fire spreading to Phoenix, and Medford. 2,500 homes were burnt down, displacing 3,000 people, and killing three. This is the first hand look at what it was like inside the fire.

description:
Stetson cowboy hats are an iconic American accessory. The popular Skyline style will cost you $245, while other premium varieties can set you back $5,000. Over the years, famous figures like President Ronald Reagan and Beyonce have worn Stetsons, further solidifying the brand's image as the premier American cowboy hat. It's one of the few hat brands that have reached icon status. So what made Stetson so iconic? And is that why these hats are so expensive?

description:
From shiitakes to criminis, 60% of America's mushrooms come from one small Pennsylvania town, Kennett Square. But America's mushroom capital is getting hit hard with a labor shortage. With not enough pickers, farmers have been forced to kill off rooms of mushrooms they can't get to in time. It's led to million-dollar losses for mushroom farmers already operating on thin margins. So what caused the labor crunch, and can the industry recover? We visited three mushroom farms in Kennett Square to find out.

description:
After a settlement was reached in February between Amazon and the FTC, certain drivers will finally start to receive payments for tips that were withheld by Amazon. Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2021/11/03/amazon-will-pay-back-withheld-tips-from-drivers/6265205001/

"Over 140,000 Amazon drivers are being repaid nearly $60 million in tips that the company allegedly withheld from them, the Federal Trade Commission announced Tuesday.
The FTC and Amazon reached a settlement in February, with the company agreeing to pay more than $61.7 million, the full amount the tech giant allegedly withheld which will be used by the FTC to compensate Amazon Flex drivers."

description:
A California teacher is under fire after students recorded a QAnon-inspired rant during an 8th-grade history class. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.alternet.org/2021/11/anti-vax-teacher/

"A mother in Ventura, California is furious after her son came home saying she and his father lied to him after his 8th-grade history teacher told the class Donald Trump is still president, hospitals steal newborn babies from unvaccinated parents, Hunter Biden's laptop had child pornography on it, and he's never going to get vaccinated ever again.

"He's damaged. He's hurt. He's scared. He doesn't trust his parents now. He thinks we lied to him," Sarah Silikula told CBS affiliate KCAL."

description:
In a surprising turn from Tucker Carlson’s usual behavior, the Fox News host went at Trump’s neck on his internet show by saying it was “appalling” that Trump has yet to donate any money to his supporters that were arrested in connection with the January 6th Capitol Riots. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.mediaite.com/politics/tucker-carlson-shocked-that-trump-hasnt-sent-jan-6-rioters-any-money-i-just-find-that-appalling/?utm_source=mostpopular

"Fox News host Tucker Carlson — who is currently rolling out his controversial three-part Fox Nation series on the January 6th insurrection — made a rare on-air break with former President Donald Trump on Monday night.

Carlson, while interviewing right-wing commentator Julie Kelly, said he finds it “appalling” that Trump had yet to donate any money to his supporters who were arrested on January 6th at the U.S. Capitol."

description:
Billionaire investor and Goldman-Sachs alum Leon Cooperman believe that the proposed billionaire tax is unconstitutional and that the Democrats are "attacking billionaires for no reason”. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://news.yahoo.com/billionaire-hates-wealth-tax-says-100000601.html

"For a few brief hours on Wednesday, it seemed like Democrats would propose a tax on billionaires.

Democrats are still hammering out the details of what will be in a final social-spending package, but the tax-focused on billionaires looks like it's getting chopped. The architect of the tax, Sen. Ron Wyden, the chair of the Senate finance committee, told Insider's Joseph Zeballos-Roig that "this is not done" as he fights to keep it alive.

But at least one person who would be affected by the proposal would be thrilled to see it on the cutting-room floor."

description:
Capitol rioter Jenna Ryan was very confident that she wouldn’t face any jail time due to her involvement in the insurrection. She was wrong. Cenk Uygur, Jayar Jackson, and Francesca Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

"Capitol rioter Jenna Ryan continued to lash out at the media and others on Thursday evening, after she was sentenced to 60 days behind bars for her role in the Jan. 6 insurrection.

Ryan, a Dallas-area realtor who traveled to DC on a private plane before the insurrection, infamously boasted on Twitter in March that she wouldn't face incarceration because she's white and blonde. In court on Thursday, federal prosecutors cited the tweet in arguing for a prison sentence."

description:
Fox News correspondent Peter Doocy faced backlash from White House adviser Cedric Richmond over some disturbing questions Doocy asked President Biden regarding payouts to migrant families that have lost a child due to Trump administration policies. David Schuster and Francesa Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.alternet.org/2021/11/fox-news/

"White House adviser Cedric Richmond appeared on Fox News over the weekend where he blasted correspondent Peter Doocy for asking President Joe Biden "absurd" questions about migrant families.

During a Sunday interview on Fox News, host Bill Hemmer presented a video of Doocy grilling the president about payouts to migrant families who lost a child due to the policies of former President Donald Trump's administration. At the time, Doocy suggested that some migrant families may plot to have a child taken away from them in hopes of getting money from the U.S. government.

Doocy said that the payments might "incentivize" families to want to lose children in exchange for money."

description:
Former President Trump did not hold back his criticisms of Congressional Republicans who voted in favor of the recently-passed bipartisan infrastructure bill, singling out Mitch McConnell as the most at fault. David Schuster and Francesa Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/580471-trump-bashes-moderate-republicans-mcconnell-over-bipartisan

"Former President Trump on Sunday doubled down on his criticism of Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and other Senate Republicans who voted in favor of passing a $1.2 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill.

“All Republicans who voted for Democrat longevity should be ashamed of themselves, in particular Mitch McConnell, for granting a two-month stay which allowed the Democrats time to work things out at our Country’s, and the Republican Party’s, expense!” Trump said in a statement."

description:
Southwest Airlines is back in the headlines after a flight attendant reported a white mother with her biracial child as being “suspicious” of human trafficking. Cenk Uygur, Jayar Jackson, and Francesca Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://news.yahoo.com/mom-her-biracial-child-were-211246241.html

"A white California mom and her biracial 10-year-old daughter were stopped by police for suspected human trafficking after a Southwest Airlines flight attendant reported the pair as "suspicious" - an incident the mother called "racist harassment."

Mary MacCarthy, 42, told Insider that she and her daughter, Moira, boarded a Southwest Airlines flight from Los Angeles to Denver with a connecting flight in San Jose on October 22 in order to be with her family following the sudden death of her brother."

description:

Read more HERE:  
https://www.kezi.com/content/news/Fight-erupts-at-Eugene-store-over-mask-mandate-575670731.html

"The owner of a Eugene cookie store was assaulted while trying to enforce the mask mandate on Wednesday, police say.

It happened at about 11 a.m. at Crumb Together on Oak Street when a man and woman walked into the business and refused to wear a mask, police said. Police said Ricki Collin, 34, and Amy Hall, 45, both of the Portland area, were arrested and taken to the Lane County Jail after the altercation."

"Authorities were able to find a missing 16-year-old girl after she caught the attention of a driver by using hand gestures popularized on the social media platform TikTok.

description:
West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin drives his coal-funded Maserati into a group of climate change protestors. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more here: https://www.mediaite.com/politics/joe-manchin-maserati-protest/

"Sen. Joe Manchin (D-WV) was loudly confronted by numerous Sunrise Movement climate change activists on Thursday morning. They greeted the West Virginia senator outside of his houseboat this morning and followed him to his Maserati, according to HuffPost’s Jennifer Bendery.

The activists were protesting his opposition to large portions of President Joe Biden’s Build Back Better agenda, including measures related to climate change. Manchin was heading toward a parking garage as a large group of protestors surrounded him chanting, “We want to live!”*

description:
Sesame Street icon Big Bird announced on Twitter this week that he received his first COVID-19 vaccine shot, garnering praise from the Twitter community and even President Biden. However, not everyone was happy about the news, especially Republican Senator Ted Cruz. David Schuster and Francesa Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/11/08/ted-cruz-big-bird-vaccine-tweet/

"Big Bird, like scores of American 6-year-olds, became eligible for the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine last week. On Saturday, he announced he had lined up for his shot.

“My wing is feeling a little sore, but it’ll give my body an extra protective boost that keeps me and others healthy,” the big, feathered yellow bird, who is eternally 6 years old, wrote on Twitter.

“Good on ya, @BigBird. Getting vaccinated is the best way to keep your whole neighborhood safe,” President Biden tweeted in response."

description:
A recent ‘independent' review conducted by Air Force Lt. Gen. Sami Said concluded that there was no misconduct by the U.S. concerning a drone strike that killed innocent civilians, including seven children in Afghanistan. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://apnews.com/article/afghanistan-kabul-bf24b4a670895ab1cc0b345ee9c90c74?utm_source=Twitter&utm_campaign=SocialFlow&utm_medium=AP

"An independent Pentagon review has concluded that the U.S. drone strike that killed innocent Kabul civilians and children in the final days of the Afghanistan war was not caused by misconduct or negligence, and it doesn’t recommend any disciplinary action.

The review, done by Air Force Lt. Gen. Sami Said, found there were breakdowns in communication and in the process of identifying and confirming the target of the bombing. Said concluded that the mistaken strike happened despite prudent measures to prevent civilian deaths."

description:
The Federal Elections Commission is now allowing for foreign actors to make financial donations to U.S. ballot committees, opening the door for foreign nationals to influence U.S. elections and voters. Cenk Uygur, John Iadarola, and Caroline Johnson discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.axios.com/fec-foreign-money-referendum-dcc92322-05ad-4093-8bb8-35446ef6c964.html?utm_campaign=organic&utm_medium=socialshare&utm_source=twitter

"The Federal Election Commission has ruled foreign donors can finance U.S. referendum campaigns, opening the door to foreign spending on fights over high-profile policy issues, Axios has learned.

Foreign nationals are barred from donating to U.S. political candidates or committees. But the FEC's decision — allowing them to support ballot committees — provides another avenue for foreigners to directly influence U.S. voters and domestic policy."

description:
Pramila Jayapal did not hold back on her criticisms of Texas’ controversial abortion law, specifically targeting Texas Rep. Chip Roy and his attitudes towards women. Cenk Uygur, Jayar Jackson, and Francesca Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.mediaite.com/tv/pramila-jayapal-torches-chip-roy/

"During a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Texas’s controversial abortion law on Thursday, Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-WA) absolutely laid into Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX) for his “paternalistic” attitude toward women.

At issue in the hearing was S.B. 8 in Texas, which is a highly unusual anti-abortion law that doesn’t rely on state enforcement, but rather allows private citizens to sue people they think have assisted a woman in getting an abortion after six weeks of pregnancy. The law is also known as the Texas Heartbeat Act, so named because six weeks is around the time fetal cardiac activity can be detected. As many critics of the law have pointed out, many if not most women do not even know they are pregnant at six weeks."

description:
A Texas family who purchases 12 gallons of milk EVERY WEEK seemingly shows that inflation and small price surges have very real impacts on consumers. However, polling and price data does not fully support this narrative. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.dailydot.com/debug/12-gallons-milk-meme-twitter-cnn/

"This is a blog post that needs to begin with three caveats. First, inflation has had a very real impact, and it is squeezing the purse strings of the Americans who are least capable of stomaching it. Second, if you have a family, you are free to feed them and support their needs however you see fit. Third, the internet is full of callous, misanthropic East Coasters who often look down disdainfully on middle America, and highlighting their mockery is probably not the best use of anyone’s time That said, (and we really do mean those three caveats), this lady in Texas is buying a lot of milk."

description:
Popular rapper Travis Scott’s Astroworld Festival took a turn for the worst this weekend after 8 people lost their lives and hundreds more were injured in a crowd surge during Scott’s set. Adrian Lawrence and Francesa Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/9656358/astroworld-security-officer-needle-prick-narcan

"During a news conference Saturday (Nov. 6) about the tragedy that claimed eight lives during Travis Scott's Astroworld Festival on Friday (Nov. 5) night, Houston Police Chief Troy Finner confirmed a report about an officer receiving a needle prick from an unknown person.

"We do have a report of a security officer, according to the medical staff that treated him last night, that he was reaching over to restrain or grab a citizen and he felt a prick in his neck,” Finner said during the news conference. The security officer went unconscious, was treated with Narcan and was successfully revived. Medical staff treating the security officer later noticed evidence of a prick mark in the man's neck consistent with that of an injection."

description:
Xenophobic Senate Republicans have blocked the appointment of Dilawar Syed to the Small Business Administration, which would make him one of the highest-ranking Muslim officials in the country. https://www.businessinsider.com/republicans-continue-hateful-bigoted-blockade-of-muslim-biden-nominee-2021-11

"For the fourth time, Senate Republicans blocked the consideration of Dilawar Syed, the CEO of a healthcare AI company and President Joe Biden's nominee to serve as deputy administrator of the Small Business Administration, in the Senate's Small Business Committee. If confirmed, Syed would be the highest-ranking official in the federal government who is a practicing Muslim.

Syed is not the only Biden nominee facing a blockade — Republican Sens. Ted Cruz and Josh Hawley have put a hold on many of the president's diplomatic and national security-related nominees as well. But this blockade, according to Senate Democrats and religious advocacy groups, is different."

description:
Anderson Cooper grills Congressional Progressive Caucus leader Pramila Jayapal about the recent Democrat loss in the Virginia gubernatorial race. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.mediaite.com/tv/anderson-cooper-grills-jayapal-on-democrats-election-losses-do-you-take-any-blame-in-this/

"Anderson Cooper interrogated Rep. Pramila Jayapal, chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, on Wednesday night and asked whether she bears some responsibility for Democrats losing Virginia’s governorship.

Republican Glenn Youngkin defeated Democrat Terry McAuliffe as a pair of spending bills were slowly making their way through Congress. In August, the Senate passed a bipartisan infrastructure package that is waiting to be taken up by the House. Speaker Nancy Pelosi had originally said she wouldn’t bring it to the floor until the Senate had also passed a separate reconciliation bill containing Joe Biden’s Build Back Better agenda."

description:
The judge overseeing Kyle Rittenhouse’s trial has dismissed a juror after the juror made a crude joke about Jacob Blake, who was shot by Kenosha police. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://lawandcrime.com/live-trials/live-trials-current/kyle-rittenhouse/judge-boots-juror-from-kyle-rittenhouse-murder-trial-for-making-jokes-to-bailiff-about-police-shooting-of-jacob-blake/

"Saying that the “appearance of bias is present,” the judge overseeing the intentional homicide trial of Kenosha, Wis. shooter Kyle Rittenhouse on Thursday morning dismissed a juror who made an inappropriate joke about the police shooting of Jacob Blake.

Judge Bruce Schroeder talked with prosecutors and defense attorneys without the jury present to discuss the matter involving Juror #7’s purported joke on Thursday morning."

description:
Pretty much the entire jury has been replaced in the Ahmaud Arbery trial after defense attorneys and the overseeing judge determined that there was “intentional discrimination” in selecting the jury. After starting with 12 African-American jurors, there only remains one after replacement. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/salvadorhernandez/jury-black-ahmaud-arbery-trial

"Defense attorneys removed 11 of the 12 Black potential jurors Wednesday, ensuring that the three white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery will face a nearly all-white jury in their trial.

Just one Black person will serve as a juror in the trial of three white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, even after the judge overseeing the case said there appeared to be "intentional discrimination" in jury selection."

description:
The mainstream media is at it again and this time they’re blaming Pramila Jayapal and other Progressives for supporting supposedly unpopular policies even though the same policies are polling extremely well with voters. Cenk Uygur, John Iadarola, and Caroline Johnson discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://thehill.com/homenews/house/580243-jayapal-its-worth-passing-spending-plan-even-if-dems-lose-house

"Congressional Progressive Caucus Chair Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) said on Friday that it’s worth Democrats passing the party’s sweeping social spending and climate change package even if they lose the House in next year’s midterm elections.

Jayapal was asked early Friday ahead of an expected vote on the legislation if it's worth the party passing the legislation if it could help the GOP take back the House next year, just as Republicans did in 2010 following passage of the Affordable Care Act."

description:
Right-wing Rep. Lauren Boebert posed for a photo with Donald Trump earlier this week donning a ridiculous dress with the phrase “Let’s Go Brandon”, taking a shot at AOC's "Tax The Rich" dress. Cenk Uygur Jayar Jackson and Francesca Fiorentini discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://news.yahoo.com/rep-lauren-boebert-takes-brandon-081644471.html?guccounter=1

"Conspiracy theory-endorsing Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) wore a dress emblazoned with the anti-President Joe Biden phrase “Let’s Go Brandon” and posed for a photo with ex-President Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago resort on Wednesday.

“It’s not a phrase, it’s a movement,” Boebert wrote on Twitter, referencing the phrase that’s gone viral among conservatives since a NASCAR sportscaster mistook it for a “F--- Joe Biden” chant at a race last month."

description:
Popular right-wing YouTuber and prominent anti-vaxxer Tim Pool has contracted COVID-19, along with other members of his media team, following a recent live show his company organized in a West Virginia bar and restaurant. Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://www.thedailybeast.com/tim-pool-caught-covid-and-joe-rogan-offered-to-pay-his-medical-bills

“Tim Pool, one of the more prolific and popular political YouTubers on the right, has come down with a bad case of COVID-19, as he described it in a video posted Wednesday morning.

The virus has been spread to multiple members of his media company, who began testing positive a week or so after Pool hosted a well-attended indoor event at a bar and grill in nearby Charles Town, West Virginia. During the combination comedy, musical, and Q&A show, parts of which were shown in a paywall-protected video, Pool’s producer gave a shout-out to people who’d refused to get vaccinated, encouraging them to hold fast. The audience cheered her."

description:
Pfizer has just announced that they have developed a potentially groundbreaking pill treatment for COVID-19 that reportedly reduces risk of hospitalization and death by ~90% if taken quick enough after symptoms develop. Cenk Uygur, John Iadarola, and Caroline Johnson discuss on The Young Turks. Watch LIVE weekdays 6-8 pm ET. http://youtube.com/theyoungturks/live

Read more HERE:  
https://abcnews.go.com/Health/pfizers-covid-19-pill-reduces-risk-hospitalized-dying/story?id=80979366

"A course of pills developed by Pfizer can slash the risk of being hospitalized or dying from COVID-19 by 89% if taken within three days of developing symptoms, according to results released Friday by the pharmaceutical company.

In a study of more than 1,200 COVID-19 patients with a higher risk of developing serious illness, people who took Pfizer's pills were far less likely to end up in the hospital compared to people who got placebo pills."
