description:
In this week's True Crime Daily Podcast: A Texas woman is shot while driving on a highway after finding a tracking device on her car. Police say the woman, who was an exotic dancer, was allegedly stalked by a customer who made their text messages public. She's dead, and he's now sitting in a jail cell (3:18).
And an Alabama woman gets life in prison after testifying against her husband (37:33). She's admitted to helping him kill a family of five in 2015. The victims include the man's new wife, their unborn child, the woman's other child, her nephew and her mother. The husband was married to both women at the same time.
Criminal defense attorney Mike Cavalluzzi joins host Ana Garcia.

description:
In this wide-ranging two-part interview with renowned attorney Mark Geragos, Joshua Ritter discusses the landmark cases of Geragos’s prolific career.
From Michael Jackson to Scott Peterson, Winona Ryder to Colin Kaepernick and Jussie Smollett, Geragos reveals how he got started in law, and the cases that propelled his success, including how the Susan McDougal trial “supercharged” his career in the 1990s.
Geragos talks about a possible new trial for convicted murderer Scott Peterson; the return to the courtroom for actor Jussie Smollett; jury selection; law enforcement; defending notorious clients; civil rights and the pursuit of justice; and much more.

John DeLorean 20:20

description:
QAnon, your not-so-friendly, neighborhood conspiracy cult, has gotten so out of hand that even “Q” - the All Mighty leader - is disavowing some of the most fringe conspiracy theories being peddled by its loyal followers. Including the theory that John F. Kenney Jr. is actually alive and will reveal himself as Donald Trump’s 2024 running mate. At the end of the day, these people - no matter how far on the fringe they fall - are fellow Americans who have been manipulated by the system. They are motivated and they are voting. There will almost certainly be more QAnon supporters on the ballot in 2022. So if you think it’s scary now, you have no idea.» Subscribe to MSNBC: http://on.msnbc.com/SubscribeTomsnbc

description:
Right-wing “vigilante justice” is under fire in two high-profile murder trials. The opening arguments were heard in the trial of the white men who killed Ahmaud Arbery, a trial where they are facing a nearly all-white jury. The judge condemned the discrimination found by the court, but noted he could not prevent it under current Supreme Court precedent. Meanwhile, teenager Kyle Rittenhouse is on trial for murdering two BLM protesters in Wisconsin, and many have been quick to sympathize with him.

In this special report, MSNBC’s Ari Melber breaks down the mounting right-wing political extremism and violence throughout the country. Melber analyzes the many factors at play contributing to this rise, including actual Republican-passed laws like the “vigilante” system stemming from Texas’ abortion ban and the horrific killings of unarmed, innocent people. Melber points to the trial for the killing of Ahmaud Arbery and the high-profile trial of Kyle Rittenhouse, who shot two protesters to death during a BLM rally.

description:
Two Chinese astronauts have completed a several-hour-long space walk outside the Tiangong space station. The mission was notable for featuring China’s first woman astronaut to perform the out-of-this-world procedure.

Wang Yeping was joined by fellow astronaut Zhai Zhigang, another of the three-person team currently aboard China’s latest space station. The two successfully completed the 6.5-hour spacewalk in the early hours of Monday morning, according to the China Manned Space Agency.

The pair disembarked from the main module of the Tiangong station on a spacewalk that lasted over six hours. They carried out tests alongside the station’s robotic arm and installed equipment for part of the station’s ongoing construction.

A third astronaut, Ye Guangfu, assisted the duo from inside the station. State broadcaster CCTV shared footage of the astronauts carrying out their tasks and floating in space.

description:
Last week, the Federal Reserve voted to keep interest rates near zero as inflation rises to the highest point in 30 years. description:

description:
(3 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351443

Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy and Republican Jack Ciattarelli were locked in what amounts to a tie in the New Jersey governor's race. 
The Associated Press had not declared a winner in the contest on Wednesday, which was too early to call. 
In Bergen County and across the state, election workers were busy counting mail-in and drop box ballots and adding them to the statewide vote tally. 
But Murphy had a lead of less than a percentage point in incomplete results as county elections officials continued to count ballots. 
The closeness of the race surprised experts, who watched public polls showing Murphy leading comfortably and looked to his party's registration advantage of more than a million voters. 
Murphy had no public schedule on Wednesday, and Ciattarelli has also not announced plans to appear publicly.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Pakistan's poor suffer amid spiraling inflation and growing fuel prices.
An independent economist says the government should interfere and give the poor a targeted subsidy on fuel.

STORY-LINE :
40-year-old Hameeda Khatoon, a widow living in Karachi, has four young children. 
The rising costs of necessities in Pakistan has made it increasingly hard for her to feed her family. 
"How can we survive in such circumstances? These conditions make us want to kill ourselves. It's better to die than live in such a manner," says Khatoon. 
The inflation rate in Pakistan has been close to 10% since 2019, according to World Bank. 
The government says the increase in prices in the country is the result of inflation across the world, but independent economists say that it is only one of the reasons behind the rising prices.
Pakistani economist Aqdas Afzal said there are local and international factors behind the steep increase in prices.
He said the government should interfere.
"The government needs to focus on the poor people. It needs to give them a targeted subsidy on fuel. It needs to raise the amount of money it's giving to the poor people in this country," Afzal said.
Much of the inflation in the country is driven by rising fuel prices. 
The price of petrol has risen to Rs137.79 ($0.79) a liter from Rs108.56 ($0.62) on June 1, an increase of 27%.

(4 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351597

Striking miners from Alabama protested outside BlackRock headquarters in New York on Thursday, demanding higher wages and better working conditions. 
More than 100 workers employed at Warrior Met Coal took part in the protest which began with a march from Central Park to BlackRock headquarters. BlackRock is an investor in Warrior Met Coal.
Several arrests were made after the protesters refused to stop blocking the street.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) Wole Soyinka, Nigeria's Nobel-winning author, sees his country's many problems — misgoverning politicians, systemic corruption, violent extremists, and kidnapping bandits — yet he does not despair.
At 87, he believes Nigeria's youth may have the energy and the know-how to get the troubled country back on track.
Soyinka credits young Nigerians between 15 and 35 — about a third of the population — for trying to fundamentally reform the country. 
He cites the #EndSARS protests a year ago against police brutality.
"The kind of energy and intelligence which created the #EndSARS movement is one, for instance, that can be used on a much broader scale to involve masses of people," he comments.
Soyinka won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986, the first Black African to do so. 
Now he's published a new novel, his first in almost 50 years. 
In "Chronicles from the Land of the Happiest People on Earth" he has created a fictional Nigeria rife with crime, corruption and chaos,  governed by the oppressive People on the Move Party (POMP). 
The people it portrays are anything but happy, despite the annual, ironically-named, 'Festival of the People of Happiness'.
It's a parody of the real-life Nigeria of today under the leadership of President Muhammadu Buhari.
In 2015, Soyinka endorsed Buhari for president, and asked Nigerians to forgive his past as a former dictator in the 1980s.
Now Soyinka is critical of Buhari.
"Right from the middle of the first round of his government, it has failed on many levels and it is up to Nigerians to wake up and reverse the direction in which they are being taken," he says.
The author believes Buhari and his administration have been unable to tackle the extremist violence that's led to thousands of deaths and the mass kidnappings of schoolchildren.
"They refused to take action at the right time," he says. "They compromised. They appeased. They excused. They even rhetoricized the danger, the reality. And in the process we lost our humanity completely." 
Soyinka admits he is not as strong as he once was, but he's tired of reading his own obituary.
In Nigeria, fake news reports about Soyinka's death are rampant.
"I am getting bored with dying," he says. "I am just bored each time I read my obituary. It's been going on for years."

description:
(31 Oct 2021) The usually crowded center of Rome was deserted Sunday morning, with only security personnel, police and some disappointed tourists walking the streets.
The city center was cut off to car and pedestrian traffic to allow the leaders of the G20 countries to visit the Trevi Fountain.  
Disappointed tourists were told it was temporarily closed and were advised to move on.
A legend in Rome is that if one throws a coin in the Trevi Fountain, they will be sure to return. 
Thousands of coins are thrown in the fountain every day and the city regularly cleans them out and uses them for charitable causes. 
COVID-19 economic recovery and climate change have been the two main issues tackled by the leaders of the world's 20 biggest economies, who gathered in Rome this weekend and are heading to Glasgow, Scotland, for the U.N. climate conference - COP26.
The G20 countries represent 80% of the global economy.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Lebanon's airshow brings locals and soldiers together amid the country's unprecedented economic crisis.
Visitors got a closer look at air force equipment and mingled with pilots at the Rayak Airbase of the country's east.

STORY-LINE:  
Hundreds of Lebanese on Sunday attended an airshow by the Lebanese Army's air force in the eastern Bekaa Valley.
Light attack Tucano aircrafts, helicopters, a drone and weapons were on display at the event. 
The newly bought, U.S.-made MD530F helicopter was put into action for the first time.
Visitors walked in the airfield to have a closer look at air force equipment, take pictures and talk with the pilots.
They also watched a show of aerobatic maneuvers by the Tucano aircrafts.
"This is an entertaining and an educational day -- a patriotic day par excellence," said Col. Hassan Barakat, a pilot in the Lebanese Army.
"Amid the current situations, that all of us are going through, and that we (army) too are affected by, we are giving our people a glimmer of hope for a better future. Hope comes when they see us standing steadfast," he said.
Lebanon is going through the worst economic and financial crisis of its modern history.
The Lebanese have always considered their military as an anchor for stability, one of the only institutions standing above the country's divisions.
But the military is now threatened by Lebanon's devastating financial collapse.
The economic meltdown is putting unprecedented pressure on the U.S.-backed army's operational abilities, wiping out soldiers' salaries and wrecking morale.
"We came here to assure that we stand beside the Lebanese Army in war and in peace. There is no security without the Lebanese Army," one visitor said.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) A notorious gang leader in Haiti is calling for the United Nations and the United States to break ties with the country's government in order to help "liberate Haiti".
Jimmy "Barbecue" Chérizier, the leader of the G9 Family and Allies, a federation of nine violent gangs that control much of Port-au-Prince, issued the appeal duering a news conference on Wednesday in La Saline, one of the capital's poorest areas.
"We take this opportunity to invite the United Nations in general and the so-called friendly countries of Haiti, in particular the United States of America, to register in this page of history as loyal allies who want the well-being of the Haitian people by divorcing the status quo", Chérizier said.
The G9 controls entire sections of the capital and their violent acts have many residents living in fear. 
They have been implicated in dozens of killings, including infants. 
The gang is responsible for burning neighbourhoods to the ground forcing thousands to flee, and for demanding extortion payments from businesses. 
Those who do not comply see their businesses looted or the owners killed.
Chérizier has repeatedly called for the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry, blaming him for much of the unrest the country is experiencing.
The gang leader accused him of taking part in the assassination last July of President Jovenel Moise after mobile phone calls between Henry and Joseph Felix Badio, one of the prime suspects in the killing, became public.
The calls were made the night of the assassination. 
Henry denies remembering those calls and has said he spoke to many people that night, but does not remember speaking to Badio, whose whereabouts remain unknown.
While Chérizier fancies himself a liberator and a Robin Hood of sorts, the everyday reality for Haitians is much different. 
The G9 have sealed off access to country's main port in the capital leading to major fuel shortages that have affected all residents and caused outbursts of violence near gas stations and a general strike by workers unions.
Insecurity along with a lack of goods and general services under a government that seems overwhelmed and unable to bring stability to the Western Hemisphere's poorest nation, is what Haiti's population is experiencing on a daily basis.
Chérizier and his G9 show no signs of backing down.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/APArchives ​​
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/APNews/


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/940cf2533c60457381a47afcc1412169

title: Haiti gang leader urges UN to break with government

description:
(2 Nov 2021) المقدمة:
مع تصاعد الخلاف الدبلوماسي مع السعودية وحلفائها، يسارع المواطنون اللبنانيون المقيمون في دول الخليج لمغاردة بيروت. 
القصة:
العشرات من المواطنين اللبنانيين الذين يزورون لبنان يبادرون  بالعودة ادراجهم إلى دول الخليج حيث يعيشون، في خضم نزاع دبلوماسي بين بلدهم الأم والسعودية.
المملكة أمرت سفير لبنان لدى الرياض بالمغادرة، وحظرت جميع الواردات القادمة من لبنان، في ضربة قوية للبلد الذي يعاني بالفعل من أسوأ أزمة اقتصادية يشهدها منذ عقود.
الكويت والبحرين والإمارات حذت جميعا حذو المملكة وأعلنت اتخاذ إجراءات ضد لبنان، ما زاد الضغط على البلد الذي يئن بالفعل تحت وطاة أزمته وفي أمس الحاجة للمساعدة الخارجية.
كثير من أبناء لبنان سارعوا للعودة للخليج مخافة تعليق الرحلات الجوية أو فرض مزيد من الإجراءات العقابية. 
التوتر اندلع بعد تصريح تلفزيوني أدلى به جورج قرداحي- أحد أشهر مقدمي البرامج التلفزيونية اللبنانيين والذي أصبح وزيرا للإعلام في الحكومة الحالية- حول الحرب في اليمن.
قرداحي كان ضيفا على أحد البرامج التلفزيونية في حلقة تم تصويرها في أغسطس/آب الماضي، لكنه بثت الأسبوع الماضي، وصف فيهالحرب في اليمن بأنها عدوان من السعودية والإمارات. 
قرداحي الذي يعارض نشوب حروب بين الدول العربية ، شدد على أن الحرب في اليمن "عبثية" ويجب أن تتوقف. 
دفع الغضب من تصريحات قرداحي دول الخليج العربية لاتخاذ خطوات تهدد بانقسام حكومة لبنان  الائتلافية الجديدة والمكلفة بوقف الانهيار الاقتصادي للبلاد.
الإجراءات العقابية التي أعلنتها السعودية-التي كانت يوما حليفا مهما ضخ ملايين الدولارات في لبنان- قد تتسبب في زيادة المعاناة الاقتصادية.
ذاك هو أحدث تصعيد في العداء الدائر منذ أمد بين السعودية وإيران على الساحة اللبنانية.
استمرت التوترات لسنوات حول الدور المهيمن لجماعة حزب الله المدعومة من إيران في لبنان. 
والآن يصر المسؤولون السعوديون على أنه من غير المجدي التعامل مع الحكومة في بيروت بعد كل هذا  الانجراف تجاه إيران.
قرداحي مقرب من حركة "تيار المردة" المسيحي، وحليف لجماعة حزب الله.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) THE GO-GO'S: 'WE STILL DON'T KNOW' WHAT WE'RE DOING
After being inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Saturday (30 OCT. 2021), Belinda Carlisle of The Go-Go's said "it's surreal" to be honored because "we had no idea what we were doing when we started in 1978 so and here we are." Added Gina Schock, 'We still don't know. We fake it really well."
The Go-Go's share an induction class with Foo Fighters, Jay-Z and Carole King, who said backstage that she is no longer writing songs because she doesn't feel she has as much to say. She is now focused on efforts "to keep climate change from going forward as badly as it is."
LL Cool J, Billy Preston and Randy Rhoads were honored with musical excellence awards.
Clarence Avant, a former manager, label owner and concert organizer, received the Ahmet Ertegun Award as a non-performer. His impact on the music industry was highlighted in the 2019 Netflix documentary, "The Black Godfather."
Said music producer and writer Jimmy Jam of Avant: "There would be no Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis that anybody would know anyway without Clarence Avan. For us it's amazing to be here tonight to support him and to watch him be inducted. It's an amazing event and it's so deserved."

description:
(2 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Lebanese citizens living in the Gulf are rushing to leave Beirut as a diplomatic spat with Saudi Arabia and its allies escalates.

STORY-LINE:
Scores of Lebanese citizens visiting Lebanon were returning to the Gulf nations where they live amid a diplomatic spat between the small Mediterranean country and Saudi Arabia.
The Kingdom ordered Lebanon's ambassador to Riyadh to leave and banned all imports from Lebanon in a major blow to the country that is already passing through its worst economic crisis in decades.
Kuwait, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates followed suit with measures against Lebanon, increasing pressure on the crisis-hit country badly in need of foreign assistance.
Many Lebanese have rushed to go back to the Gulf fearing that flights might be stopped or further punitive measures are taken.
The tension started after a televised remark by a game show host turned cabinet minister in Lebanon about the war in Yemen.
During a TV program filmed in August and aired last week, George Kordahi described the war in Yemen as an aggression by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
He added that the war in Yemen was "absurd" and must stop because he is opposed to wars between Arabs.
Anger over Kordahi's comments led to steps by Gulf Arab countries that threaten to split its new coalition government, tasked with halting the country's economic meltdown.
Punitive measures from Saudi Arabia, once an important ally that poured millions of dollars into Lebanon, could cause more economic pain.
It is the latest escalation in the rivalry that has long played out in Lebanon between Saudi Arabia and Iran.
Tensions have dragged on for years over the dominant role in Lebanon of the Iranian-backed militant Hezbollah group.
Now Saudi officials insist it is pointless to deal with the government in Beirut after so much drift toward Iran.
Kordahi is close to the Christian Marada movement, an ally of the militant Hezbollah group.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) PRINCE WILLIAM AND KATE COOK AND POT PLANTS WITH SCOUTS IN GLASGOW
Prince William and Kate spent some time with scouts in Glasgow on Monday (1 NOVEMBER 2021) while in Scotland for the 2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference, also known as COP26.
The royals joined the scouts in activities such as cooking veggie burgers and potting plants to demonstrate how scouting is helping young people combat climate change by learning simple skills.
Queen Elizabeth did not attend the conference in person after being hospitalized overnight last month. But the 95-year-old monarch did deliver a recorded message, saying "the time for words has now moved to the time for action."

description:
(3 Nov 2021) Boston voters have for the first time elected a woman and an Asian American as mayor, tapping City Councilor Michelle Wu to serve in the city's top office. 
New England's largest city had previously only elected white men as mayor since its founding in 1630 by English puritans. 
Wu defeated fellow Boston City Councilor Annissa Essaibi George. 
The two Democrats faced off against each other after defeating other mayoral hopefuls in a September preliminary election. 
The election of Wu, whose parents immigrated from Taiwan, marks another break from tradition in Boston. 
Wu grew up in Chicago, moving to Boston to attend Harvard University and Harvard Law School. 
Boston typically elects mayors with lifelong Boston roots. 
Wu takes office on Nov. 16.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Libyan jockeys race during the Marcos Arch Horse Racing in Tripoli.

STORY-LINE:
Libyan horsemen from across the country competed on Friday during one of the rounds of the Marcos Arch Horse Racing in Tripoli.
The tournament, organized by the Libyan General Federation for Equestrian Sports, started on Sept. 25, and will run until mid-December.
Jockeys race to win prizes totaling one million Libyan dinars (about $217,000).
There are nine rounds in the event: three rounds for purebred Arabian horses, three for local thoroughbred horses and three for imported thoroughbred horses.
In each round, jockeys compete to collect the largest number of points to qualify for the final rounds in December.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Robot food delivery is no longer the stuff of science fiction. 
Hundreds of little robots are now navigating college campuses and city sidewalks in the U.S., the U.K. and elsewhere.

STORY-LINE:
Robot food delivery is no longer the stuff of science fiction.
Hundreds of little robots - knee-high and able to hold around four large pizzas - are now navigating college campuses and city sidewalks in the U.S., the U.K. and elsewhere.
While robots were being tested in limited numbers before the coronavirus hit, companies say pandemic-related labor shortages and a growing preference for contactless delivery have vastly accelerated their deployment.
Starship Technologies has recently completed its 2 millionth delivery.
The company has more than 1,000 robots in its fleet, up from just 250 in 2019. 
Hundreds more will be deployed soon. 
They're delivering food on 20 US campuses, 25 more will be added soon. 
They're also operating on sidewalks in Milton Keynes, England; Modesto, California; and the company's hometown of Tallin, Estonia.
Robot designs vary - some have four wheels and some have six.
But generally, they use cameras, sensors, GPS and sometimes laser scanners to navigate sidewalks and even cross streets autonomously. 
They move around 5 miles per hour.
Remote operators keep tabs on multiple robots at a time, but they say they rarely need to hit the brakes or steer around an obstacle. 
When a robot arrives at its destination, customers type a code into their phones to open the lid and retrieve their food.
The robots have drawbacks that limit their usefulness for now. 
They're electric, so they must recharge regularly. 
They're slow, and they generally stay within a small, pre-mapped radius. 
They're also inflexible. 
A customer can't tell a robot to leave the food outside the door, for example. 
And some big cities with crowded sidewalks, like New York, Beijing and San Francisco, aren't welcoming them.  
Patrick Sheck, a junior at Bowling Green State University in Bowling Green, Ohio, gets deliveries from a Starship robot three or four times a week as he's leaving class. 
"Students love them. They're part of the BG family now. They're recognized all over campus, and they just blend in well with the student population," Sheck says.
"The robot pulls up just in time for me to get some lunch," he adds
Bowling Green and Starship charge $1.99 plus a service fee for each robot delivery.
"It's gone from being really just a nice thing to have to really more of an essential service. And our students are loving it," says Frank Comery from Starship technologies.
Delivery companies are also jumping into the market. 
Grubhub recently partnered with Russian robot maker Yandex to deploy 50 robots on the campus of Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio. 
Grubhub plans to add more campuses soon, although the company stresses that the service won't go beyond colleges for now.
Yandex used technology developed for its self-driving cars to build and deploy more than 100 robots globally over the last year. 
It's also testing the robots in Moscow and Israel.
"I think, right now, we're at that point where, for something like these delivery rovers, the technology, we believe, is really ready to roll out in a big way," said Toby Snuggs, Yandex's head of sales, noting the uptick in demand for meal delivery during the pandemic.
U.S. delivery orders jumped 66% in the year ending in June. 
That's according to NPD, a data and consulting firm. 
And delivery demand could remain elevated even after the pandemic eases, because customers have gotten used to the convenience.

title: Robot food deliveries surge in popularity in US

description:
(3 Nov 2021) Anxious families waited for news on Wednesday about loved ones trapped under the rubble of a 21-storey building that collapsed in Lagos as the search and rescue continued for a third day.
The death toll from the collapse of the block under construction in Nigeria’s most populous city rose to 23 with two more bodies recovered Wednesday afternoon, authorities said.
Hazeez Olalere remained hopeful for his relative, Babatunde Olalere, who worked as a mason at the construction site. 
Babatunde did not return home to his wife and baby on Monday and after repeated calls to his number with no response the family is devastated.
"I personally called his number yesterday, and the first response I got was 'switched-off', on the second attempt the call went through and rang repeatedly with no response, so later we learnt about the incident at his place of work," Hazeez said.
The president of the Architects Regulation Council of Nigeria, Dipo Ajayi, told The Associated Press that sub-standard building work was likely responsible for the collapse.
It is still unclear the number of people at the construction site when the building came down.
Nine people had been rescued by Tuesday, but no new survivors were found Wednesday.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) Thailand on Monday substantially reopened to foreign tourists, some 18 months after effectively closing its borders against the coronavirus, raising hopes of economic revival in a country more dependent than most on the spending power of overseas visitors.  
A steady stream of inbound passengers bustled though Bangkok international airport's previously almost deserted public areas.
Fully vaccinated tourists from 63 countries and territories can now fly in, with minimal conditions. 
They take a COVID test on arrival then spend one night in a designated hotel, awaiting the result. 
If their test is negative they are free to leave and enjoy their stay unhindered.
So far so good for Bruce Stiles, from the UK, who had just got off a flight from London.
"Yeah it was OK. It was pretty smooth. We knew it would take a while" to pass through the airport on arrival, he said.
Those from countries outside the list of 63 can still enter but have to go through lengthy quarantine periods, upon arrival, as well as frequent tests.
According to the general manager of Bangkok's international airport, around 2,300 people are expected there from international flights on Monday. 
"I think it is a good sign for starting after we have had COVID and after today I think Thais will have a future," said Kittipong Kittikachorn, the general manager of Suvarnabhumi Airport, who admitted to nervousness as he watched the passengers filter through.
With crowds of tourists absent from the streets, it's been a desperate time for Thailand's vast hospitality sector. 
It accounted for an estimated 12-20% of GDP before the coronavirus pandemic.
Not now. 
With tight entry restrictions in place, visitor numbers plummeted from almost 40 million in 2019, to just 6.7 million in 2020. 
The result: shuttered bars, restaurants and hotels, and worker lay-offs. Even places that have survived, like this restaurant near Bangkok's Grand Palace, have taken on huge debt.
Thai Restaurant Association president Taniwan Koonmongkon spells out how hard the industry's been hit.
"For the period that restaurants didn't have income, if it had only been one or two months, they could probably have survived. But restaurants were closed, then opened, then ordered closed again, like this, for almost two years now. We've endured such severe hardship," she said.
The re-opening then is raising spirits, right across the ailing sector.
This city centre hotel has survived by providing quarantine facilities. Now it's preparing for new guests under the re-opening initiative and looking towards a more stable future.
"I expect customers will return as normal after 1 November," says Wassana Chitapiwantha, the deputy manager. "They will book with us like they used to. Staff who were laid off during the shutdown will come back to work when we open hundred percent with a full service."
Bangkok tuk-tuk driver Boonyeam Markthong has seen his daily income drop from as much as 3,000 baht (approximately 90 US dollars) to almost zero, some days. Now he hopes the nightmare is ending.
But there remains substantial concern that the growing influx of visitors will cause a spike in COVID-19 cases, just as the country is getting its latest outbreak under control. 
For many Thais, public health still outweighs concern over the economy.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351240

The Archbishop of New York kicked off the holiday season Tuesday by blessing the animals that will be featured in the Radio City Music Hall's live Nativity scene.
Joined by the famous Rockettes, Cardinal Timothy Dolan sprinkled Holy Water on a camel, donkey and sheep after they paraded around the famous building.
"I'm here 13 years now, and I've done it. I think every year because I love it, I enjoy it and darn it, I don't mind saying, we need a little Christmas, right this very moment with everything that we've been through," Cardinal Dolan said.
Covid-19 forced the cancellation of the the holiday show and the blessing of the animals last year. 
"The animals help remind us of the true meaning of Christmas with the living Nativity scene so the animals... are just a reminder of that and we're just so excited again to be back," Alexis Payton, who is her in first season as a Rockette, said.
Tiffany Billings, who is in her tenth season on the famous kick line, was happy that Cardinal Dolan was continuing the tradition.
"Last year we weren't here, so this is so, so special," Billings said. "We love our furry cast mates so much and we're so excited that they're here."
The Christmas Spectacular Starring the Radio City Rockettes will run from November 5, 2021-January 2, 2022.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) Peruvians had hoped this year they'd be able to resume their Day of the Dead traditions of visiting the gravesites of their loved ones. 
But health and local authorities decided to close most cemeteries in Peru to prevent a third wave of COVID-19, which has already claimed the lives of more than 200-thousand people.
The Nueva Esperanza cemetery on the outskirts of Lima, known as Virgen de Lourdes, is among the largest in the world, with over one million tombs, and it's located in one of Lima's most impoverished neighborhoods. 
Some residents attempted to climb hillsides and use other unauthorized passages used to gain entrance but were stopped by armed security forces. 
Visiting loved one's tombs on the Day of the Dead is a tradition for many in Peru and other Latin American countries. 
People tend to eat and drink and pay tribute to the deceased on the Day of the Dead every November.

(2 Nov 2021) KRISTEN STEWART IS ENGAGED TO DYLAN MEYER: 'WE'RE MARRYING'
Kristen Stewart is engaged to screenwriter Dylan Meyer. The 31-year-old actor announced the news The Howard Stern Show Tuesday.
“We’re marrying, it’s happening,” Stewart said.
She also revealed that Meyer did the proposing.
“I wanted to be proposed to, so I think I very distinctly carved out what I wanted and she nailed it,” Stewart said.
The two started dating in 2019 after they met at a mutual friends’ party and bonded over having grown up in Los Angeles. Meyer a week ago on Instagram posted a photo of them laying on the floor in each other’s arms with the caption “Awful proud of this hard-working princess.”
Stewart is currently promoting the Princess Diana film “Spencer,” which comes out in theaters on Friday.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) A beauty pageant competition in Venezuela on Saturday offered the young men who were competing a chance to temporarily escape the harsh realities experienced by many in the country. 
Nineteen men took part in the Mr. Handsome Venezuela International pageant in Caracas, showing off their dancing and other skills.  
The pageant this year was attended by some media and special guests after last year's edition was cancelled due to COVID-19.
Rafael Sanchez, the representative of the state of Lara, was announced as the winner.
Another participant, Renzo Guaramato, spoke of his love for modelling. 
"It's not easy to do what you like, it's part of the sacrifice, but when you can, when you want to, you do your best," Guaramato said. 
He recalled the time he had to travel on a garbage truck since he lacked the money to pay for public transportation and had even gone hungry at times. 
"But that didn't stop me from being here. You know that the effort and dedication and love for modeling is more than the challenges I had in the journey," he said. 
Alirio Martinez, the President of Mr. Handsome Venezuela, said the participation and training the young men receive has catapulted some into the world of entertainment. 
"This is like a trampoline. Mr. Handsome is like a trampoline for the young men of Mr. Handsome Venezuela, the participants. It is a school, it is a university where they learn to develop in the artistic environment," Martinez said.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351286

Yahoo Inc. said Tuesday it has pulled out of China, citing an increasingly challenging operating environment.
The withdrawal was largely symbolic, as many of the company's services were already blocked by China's digital censorship. But recent government moves to expand its control over tech companies generally, including its domestic giants, may have tipped the scales for Yahoo.
"In recognition of the increasingly challenging business and legal environment in China, Yahoo's suite of services will no longer be accessible from mainland China as of November 1," the company said in a statement. It said it "remains committed to the rights of our users and a free and open internet."
The company's move comes as the American and Chinese governments feud over technology and trade. The U.S. has put restrictions on telecom giant Huawei and other Chinese tech companies, alleging that they have ties with China's government, military or both. China says the U.S. is unfairly suppressing competition and trying to block China's technological rise.
Yahoo is the latest foreign tech company to exit China. Google gave up several years ago, and Microsoft's professional networking platform LinkedIn said last month it would shutter its Chinese site, replacing it with a jobs board instead. The departures illustrate the choices internet companies face in a huge potential market, but one where the government requires them to censor content and keywords deemed politically sensitive or inappropriate.
In their place, Chinese companies have filled the void, creating an alternative internet with its own digital giants. The Baidu search engine has largely replaced Yahoo and Google in China, and WeChat and Weibo are the leading social media platforms.
Yahoo's departure coincided with the implementation of China's Personal Information Protection Law, which limits what information companies can gather and sets standards for how it must be stored.
Chinese laws also stipulate that companies operating in the country must hand over data if requested by authorities, making it difficult for Western firms to operate in China as they may also face pressure back home over giving in to China's demands.
Yahoo was harshly criticized by lawmakers in the U.S. in 2007 after it handed over data on two Chinese dissidents to Beijing, eventually leading to their imprisonment.
Yahoo had previously downsized its operations in China, dropping a music and email service in the early 2010s and shuttering its Beijing office in 2015. Anyone who tried to access Engadget China, a tech news site that it had continued to operate, was greeted Tuesday with a popup saying the site would no longer publish content.
China has also blocked most international social media sites and search engines, such as Facebook and Google. Some users in China circumvent the block by using a virtual private network (VPN) that masks who you are and where you are logging in from.
Verizon Communications Inc. acquired Yahoo in 2017 and merged it with AOL, but later sold the entity off to private equity firm Apollo Global Management in a $5 billion deal. Apollo announced in September that its acquisition of Yahoo was complete.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) People in India have had a mixed reaction to the country's goal of having net zero emissions by 2070. 
India's prime minister said Monday his country would aim to stop adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere by 2070 - two decades after the United States and at least 10 year later than China pledged to do so.
"The prime minister or any political party says many things, but it depends on the people," said 23-year-old Damiya Farhana, a post graduate student from Assam State. 
She said individuals will have to take more initiative in achieving the goal.
Abdul Hai, a 43-year-old unemployed graphic designer, said the only way to save the environment was to stop  dependence and usage of "modern things and technologies."
Jitender Saxena, 47, who works in a shop and is an ardent supporter of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, said he won't be surprised if India achieves the goal much earlier than 2070. 
"Today, anywhere that Modi goes, the whole world is looking up to him," he said.  
Modi announced the target Monday at the U.N. climate summit in Glasgow, Scotland.
He said the goal of reaching "net zero" by 2070 was one of five measures India planned to undertake to meet its commitments under the Paris climate accord.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) DWAYNE JOHNSON SAYS HIS PRODUCTION COMPANY WILL STOP USING REAL GUNS ON FILMS
Dwayne Johnson says his production company Seven Bucks will no longer use real guns on any set, following death of "Rust" cinematographer Halyna Hutchins.
"Moving forward on any Seven Bucks production, in television or film or otherwise, we will not use real guns ever again. We are going to be using rubber guns and we'll take care of it in post," Johnson said, at the Los Angeles premiere for "Red Notice," Wednesday (3 NOVEMBER 2021).
"And we won't worry about the dollars, we won't worry about math and what the cost is. I think we're going to do it the right way," the actor and producer added.
Hutchins was fatally shot by Alec Baldwin on the "Rust" set in New Mexico last month. Investigators believe Baldwin's gun fired a single live round that killed the cinematographer and wounded director Joel Souza.
Johnson said the tragedy will be a catalyst for change. 
"It's created a new lens and new perspective on how we can operate moving forward. We have to use, as awful as this situation was and is, we have to use this as an example and I think in a way to be smarter as we move forward, be safer," he said. 
In action comedy "Red Notice," Johnson plays an FBI profiler who is after the two biggest art thieves in the world, played by Ryan Reynolds and Gal Gadot. 
Reynolds said the long off-screen friendship between the stars prevented any ego clashes on set. 
"I've known Dwayne for 21 years now. So, you know, he and I first met, he was doing 'Scorpion King', I was doing 'Van Wilder'. It was a really long time ago, So we all kind of know each other is a built-in chemistry, but it was just love. I mean, truly a love fest. I know that like you probably hear that a lot from actors in my position, but it really was amazing. The set was just a lovely place to work and play."
Reynolds also discussed his recent announcement on social media that he will temporarily step away from acting, to focus on his family. 
"I don't know exactly when I'll be back, but I've got to take a little bit of time just like my kids are growing up," he said. 
"We usually all travel together when we shoot films and they're in school, so they can't do that now, so I just needed to be home and, you know, I'm really fortunate that I am able to do that. Not everyone can do that. So, you know, it's just nice to be close for a little while."
Written and directed by Rawson Marshall Thurber, "Red Notice" is out on Netflix on November 12.

(4 Nov 2021) LEAD IN: 
Kurdish models have taken to the catwalk during a fashion show in Iraq's northern city of Sulaymaniyah.
They showcased designs ranging from traditional Kurdish outfits to Islamic dresses and modern clothing. 

STORY-LINE: 
Hitting the catwalk in Iraq's Kurdish region, models on Tuesday showed off traditional Kurdish outfits, Islamic and modern clothing.
Twenty-six designers, mainly Kurds from Iraq and Iran, have participated in the fashion show in Sulaymaniyah.
Around 30 models, men and women, showed the designs during the Flora Fashion Show.
Stage manager and model trainer Moyad Karash said the event meant to encourage local designers to produce more outfits.
Sulaymaniyah is known as an art and cultural hub the Kurdish region of Iraq.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Scientists are studying a unique frozen archive of Greenland's ice sheet.
They're searching for clues to Earth's past and our planet's warmer future, as a result of temperature-rising climate change.
In recent decades, the archive's worth to scientists has increased, as climate change and rising temperatures eat away at Greenland's glaciers, contributing to global sea level rise.

STORY-LINE:
The University of Copenhagen's Niels Bohr Institute is home to a library of Greenlandic ice cores. 
Scientists from Denmark, which rules Greenland, have been regularly visiting the giant frozen island since the 1970s, bringing back deep-drilled, tube-shaped ice cores to study in sophisticated laboratories back home. 
If stacked end-to-end, the large, frosty collection would now stretch more than 20 kilometres. It is kept constantly chilled in large freezers at minus 30 degrees Celsius.
"All the metrological measurements and atmospheric measurements humans and have done in the last hundred years or so are already influenced by climate change that is human caused," explains Bo Vinther, an associate professor at the Niels Bohr Institute. 
"So, if we want to see the natural state of climate and natural variability, then we need to go way, way further back in time, and our archives provide this window into the past."
An international team of scientists is now studying not the frozen ice chunks, but frosty deposits of muddy sediment and pebbles that once lay 1.4 kilometres beneath the ice sheet's surface.
The samples sat largely forgotten in cold storage for decades after being drilled by U.S. scientists in the 1960s, as part of work to establish a military base within the Greenland Ice Sheet at the height of the Cold War. They were "rediscovered" three years ago.
While the brown-coloured basal sediment samples - each about the size of a football - might not be much to look at, the team's Andrew Christ, a glacial geomorphologist from the University of Vermont, describes the ancient rubble as a "time capsule".
"By cracking open these sediments for the very first time, we're able to learn more about what it used to be like in the past," he says.
The team plans to use a method known as luminescence dating to learn how long ago the sediment's mineral grains were last exposed to direct sunlight. 
Combined with other measurements, it could reveal temperatures when the Greenland Ice Sheet last melted away. Initial results reported last year suggested the ice sheet had been absent within the last million years.
"With this research, we are hoping to learn more about past times when this part of Greenland melted away and then understand what climate was like at those times," explains Christ. 
"How much warmer was it at that point? What was different about Earth's climate system at those times versus today? And what does that tell us about how sensitive Greenland is to melting in the future?"
Working in almost complete darkness and lit by the glow of a red-coloured bicycle light, Christ and his colleague Pierre-Henri Blard from CNRS, the French National Centre for Scientific Research, carefully saw into the frozen soil samples, dividing them into smaller chunks for transport back to U.S. labs - even the slightest exposure to sunlight could throw their readings millennia off.
The team's work is timely. Delegates are meeting in Glasgow, Scotland for the delayed U.N. COP26 climate summit. It's been billed as a "last hope" to keep the emission-cutting commitments made in the 2015 Paris climate accord. 
"So, for that, we have to look into the past."

title: Greenland ice archive gives frosty clues to Earth’s warmer future

description:
(4 Nov 2021) Voters in the US state of New Jersey reacted on Wednesday to the news that Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy narrowly won reelection in his reliably blue state. 
Murphy eked out a victory against GOP challenger Jack Ciattarelli, who mounted a surprisingly strong campaign on issues including taxes and opposition to pandemic mask and vaccination mandates. 
Murphy, in a brief victory speech Wednesday night, alluded to his narrow margin of victory by saying he would “listen to all of New Jersey,” but still emphasized Democratic goals like expanding voting rights, raising taxes on the wealthy and defending abortion rights.
New Jersey voter Matthew Kessler, a 27-year-old Democrat and Murphy supporter, said the close race didn't surprise him.
"The pandemic has really been a polarizing issue, so it's not too surprising to me that it was as close of a race," he said.
Terry Ferguson, also a Murphy supporter, mentioned the polaizing and divisive state of politics around the US, but expressed surprise that it came into play in his home state.
"I think that it's sort of a reflection of the polarization and politicization within the the country as a whole. But I had not imagined that it would be so close here or so evident in New Jersey," he said.
Ferguson also expressed confidence in the US electoral system.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Hundreds participated in the funeral of Sabah Fakhri, one of the Arab world's most famous singers, in Damascus on Thursday.

STORY-LINE:
Syria on Thursday held a major public funeral for the legendary singer Sabah Fakhri, who died this week at 88. 
Hundreds of people poured into the streets in Damascus to bid farewell to the Syrian tenor, who had entertained generations with traditional songs and preserved extinct forms of Arabic music. 
The body of the great artist was escorted from the capital's al-Shami Hospital, wrapped in the national flag.
Men carried his coffin on their shoulders and marched in a solemn procession in Damascus's Umayyad Square where funeral prayers were held. 
The procession then continued to Aleppo, Syria's second largest city and Fakhri's hometown.   
Fakhri died on Tuesday. The cause of death was not immediately known. 
He was born Sabah Abu Qaws in the Syrian city of Aleppo in 1933 and got his stage name as an adolescent performer.
Fakhri was a world class Tarab singer, an Arabic form of music associated with emotional evocation that can last for hours.  
On stage, Fakhri would engage the audience and sway to the music almost in a trance, turning the lyrics of his songs, often in classical Arabic, into refrains they could easily sing back to him.  
He once performed for 10 hours straight in 1968 at a concert in Caracas, Venezuela, without a single break, earning an entry in the Guinness Book of World Records.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4350941

Tiny and suffering from malnutrition, Mohebullah's life was on the brink, but doctors in Mirbacha Kot, a small district hospital outside Kabul, have managed to save him.
The same health workers continue to work without salaries, without medicine and with frequent power cuts as Afghanistan's economy crumbles.
In Mirbacha Kot, they have not been paid in five months.
Many of the medical staff feel they have no choice but to carry on as there is nowhere else for them to find work.  
Mohammed Javid Ahmadi, the 22-year-old recently-appointed Taliban supervisor of the hospital, has big plans for it, to the dismay of the doctors who work there.
Fresh from a war that has spanned most of his life, Ahmadi was asked by his superiors what kind of jobs he could do.
He was given the hospital from the gamut of ministries and institutions now under the Taliban's power following August's blitz takeover of the country.
The first order of his day is the registration book - Ahmadi wants every doctor to sign in and out.
It's a formality most health workers are too busy to remember, but neglecting it is enough to make Ahmadi angry.
The second is planning to build a mosque in the hospital grounds.
Workers come to the hospital to take measurements and Ahmadi gives them orders.
"We are Muslims, and we have 32 staff members, and for them, we need a mosque," he said.
"There are multiple benefits," he added.
Relatives can stay with sick patients overnight as the hospital lacks extra beds especially during the winter months, "and this is what is needed the most," Ahmadi stated.
Doctors, lacking basic equipment and salaries do not seem to be in agreement.
For Sabour Babakarkhil, the director of Mirbacha Kot hospital, it is a situation he is sadly familiar with.
"I remember during the past regime of the Taliban we faced similar problems. During that time I worked in a hospital, the hospital didn't have anything," he said.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) Palestinian families in a tense neighborhood of Jerusalem on Tuesday rejected an offer that would have delayed their eviction by Jewish settlers. 
The families' plight helped ignite protests and clashes earlier this year that eventually led to the 11-day Gaza war. 
During a news conference on Tuesday in Sheikh Jarrah, the families said their decision springs from "our belief in the justice of our cause and our right to our homes and our homeland."
The proposal floated by Israel's Supreme Court earlier this month would have made them "protected tenants" blocking any eviction and demolition order for at least the next 15 years, according to Ir Amim, an Israeli rights group that closely follows developments in the city.
But it would have forced them to acknowledge the settlers' ownership of the properties, which could weaken the families' case going forward.
The four families are among dozens in Jerusalem who are threatened with eviction by Jewish settler organizations in several cases that are at various legal stages. 
The settlers are making use of an Israeli law that allows them to claim properties that were owned by Jews prior to the 1948 war surrounding Israel's creation. 
Palestinians who lost homes, properties and lands in the same conflict do not have the right to recover them.
Israel captured east Jerusalem along with the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in the 1967 war. 
The Palestinians want all three territories to form their future state and consider east Jerusalem their capital.
Israel annexed east Jerusalem shortly after the 1967 war and considers the entire city to be its capital, a claim not recognized by most of the international community.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) BRANDI CARLILE, JIMMY JAM, CAROLE KING ON 2021'S MOST-DIVERSE CLASS OF HALL OF FAME INDUCTEES
This year's Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees are the most-diverse class yet, including Tina Turner, Carole King, The Go-Go's, Jay-Z, Foo Fighters, LL Cool J, Billy Preston, Randy Rhoads and Clarence Avant.
Backstage at Saturday's (30 OCT. 2021) induction ceremony, Brandi Carlile said she strides are "heartening to see."
"Rock and roll can, should and does look like the culture it impacts. And to see the amount of thought and intention put into that that I'm seeing today is really exciting to me. It's exciting to me as an LGBTQIA artist and it's exciting to me as a queer singer, and I'm I'm loving seeing this. This is a special, special night to be a part of."
Added music producer and writer Jimmy Jam, "I think the diversity of this class is wonderful, and as it should be. I mean, everybody has their opinion about what rock and roll is. I know a lot of people think that it's a white guy with a guitar, you know? Oh, I think it's so much broader than that, and I think it should want to be looked at much broader than that because to me, it should be known only about the music, but also about the attitude of the people that make the music. The groundbreaking, the breaking of barriers, which includes women, which includes hip hop, which includes all of those genres of music to me."

description:
(3 Nov 2021) CHANEL SHOWCASES ITS LATEST COLLECTION WITH A RUNWAY SHOW IN DUBAI
The iconic French label Chanel drew throngs of guests including some celebrities to view the brand's latest resort collection with a runway show in Dubai Tuesday (2 NOVEMBER). The collection was defined by its iconic stark two-tone pieces.  
It marked the second time Chanel has held a runway show for one of its cruise collections in Dubai, a global hub and shopping mecca that beckons jet-setting fashionistas and style mavens.
The Chanel Cruise 2021/22 collection by creative director Virginie Viard was first unveiled virtually in May due to the coronavirus pandemic. This time, it was shown to a live audience for the first time in Dubai. All guests in attendance had to prove to be fully vaccinated for COVID-19 or provide a negative PCR test.
The fashion for this collection was inspired by the label's founder, Gabrielle "Coco" Chanel, and her friendship with French filmmaker and visual artist Jean Cocteau. Specifically, the collection drew inspiration from a black and white experiential film he directed in 1960.
The ready-to-wear collection mirrored the era's modern and punk sensibilities with pieces distinguished by leather, fringes, beads, sequins, and Chanel's iconic tweed suit pieces. A few of the bags from the collection also included fringe, as well as redefined details on the label's quintessential black quilted leather style. The shoes included pointed metallic-wedged Mary Janes and mid-calf, gold-tipped booties. Accessories included a black leather garter with a small attached purse with Chanel's double-C logo.
The fashion on the runway was matched only by the fashion off the runway as the show's Chanel-clad guests, many of whom are loyal customers of the brand, sashayed through adjacent doors to the after-party, which featured a surprise performance by singer John Legend. Other celebrities in attendance included actress Penelope Cruz, as well as several Arabic-language movie stars. The diverse crowd of Lebanese, French, South Asian, Korean and others included many who'd flow in for the event.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351138

Three months after torrential rains flooded much of central China's Henan province, stretches of the country's flat agricultural heartland are still submerged in several inches of water. 
It's one of the many calamities around the world that are giving urgency to the UN climate summit under way in Glasgow, Scotland.
In the hardest hit areas of Henan, farmers are struggling after the floods destroyed most of their harvest. 
Some of the corn ears can be salvaged, but because the husks are moldy, they can be sold only as animal feed at lower prices.
Hou Beibei's greenhouse garden of eggplants, garlic and celery remain flooded three months after the rains. 
"We have been working so hard, breaking our backs … without even a penny back, my heart aches," said Hou. 
A 58-year-old farmer who gave only her last name, Song, said everything she owned was submerged by the floods — her home, furniture, fields, farming equipment.
"Ordinary people suffer the most," she said. 
The disaster was also a preview of the kind of extreme conditions the country is likely to face as the planet warms and the weather patterns growers depend upon are increasingly destabilized. 
China, the most populous country in the world, with 1.4 billion people, is now the planet's largest contributor to climate change, responsible for around 28% of carbon dioxide emissions that warm the Earth, though the United States is the biggest polluter historically.
As world leaders take part this week in the climate summit, China is being criticized for not setting a more ambitious timeline for phasing out fossil fuels.
President Xi Jinping, who has not left China since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic and will not be attending the summit but sent a veteran negotiator, has said the country's carbon emissions will level off before 2030. Critics say that's not soon enough.
Chinese government projections paint a worrying vision of the future: rising sea levels threatening major coastal cities, including Shanghai, Guangzhou and Hong Kong, and melting glaciers and permafrost imperiling western China's water supply and grand infrastructure projects such as the railroads across the Tibetan plateau.
Top government scientists also predict an increase in droughts, heat waves and extreme rainfall across China that could threaten harvests and endanger reservoirs and dams, including Three Gorges Dam.
Meanwhile, China's people are already suffering the brunt of climate change. And in a common pattern around the world, those who have contributed least to the warming and have the fewest resources to adapt often feel the pain most acutely.
In late July, Chinese news broadcasts carried startling footage of torrential rains swamping Henan's provincial capital, Zhengzhou — at one point, 8 inches (20 centimeters) fell in a single hour — with cars swept away, subways flooded and people struggling through waist-deep water. 
More than 300 people died as the megacity turned into an accidental Venice, its highways transformed into muddy canals.
Even after the most dramatic storms ceased, the water continued to pool in much of the surrounding countryside, a flat and fertile region.
Here the economy depends on corn, wheat and vegetables, and other regions of China depend on Henan for food. The local government reported that nearly 3 million acres (1.2 million hectares) of farmland were flooded — an area about the size of Connecticut — with damage totaling $18 billion.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
China's Huawei Technologies Co. is gearing up to provide smart services and 5G technology to industries such as healthcare for new revenue streams that might offset the damage to its smartphone business from U.S. sanctions. 
In the southern city of Guangzhou, the company has teamed up with a Chinese hospital to equip it with 5G technology and more than 10,000 smart devices that can collect and transmit real-time health data from patients to doctors and nurses to improve patient care. 

STORY-LINE:
This ambulance may look just like any other from the outside, but its on board medical devices are connected to 5G.
5G is an ultra-fast wireless technology that has little lag time and can support a massive number of smart devices connected to the internet simultaneously. The current mainstream technology, 4G, is slower at transmitting data and can support fewer devices.
The hospital in Guangzhou, a city of 15 million, uses various smart technologies, including this 5G ambulance. It is fitted with medical devices and cameras to transmit data and footage in real time, allowing doctors to make better diagnoses while patients are on their way to the hospital so they can be treated as soon as they arrive
In the case of a chest pain patient, their electrocardiogram can be immediately be sent back to the hospital where a cardiologist can review it and make an accurate diagnosis. 
If it suggests a heart attack, the hospital can prepare for an operation to be conducted as soon as the patient arrives.
"After the electrocardiography is done, the doctor in the ambulance can see it, and at the same time, people in the hospital, for example the cardiologists, can see the electrocardiogram too," says Liu Xingtao, chief physician and director of the emergency department the Guangdong Second Provincial General Hospital.
"This way, accurate diagnosis can be made. For example, this is a patient with chest pain, and electrocardiography is done (in the ambulance). And what does the electrocardiogram say? It suggests acute myocardial infarction. After a cardiologist examines (the electrocardiogram), the hospital can immediately activate the catheterisation laboratory. Once the patient arrives at the hospital, they can bypass both the emergency department and CCU (coronary care unit) and go to the catheterisation laboratory directly to receive emergency percutaneous coronary intervention. In this case, there will be a higher chance for a successful rescue."
According to Liu, thanks to the 5G ambulance, the time between a patient's arrival at the hospital and the conduction of an operation is reduced by around half an hour.
Without 5G, the transmission of medical data is slower, and some data could be lost due to bandwidth limitations.
Real-time monitoring and quicker diagnoses are also transforming the way that medical care is provided to inpatients at the hospital.
Now, doctors are able to monitor heart rates in real time, send an alert once there are abnormal signs and react accordingly much quicker.  
"No, you couldn't do real-time (monitoring). But now we are able to (monitor) in real time. When you're (only) carrying a device, I won't be able to see anything. In the worst-case scenario, if a patient passes out, we won't know what his/her heart rate is. With real-time (monitoring), we are able to learn about what's going on with a patient's heart rate and can immediately instruct them about what to do," says He Yongcong, a physician at the hospital's cardiovascular medicine department.
Altogether, the hospital can monitor the heart rate of around 400 patients at the same time.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) Hundreds of people blocked the streets of Ukraine's capital Wednesday to protest mandatory vaccination and new restrictions for non-vaccinated residents.
Around 500 protesters marched to the Ukrainian parliament building with placards urging the government to respect people's right not to get jabbed.
Starting Monday, Kyiv's authorities restricted access to public transport and venues for people who remain unvaccinated against COVID-19, in a bid to bolster the sluggish rate of vaccination in the country.
Non-vaccinated residents will no longer be able to go to work and visit public places unless they have tested negative for the coronavirus.
Restaurants, hotels and fitness centers will remain open if 100% of the employees are vaccinated or have negative daily tests.
Ukraine has one of the slowest paces of vaccinations in Europe.
Only around 17% of population have been fully vaccinated.
Ukraine has reported 23,393 new coronavirus cases Monday, bringing the country's total to more than 2.9 million.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) Republican Winsome Sears, who returned to Virginia politics after an absence of nearly two decades, has become the first female lieutenant governor and the first woman of color to win statewide office in Virginia.
Sears, who used her acceptance speech to priase her family, her Jamaican roots and her faith in God, says she also wants to be an inspiration.
"In case you haven't noticed, I am Black and I have been Black all my life," she says of her historic win.
Sears defeated Democrat Hala Ayala in Tuesday's election. Ayala also would have been the first woman of color to hold statewide office if she had won. 
The Republican rocketed out of political obscurity earlier this year when she won the GOP nomination on the strength of a campaign photo in which she posed holding a military rifle.
Sears will succeed Democrat Justin Fairfax, who unsuccessfully ran for governor. Her role as a tiebreaking vote in a closely divided state Senate has become even more important given GOP victories in other races. Republicans won the governor's mansion, and the party is also claiming that it has regained control of the House of Delegates, though several key races are still too early to call.
If Republicans do gain control of the House, the only thing blocking them from total control of state government is a narrow 21-19 Democratic advantage in the state Senate. Senators are not up for reelection until 2023.
A former Marine, Sears had a brief stint in electoral politics 20 years ago as a one-term delegate in the General Assembly, representing parts of Hampton Roads. Her return to politics after a two-decade absence began when she served as national chairperson for Black Americans to Re-Elect President Trump.
Throughout the race, Sears also highlighted her background as a Jamaican immigrant, campaigning against illegal immigration and rejecting the notion that the nation is plagued by systemic racism.
She said she will work to fully fund historically Black colleges and implement Youngkin's agenda.
Ayala conceded early Wednesday afternoon in a statement on Twitter.
During the campaign, Ayala criticized Sears for refusing to say whether she had been vaccinated against the coronavirus. Sears ridiculed mask mandates during the primary.
Sears won despite being badly outgunned financially — reports showed Ayala's campaign more than doubled Sears in fundraising, with $6.4 million raked in by Ayala, compared with $2.6 million for Sears.
Both the attorney general and the lieutenant governor posts have served as launching pads to the governor's mansion. Half of the past 10 lieutenant governors in Virginia have gone on to be governor. The previous nine elected attorneys general all ran for governor.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) PRINCE WILLIAM MEETS EARTHSHOT PRIZE WINNERS AT COP 26
Prince William met some of the winners of his Earthshot Prize Tuesday (2 NOVEMBER 2021) in Glasgow, where world leaders and U.K. royals are taking in part in COP 26.
The Prize is an ambitious environmental program that aims to find new ideas and technologies around the world to tackle climate change and Earth's most pressing challenges.
The prince talked to a few of the finalists and winners and then attended a reception.  He was introduced on stage by Michael Bloomberg, and told the guests that he was "honored and proud" to be working alongside the "Earthshot family." 
"Thank you for believing that we can face the vast challenges in front of us today, and for doing your utmost to overcome them," said William.  "Your success is our collective global Earthshot, and we will do everything we can to help you go further than before.  We are still at the start of our journey together and if we are to achieve our goal to repair our planet in what is now less than a decade, it is our shared responsibility to continue thinking differently, acting boldly, and making the impossible possible."  
William and his charity, The Royal Foundation, launched the Earthshot Prize last year, inspired by President John F. Kennedy's 1962 "Moonshot" speech that challenged and galvanized Americans to go to the moon.
The prize, to be awarded to five winners every year until 2030, is billed as the most prestigious of its kind.  Each winner will receive a grant worth 1 million pounds ($1.4 million) to develop and scale up their ideas.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) FAMILIES FLOCK TO SEE GIANT SCULPTURES IN SANTIAGO
People in the Chilean capital Santiago enjoyed an open-air exhibition by world-renowned artists on Saturday (30 OCTOBER 2021) with works that included giant rubber ducks, fried eggs, and a toy robot.
Works on display included the iconic rubber duck sculpture by Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman, the wooden troll by Thomas Dambo, and multiple installations of fried eggs by Henk Hofstra. 
The sculptures sit on the shore of the artificial Lake of the Family Park, filled with water diverted from the Mapocho River that flows through Santiago.  
"I think this is a great opportunity for the family to go out, rest, and enjoy open spaces as well as to enjoy works of art," said Diana Fernandez, one of the visitors.
Entrance to the exhibition is free. It's open in Santiago until Thursday. After that, it will go on tour to the cities of Iquique, Valdivia and Concepción.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) PAUL WESLEY AND IAN SOMERHALDER PLAYED BROTHERS ON 'VAMPIRE DIARIES' AND NOW THEY CO-OWN A BOURBON COMPANY
Actors Paul Wesley and Ian Somerhalder played vampire brothers on TV's "The Vampire Diaries" for eight seasons and now they have a new project together.
Wesley and Somerhalder have co-founded a bourbon company called, fittingly, Brothers Bond.
On "The Vampire Diaries," their characters drank bourbon together but Wesley says that off-screen, they're both big fans of the liquor.
"It's my drink.  He's a Louisiana boy. It's his drink of choice," said the 39-year-old actor, producer and director.
Wesley says the two have kept in touch since the show and live near each other in Los Angeles.  When they formed the company, they learned that making bourbon is not easy.
"I didn't know if we were going to be able to pull it off for a while," said Wesley, who played Stefan Salvatore on the supernatural smash hit.  
"And then just suddenly all the little pieces came together and our team was suddenly built and formed... but until we got the juice correct, until we got the mash bill tasting the way that we exactly wanted it, we didn't have anything.  And I remember that day.  We were blending the different mash bills and trying to figure all the stuff out in Ian's house and I just remember one day after months of blending, we looked at each other like, 'Oh, wow, this is that.  We love this.  We love this.'  And that was when really I felt like the company started."
He says that he and Somerhalder may have the same taste in bourbon but they're actually "100 percent opposite people" who complement each other.
"I am glass half-empty.  I am doom and gloom, everything's going to fall apart.  He is everything is amazing, glass half-full, oh my god, everything is unbelievable.  And in a way, it's important to have that yin and yang component when you have, you know, the two co-founders of a company and we balance one another out.  And I think that I wouldn't have it any other way, frankly.  And you know, like true brothers, we sometimes drive each other insane, but we never have these, like - it's funny, we joke, you know, we did the show for eight years.  We're stuck.  We've never had, like, you know, maybe because - we've literally never had a fight.  We argue.  I'm like, 'What are you talking about?  You're a moron,' and he says, 'No, you're a moron,' you know, but we don't do these fights.  We don't have fights.  We don't - there's no, like, major disagreements which is cool.  It's really cool.  We have this kind of, I don't know, it's kind of a unique relationship in that sense," said Wesley.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) South Korean President Moon Jae-in met with his Hungarian counterpart, Janos Ader, Wednesday in Budapest, to discuss bilateral issues, trade relations and their commitments to battling climate change. 
Moon's visit was part of a nine-day European tour, which includes a summit with the leaders of the Visegrad Group, a grouping that includes Hungary, Slovakia, Poland and the Czech Republic, as well as visits to Italy and the United Kingdom.
After arriving in Hungary, Moon paid tribute to the victims of the deadly 2019 'Hableany' tour boat accident on the Danube river in Budapest which claimed the lives of 27 South Korean tourists, one of whom was never recovered.
At a news briefing following talks with Ader, Moon thanked the Hungarian government for its efforts to recover the victims, and for erecting a memorial to the accident on the bank of the Danube where the tragedy took place. 
He also hailed bilateral trade between the two countries, which he said had broken records in 2020 despite the economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
South Korea's relations with Hungary have been elevated to a strategic partner status, Moon said, and praised Ader for his support of peace and denuclearization on the Korean peninsula. 
Ader said at the media briefing that the leaders had discussed points on the agenda of a U.N. climate summit currently underway in Glasgow, Scotland. 
"We have two common points concerning climate change," Ader said. "We both agreed that our countries will be carbon neutral by 2050, and we both think that climate neutrality cannot be achieved without nuclear energy."
Moon was expected to hold a closed-door meeting with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban later on Wednesday, according to an official with the prime minister's office.
It was the first state visit of a South Korean president to Hungary since 2001.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) Paraguay police said on Wednesday that an investigation into the murder of a German national and his daughter, killed in their home in a rural area near capital Asuncion, was still ongoing. 
Hugo Grance, Chief of Homicides, said police forensic teams were still collecting evidence and the motive for the crime was suspected to be an attempted robbery. 
No arrests have been made. 
According to police, Bernard Raymond von Bredow, 62, and his minor daughter had sustained gunshots and were tortured during the attack in Aregua town. 
Their bodies were discovered on October 22. 
Grance also said von Bredow decided to settle in a rural area in Paraguay, a common destination for retired Germans. 
He had been living in Aregua for two years, working as a violin-maker.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) STORYLINE: 
Decenas de migrantes que quedaron rezagados de una caravana que viene avanzando desde hace unos días por el sur de México se enfrentaron con piedras y palos a agentes de la Guardia Nacional que intentaban detenerlos. Al menos un oficial resultó herido.
El choque entre los oficiales y los migrantes, en su mayoría centroamericanos, ocurrió a escasos kilómetros del municipio sureño de Pijijiapan, en el estado de Chiapas. Los migrantes continuaban su camino hacia la Ciudad de México.  
La caravana de mayor dimensión que transita por México este año, partió el 23 de octubre de Tapachula, 110 kilómetros más al sur y casi en la frontera con Guatemala.  
Una fuente de la Secretaría de la Defensa Nacional dijo a The Associated Press que la estrategia para desarticular a la caravana será detener a los que se vayan quedando distantes del grueso del contingente. 
Durante el despliegue los elementos militares detuvieron a unos 30 extranjeros y pretendieron ir por otro grupo de migrantes pero este los recibió con palos y piedras obligando a los oficiales a replegarse.
-NAT- migrante que no dio su nombre
Un agente de la Guardia Nacional quedó inconsciente y los mismos migrantes trataron de auxiliarlo.
Pese a que la salud de los migrantes se ha visto afectada por el largo caminar durante 13 días, la mayoría de ellos insisten en no aceptar las visas humanitarias ofrecidas por el gobierno mexicano porque desconfían que sea un engaño para devolverlos a Tapachula o incluso deportarlos a su países de origen.
Los integrantes de la caravana han solicitado residencias permanentes en México y que se les permita el libre tránsito para poder establecerse en cualquier parte del país.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351134

Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger writes in a new book that he understood Donald Trump to be threatening him during a Jan. 2 phone call when Trump asked Raffensperger to help "find" enough votes to overturn Trump's loss in Georgia to Democratic President Joe Biden.
Raffensperger's book, "Integrity Counts" is being released Tuesday. On display is a man who stood up to pressure from Trump and his supporters, but also a man who's settling some political scores as he tries to survive a hostile Republican primary environment to win reelection in 2022.
An engineer who grew wealthy before running for office, Raffensperger recounts the blow-by-blow struggle in Georgia that followed Biden's narrow victory, including death threats texted to his wife, an encounter when a Georgia state trooper was driving him with men who may have been staking out his suburban Atlanta home, and being escorted out of the Georgia state capitol on Jan. 6 as a handful of right-wing protesters entered the building.
The book climaxes with the phone call, which was recorded and then given to multiple news organizations. Raffensperger — known as a conservative Republican before Trump targeted him — writes that he perceived that Trump was threatening him at multiple points in the phone call.
"I'm not picking a battle with him. He's picking one with me. I'll I've done is said he didn't win the state of Georgia. Twenty-eight thousand people skipped the presidential ballot. What does that have to do with my office? That has to do with his campaign team and the state elections party turning out people to vote. Why did 28,000 Georgians skip the presidential ballot? They didn't vote for anyone. They didn't vote for Biden. They didn't vote for President Trump. They didn't vote for Jo Jorgensen. They skipped it. Yet, they voted down ballot. Whose fault it that?" Raffensperger told The AP in an interview in his office.
