description:
(4 Nov 2021) Vietnamese authorities said on Thursday that they were in contact with Iranian authorities to resolve the seizure of a Vietnamese oil tanker and to ensure the wellbeing of the crew. 
Pham Thu Hang, a spokesperson for the foreign ministry, said their diplomatic offices were working with Iranian authorities to address the issue. 
Hang said the captain of the seized MV Southys vessel told the Vietnamese embassy in Iran on 27 October, three days after the seizure, that all 26 crew members were being treated well and were in normal health. 
According to two U.S officials, Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard troops took control of the MV Southys on 24 October at gunpoint.
Analysts believe the vessel was trying to transfer Iranian crude oil to Asia, in defiance of sanctions.
U.S. forces had monitored the seizure, but ultimately didn't take action as the vessel sailed into Iranian waters.
It's the latest provocation in Mideast waters as tensions escalate between Iran and the United States over Tehran's nuclear program.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351450

An independent Pentagon review has concluded that the U.S. drone strike that killed innocent Kabul civilians and children in the final days of the Afghanistan war was not caused by misconduct or negligence, and it doesn't recommend any disciplinary action.
The review, done by Air Force Lt. Gen. Sami Said, found that there were some breakdowns in communications and in the process of identifying and confirming the target of the bombing, according to a senior defense official familiar with the report. 
But, Said concluded that the mistaken strike happened despite prudent measures to prevent civilian deaths.
Said's review said the incident must be considered in the context of the moment, as U.S. forces under stress were being flooded by information about threats to troops and civilians at the Kabul airport, just days after a deadly suicide bombing. Thousands of Afghans were swarming the airport, trying to get out the country in the wake of the Taliban takeover.
Said found that better communication between those making the strike decision and other support personnel might have raised more doubts about the bombing, but in the end may not have prevented it. 
Said was asked to investigate the Aug. 29 drone strike on a white Toyota Corolla sedan, that killed Zemerai Ahmadi, and nine family members, including seven children.  Ahmadi, 37, was a longtime employee at an American humanitarian organization.
The intelligence about the car and its potential threat came just days after an Islamic State suicide bomber killed 13 U.S. troops and 169 Afghans at a Kabul Airport gate. The U.S. was working to evacuate thousands of Americans, Afghans and other allies in the wake of the collapse of the country's government.
Said concluded that U.S. forces genuinely believed that the car they were following was an imminent threat and that they needed to strike it before it got closer to the airport.
Said's report, which has been endorsed by Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, made several recommendations for improvements that have been passed on to commanders at U.S. Central Command and U.S. Special Operations Command. 
One of those recommendations is that more be done to prevent what military officials call "confirmation bias" — the idea that troops making the strike decision were too quick to conclude that what they were seeing aligned with the intelligence and confirmed their conclusion to bomb what turned out to be the wrong car.
The review recommends that the military have personnel present with the strike team whose job is to actively question such conclusions. The report says that using a so-called "red-teams" in such self-defense strikes that are being done quickly, might help avoid errors.
Said also recommeded that the military improve its procedures to ensure that children and other innocent civilian are not present before launching a time-sensitive strike.
For days after the strike, Pentagon officials asserted that it had been conducted correctly, despite mounting reports that multiple civilians and children had died and growing doubts that the car contained explosives. Said's review concluded that officials made their initial assessments too quickly and did not do enough analysis.
While Said's report does not find individual fault or recommend discipline, officials said that commanders may decide to take administrative actions once they review his report.
The U.S. is working to pay financial reparations to the family, and potentially get them out of Afghanistan, but nothing has been finalized.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

description:
(1 Nov 2021) 'SQUID GAME' MAKES WAVES IN CHINA DESPITE NOT PASSING CENSORS
A game that offers an opportunity of reliving the horror of "Squid Game" has attracted customers to Lynn Xue's lemon tea shop in Beijing since it opened two months ago.  
Xue has reproduced the dalgona game featured in the Netflix's highest rated show. 
The game requires players to carve out a complete shape imprinted on brittle candy, known as dalgona in South Korea, by using a needle.  
The South Korean survival drama depicts a group of desperate debtors competing in a series of traditional children's games, such as dalgona, to win megabucks or die. 
Fortunately, in Xue's shop there is nothing to lose. And customers can be awarded with a glass of lemon tea or another dalgona candy if they do well. 
Retailers on China's biggest e-commers platforms such as Taobao and JD.com have also been inspired to cash in on costumes and other spin-offs from the show. Even clothing sets for pets are available. 
The Chinese mainland is one of a few regions in the world where Netflix is banned. Still, many in the country have watched pirate copies of "Squid Game" or used VPNs to log onto Netflix. Over 370,000 viewers marked "watched" on Douban, a Chinese social media site popular with movie fanatics, with the show's hashtag on Weibo drawing over two billion views. 
"I think people like to watch horror dramas with bloody and violent images, because China is unable to make good horror dramas," says lemon tea shop customer, Tang Qitong. 
To further ape the series, Xue has hung on the shop ceiling a paper imitation of Younghee, a creepy doll in the game "Red Light, Green Light", looking down on customers. 
Xue says she's surprised that about 90 percent of the customers coming to her shop have watched the show.
"The sugar is very hot and sticky, and the candy came at a high scrap rate", said Xue, "The worst case I had is 51 of 100 candies were broken when they were delivered."
Chinese state media has criticized the show for its bloody and violent images that they believe could have a negative impact on adolescents. Days later, another report on state media said Netflix has raked in a big fortune from the South Korean production team. 
The criticism made it less likely for "Squid Game" to pass censorship and be aired in China officially.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/APArchives ​​
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/APNews/


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0777f57904b647f19a06be9b10e4a8c3
tags: 0777f57904b647f19a06be9b10e4a8c3, 4350988, AP Archive, Arts and entertainment, Beijing, China, China Squid Game, East Asia, Greater China, South Korea
title: 'Squid Game' makes waves in China despite not passing censors

description:
(2 Nov 2021) Mexicans returned to public celebrations of the Day of the Dead holiday Monday after the pandemic forced the closure of most cemeteries last year.  
In some smaller villages around Lake Patzcuaro in Michoacán state, residents were trying to preserve their renowned, authentic traditions passed down for hundreds of years in the face of tourism.  
"Tourists just come here to learn about our traditions, but we don't want them to interrupt us, because this is ours", said Elvia Solorio, whilst holding a vigil for her lost loved one at the cemetery in Arocutín.
Residents of the small lakeside town lit candles, laid orange marigold flowers and fruit baskets on the graves at the small local cemetery late afternoon Monday for the Day of the Dead.
Tourists arrived later at night as families held a vigil for and shared a meal with their dead, who, according to tradition, pay them a visit at night, entering the land of the living through a decorated wooden arch.

title: Mexico welcomes back Day of the Dead tourism

description:
(2 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351270

The spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians has given his formal blessing to a shrine that will replace a small parish church destroyed during the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks in New York City. 
Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew of Constantinople presided over the ceremonial door opening at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and National Shrine near the World Trade Center. 
He said the shrine is a place to show the world "that good is mightier than evil, that there is life beyond death and that love will always triumph over hate."

description:
(1 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351092

Sen. Joe Manchin says it's "time to vote" on a nearly $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, dashing hopes for swift resolution over President Joe Biden's broader policy package. 
Democrats wanted a signal from Manchin that he will support Biden's big package. Instead Monday he held a press conference at the Capitol and rebuffed progressive Democrats, telling them to quit holding "hostage" the slimmer infrastructure bill as negotiations continue on the broader package. 
Manchin said he's open to voting for a final bill reflecting Biden's big package "that moves our country forward." But he said he's "equally open to voting against" the final product as he assesses the overall framework of the sweeping social services and climate change bill.
This as Democrats have made significant progress on adding compromise provisions curbing prescription drug prices to the $1.75 trillion broader package. Democrats hope to resolve their differences vote as soon as this week.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) The UK Minister for the Armed Forces said on Wednesday that the alleged murder of a Kenyan woman by a British soldier had "let down the British Armed Forces". 
Kenyan authorities announced Tuesday they would be reopening the case of the murder of Agnes Wanjiru in 2012.
Speaking during a news conference while on a visit to the African country, James Heappey said it was "important for the UK government to show our solidarity with Agnes' family."
"I believe that she has a right to justice, her daughter has a right to justice and I think it is perfectly possible that we can meet without prejudicing the case and without admitting culpability," he added.
Heappey further said that the UK had nothing to hide as far as the case is concerned and would aid in the investigations accordingly. 
"We need that now to be investigated and brought to the courts here in Kenya as quickly as possible and any further allegations that come to light will be dealt with the same urgency on our part," he said.  
Wanjiru's body was found in a septic tank weeks after witnesses said she was seen leaving a bar with British soldiers.
Heappey said that the behaviour of the British military abroad "reflects the United Kingdom" and that what had allegedly happened near the Batuk training camp in Nanyuki "frankly has let down the British Armed Forces."

description:
(1 Nov 2021) A young inventor at the UN Climate Change Conference said "youth plays a big part in solving climate change." 
Vinisha Umashankar, 14, from India was a finalist of the Earthshot Prize, Prince William's ambitious global environmental award. 
The youngster created a solar-powered ironing cart, offering a clean alternative to charcoal-powered street irons that press clothes for millions daily.
On the streets of rural India, ironing vendors dump burnt, unused charcoal. It has been a way of life for decades.
But where many saw tradition, Vinisha Umashankar, then 12, saw a need for change, having recently learnt about pollution and renewable energy at school.
"In India, we usually put up with inconveniences rather than solving them," she told The Associated Press just a day before addressing world leaders at the COP26 climate summit.
While Umashankar did not win first prize her idea is attracting the attention of investors and she says she has a business plan to scale up production.
In Glasgow, she said she wants to call for urgent optimism: a call for rapid action, but with the conviction that every action counts and saving our planet is still possible.

description:
(31 Oct 2021) Prime Minister Zoran Zaev announced his resignation late Sunday following the heavy defeat of his governing Social Democratic Union in North Macedonia's local elections.
  
“The responsibility for this outcome is mine and I’m resigning as prime minister and as leader of the Social Democratic Union,” Zaev said at a news conference at party headquarters.
  
Zaev came out against early national elections. Instead, he will support a Social Democrat-led government under a new leader.
  
Although official results were not yet in from the local elections, Zaev conceded defeat in the most important contest - the mayor's race in the capital, Skopje, with incumbent Petre Shilegov losing to a center-right challenger, Danela Arsovska.
  
Candidates supported by the main opposition party, the center-right VMRO-DPMNE, appeared set to win at least half of the country’s 80 municipalities, with the Social Democrats set to win fewer than 20. 
At the last municipal elections, in 2017, the Social Democrats won 57 contests and VMRO-DPMNE only five.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) French President Emmanuel Macron met with British heir to the throne Prince Charles at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgoew on Monday. 
The pair were hosting a meeting on concrete measures that need to be taken in order to put into place the so-called Great Green Wall initiative in Africa.
The ambitious plan seeks to take on the impact of climate change in the belt along the Sahel region with a vast agricultural and ecological program which will span the entire width of the continent.
Prince Charles told attendees the Great Green Wall initiative "offers a precious opportunity to restore land, forest and biodiversity while also addressing the social, economic, and environmental impact of land degradation and desertification."
Macron echoed the prince's words, stating the scheme was a chance to tackle climate change but also poverty and terrorism.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) Queen Elizabeth II urged leaders at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow to "rise above the politics of the moment" and work together to create a "stabler future" for the planet.
In a video message recorded on Friday at Windsor Castle, she said she hoped leaders would "answer the call of those future generations" to address the impact of climate change.
"The time for words has now moved to the time for action," the Queen said.
She said she "could not be prouder" of her late husband, son and grandson and their work on the environment. 
"The leading role my husband played in encouraging people to protect our fragile planet lives on through the work of our eldest son, Charles and his eldest son, William," the Queen said.
"We, none of us will live forever. But we are doing this not for ourselves, but for our children and our children children and those who will follow in their footsteps," she went on to say. 
The 95-year-old monarch was due to attend the conference but has been advised to rest by her doctors.
Buckingham Palace said in a statement last Friday that the Queen had been advised to rest for at least the next two weeks.

title: Queen: Time for words has moved to time for action

description:
(31 Oct 2021) An environmental negotiator for some of the poorest and most vulnerable countries said Sunday he was looking to the world's biggest polluters to lead the way with efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions.
Speaking to the Associated Press at COP26 in Glasgow,  Kevin Conrad, the chairman of the Coalition for Rainforest Nations, said he could "understand there's a little bit of trepidation" among the wealthiest nations to making financial commitments amid the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.
But he said it was "still very disconcerting" those G-20 countries, which generate around 80% of carbon emissions, were unable to make necessary agreements on climate change when together at events like COP.
Conrad, who is based in Papua New Guinea, said the country was already noticing the effects of global warming and raised concerns about food security.
"It's impacting our fisheries, it's impacting our coastlines, it's impacting our agriculture," he said, noting that fish were relocating from Papua New Guinea's waters to cooler seas elsewhere.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351114

As deadlines loom for military and defense civilians to get mandated COVID-19 vaccines, senior leaders must now wrestle with the fate of those who flatly refuse the shots or are seeking exemptions, and how to make sure they are treated fairly and equally.
  
The vast majority of the active duty force has received at least one shot, but tens of thousands have not. For some it may be a career-ending decision. Others could face transfers, travel restrictions, limits on deployments and requirements to repay bonuses.
  
Exemption decisions for medical, religious and administrative reasons will be made by unit commanders around the world, on what the Pentagon says will be a “case-by-case” basis. That raises a vexing issue for military leaders who are pushing a vaccine mandate seen as critical to maintaining a healthy force, but want to avoid a haphazard, inconsistent approach with those who refuse.
  
The military services are reporting between 1%-7% remain unvaccinated. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has called for compassion in dealings with those troops, which totals nearly 60,000 active duty service members, according to data released last week.  
Asked about possible variations in the treatment of those seeking exemptions or refusing the vaccine, Pentagon press secretary John Kirby said it’s up to the services. "Each case is going to be treated specifically and individually as it ought to be,” he said. 
  
It unclear how widely religious exemptions will be granted. Under military rules, commanders can take into account the potential impact on a unit’s mission, and reject a religious exemption if it puts performance at risk.
The Air Force may be the test case in some instances, because they are the first to hit a deadline. The more than 335,000 airmen and Space Force guardians must be fully vaccinated by Tuesday, and the Air Guard and Reserve by Dec. 2. According to Air Force data, as many as 12,000 active duty airmen and guardians were still unvaccinated as of late last week. Some have requested or gotten exemptions, others have refused outright. They have until Monday to request exemptions.
The most successful service has been the Navy, which says that only 1% of the force is unvaccinated as of last week - or about 3,500 sailors. The Air Force and Space Force was second, with 3.6% unvaccinated, followed by the Army and Marine Corps at about 7%.
  
Vaccination numbers fluctuate for the military services, and drop off considerably for the National Guard and Reserve.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) RESTRICTION SUMMARY: AP CLIENTS ONLY

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Londres - 27 de julio de 2021
STORYLINE: 
Por encima del bullicio de la intersección de Marble Arch en Londres hay una nueva atracción para el público.
Un montículo hueco es la última instalación temporal que permite a los visitantes ver la ciudad desde 25 metros de altura.
SOUNDBITE : Leoni Avison, visitante:
"Creo que es una forma estupenda de conseguir un poco más de espacio verde en un lugar tan concurrido y bullicioso," dijo esta turista. "Y parece que se obtienen unas vistas magníficas de Londres que de otro modo no se tendrían".
El montículo de Marble Arch está situado en la esquina de Hyde Park; los visitantes ascienden 134 escalones para llegar a la cima.
La instalación, de color verde, forma parte de una campaña más amplia para fomentar las visitas al centro de Londres y revitalizar la escena cultural londinense.
El ayuntamiento de Westminster dice que los materiales utilizados se reciclarán y se utilizarán en otros parques pequeños. Las entradas para adultos a la instalación cuestan el equivalente de 5,5 usd a 11 usd.
A pesar de un aumento de las infecciones de COVID-19 a principios del verano, el gobierno eliminó el 19 de julio la mayoría de las restricciones aún vigentes en interacciones sociales y comerciales.
Sin embargo, los científicos advierten que el público no debe estar satisfecho ya que los altos niveles de infección en la comunidad probablemente provoquen otro aumento de casos en los próximos meses.
El motivo de su pesimismo es la variante delta del COVID-19, que ahora domina en el Reino Unido. Las vacunas son menos efectivas contra esta variante más transmisible, lo que significa que Gran Bretaña debe lograr una mayor tasa de vacunación si espera controlar la enfermedad. Aproximadamente el 60% de la población del Reino Unido ha sido totalmente vacunada.
ANNE MARIE GARCIA, ASSOCIATED PRESS
===========================================================

description:
(3 Nov 2021) A prosecutor says Kyle Rittenhouse instigated the confrontation that led him to shoot three people on the streets of Kenosha, Wisconsin, during a turbulent protest against racial injustice. 
But Rittenhouse's attorney says his client acted in self-defense after one of the men dove for his gun and others kicked him in the face and clubbed him in the head with a skateboard. 
The two accounts came during opening statements Tuesday at Rittenhouse's murder trial.
Rittenhouse, now 18, is charged with killing two men and wounding a third with an assault-style rifle during the summer of 2020. 
He could get life in prison if convicted.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Large sinkholes at the shores of the Red Sea are threatening local communities and tourists at the lowest point of land on Earth.

STORY-LINE:
Sinkholes keep appearing at the lowest place on Earth – the shores of the Dead See – due to climate change. 
The phenomenon has increased over the past years, making the area unsafe for visitors and locals alike.
The Dead Sea keeps shrinking, and its water level is receding at a rate of about 1.4 meter (4.6 foot) annually.
"The sinkholes keep appearing because of climate change, rising temperatures and because it's a hot area at the shores here," said environmental activist Fathi al-Hwaymil.
He said dams built on the tributaries of the Dead Sea and factories located on its shores are causing sea levels to decrease.
"We call on the concerned authorities and international donors to save the Dead Sea as it is the cultural heritage of Jordan," the activist added.
Impoverished communities living near the shores of the sea rely on land cultivation and jobs in nearby factories. 
Many farms have become unsafe because of the massive sinkholes.
The sinkholes have also damaged and destroyed many houses, roads and factories. 
They became an obstacle for investment projects in the area.
Spanning 50 kilometers (31 meters) in length and lying 429 meters (1,407 feet) below sea level, the Dead Sea lake is one of the saltiest in the world.
Saad Abu Hammour, a water expert and head of the Friends of the Dead Sea Society, says the area of the Dead Sea has shrunk from 900 square kilometers (347 square miles) to 600 sq km (231 sq miles) in the last three decades.
"The more sea water recedes, the more cracks increase, and the more sinkholes appear," the expert said.
Abu Hammour said the Red-Dead Water Conveyance Project, which envisions channeling water from the Red Sea into the Dead Sea, will solve the problems caused by the Dead Sea's depletion, but this project was cancelled.
Due to climate change, a drop in rainfall and droughts are likely to proliferate in the region in the future, he added.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/APArchives ​​
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/APNews/


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/898f0eaa5c3d43f4893de9ef3f7870e0
tags: 4351356, 898f0eaa5c3d43f4893de9ef3f7870e0, AP Archive, Dead Sea, Environment and nature, General news, Jordan, MEEX Jordan Climate Sinkholes, Middle East, Red Sea, Social affairs
title: Sinkholes multiply as Dead Sea recedes

description:
(1 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
A young Congolese entrepreneur is hoping to tackle mortality rates in the country's mining industry with the help of a new mobile app.
It works in combination with a wearable safety belt to show a miner's location and even the temperature in the underground pit.

STORY-LINE:
Mining is crucial to the Democratic Republic of Congo's economy - known for its rich soil and mineral resources - but work in the mines can be dangerous. Accidents and landslides take dozens of lives every year. 
Entrepreneur Victoire Shukuru knows people who died in the mines. So he has come up with an idea for the app, called "Min Security". 
It's a tool that integrates GPS tracking technology with an electronic safety belt connected to a smartphone app.
Miners wear the belt around their waist and, as they go further underground to dig for minerals, managers can track their location for up to one kilometre into the pit. 
This lets them to know the exact whereabouts of the miners in case of an emergency or landslide. 
The mobile app also lets managers monitor the temperature underground and foresee any dangers, such as oxygen shortages.
A group of miners at Mutanga mine, in the Masisi region towards the northwest of the country, believes the app is an important invention that could save lives.
"If at a moment something dangerous were to happen to us down here, they will be alerted quickly on the other side and we will be saved," says 35-year-old miner Jean Tafazali, who digs for coltan, cassiterite and tourmaline.
Despite the dangers, men still take the risk as it provides an attractive income.
"Here on the site of Mutanga, we can find coltan," explains mine manager, Biyimana Habyarimana, who says he has six mouths to feed. "This helps us to live, we can buy cattle, fields to cultivate, cows, and we can build houses."
Shukuru says it was the deaths of people he knew that pushed him to action. 
"Given that I am in the digital field, I said to myself I had to create a digital solution that can help our brothers who – for lack of other opportunities – resort to mining to find a means of survival," he says.
The mining activity allows them to earn money and feed their families, but the price for that is sometimes death. 
Sebyera Riziki is a 32-year-old widow mother of five children who lives in Mutanga village. 
"People continue to go to the mines even if they never stop collapsing and each time people die," she says.
Her husband died in a mine two years ago. She says it took a toll on her physical and mental health. His death left the family in financial hardship.
"I was very depressed because he would leave and come back with money to help our family. He is so missed, he disappeared down the mine," she says, seated outside her home with her children. 
Hopefully, technology will mean fewer women like Riziki have to go through that pain.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/APArchives ​​
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/APNews/


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0dc3af5978d8438a9880abd7ccab301b
tags: 0dc3af5978d8438a9880abd7ccab301b, 4350665, AP Archive, Biyimana Habyarimana, Central Africa, Democratic Republic of the Congo, General news, HZ DRCongo Mine Safety Device, Jean Tafazali, Lifestyle, Media, Sebyera Riziki, Technology, Victoire Shukuru
title: Congolese inventor creates wearable mining safety device

description:
(4 Nov 2021) "Sex and the City" fans who always imagined what it would be like to be Carrie Bradshaw can now get a better idea by spending a night at a recreated version of her Upper East Side brownstone apartment. 
For just two nights in November, Sarah Jessica Parker in partnership with Airbnb and Warner Bros. Consumer Products, is renting the space to two lucky guests to celebrate and promote the upcoming release of the HBO Max Original "And Just Like That," which marks Carrie's return to the television screen.
Liz DeBold Fusco, of Airbnb, said, "There are a lot of really special elements here for the fans who are lucky enough to get to book these stays. You can see a cordless phone similar to one that Carrie used to chat hours into the night with her friends. You can see her Carrie necklace sitting by her bedside, of course. You can even type away at Carrie's PowerBook."
And of course, there's Carrie's fashion-forward closet. "Guests will be able to enjoy and play dress-up while they spend their night here in the recreated apartment. One item is this white tutu which will look familiar to fans. It's a recreation of the tutu which Carrie Bradshaw famously wore on 'Sex and the Ciy.'" DeBold Fusco shared.
Parker will virtually host two, one-night stays for up to two guests each  on Nov. 12 and 13. She'll offer a virtual greeting at check-in and a narration reminiscent of each episode's intro.
Requests for the bookings  begin Monday, Nov. 8, at noon ET at airbnb.com/sexandthecity.

description:
(3 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351326

Boston voters for the first time elected a woman and an Asian American as mayor, tapping City Councilor Michelle Wu to serve in the city's top office. 
New England's largest city had previously only elected white men as mayor since its founding in 1630 by English puritans. 
Wu defeated fellow Boston City Councilor Annissa Essaibi George. 
The two Democrats faced off against each other after defeating other mayoral hopefuls in a September preliminary election. 
The election of Wu, whose parents immigrated from Taiwan, marks another break from tradition in Boston. 
Wu grew up in Chicago, moving to Boston to attend Harvard University and Harvard Law School. 
Boston typically elects mayors with lifelong Boston roots. 
Wu takes office on Nov. 16.

description:
(1 Nov 2021) The Ukrainian capital restricted access to public transport and venues for people who remain unvaccinated against COVID-19, in a bid to booster the sluggish rate of vaccination in the country. 
Non-vaccinated residents of Kyiv will no longer be able to go to work and visit public places unless they have tested negative for the coronavirus.
Restaurants, hotels and fitness centers will remain open if 100% of the employees are vaccinated or have negative daily tests. 
Ukraine has one of the slowest paces of vaccinations in Europe. 
Only around 17% of population have been fully vaccinated.
Ukraine has reported 13,936 new coronavirus cases Monday.
More than 3 million have been infected since the pandemic began, and more than 72,000 deaths have been recorded.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS GET CARDI B TO HOST THE SHOW THIS YEAR
Cardi B has won five American Music Awards and performed on the telecast during her career so far. Next step: hosting the show.
The rapper behind such hits as “Bodak Yellow” and “Money” has been tapped to host the fan-voted awards show airing from Los Angeles on ABC on Nov. 21.
“We are immensely excited to have the dynamic Cardi B bring her infectious energy to the American Music Awards as a first-time host,” said executive producer Jesse Collins in a statement Tuesday.
Cardi B performed “I Like It” at the AMAs in 2018 with J Balvin and Bad Bunny and also made history during her last AMAs appearance, becoming the first female rapper to win Favorite Hip-Hop Song twice. 
Olivia Rodrigo, in the first year she’s eligible, is the leading nominee this time with seven, including artist of the year and new artist of the year. 
Five-time winner The Weeknd has six nominations, going up against Rodrigo in the artist of the year category along with BTS, Ariana Grande, Drake and Taylor Swift.
Reggaeton star Bad Bunny, R&B newcomer Giveon and Doja Cat each have five nominations each. In the new artist of the year category, Rodrigo joins Giveon, 24KGoldn, Masked Wolf and The Kid LAROI.
Swift, who currently holds the record for the most awarded artist in AMA history, could further extend her streak. She is nominated for three awards total, including favorite pop album for “evermore.”
The AMAs added new categories this year, including favorite trending song, favorite gospel artist and favorite Latin duo or group.
Rapper Pop Smoke, who was killed in 2020, is nominated in three categories, including favorite hip-hop album and favorite hip-hop artist, and could win his first award posthumously.

description:
(4 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351487

New Jersey Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy narrowly won reelection Wednesday, eking out a victory that spared Democrats the loss of a second gubernatorial seat. 
He’s the state’s first Democratic governor to get a second straight term in 44 years, defeating Republican former Assembly member Jack Ciattarelli.
AP called the race Wednesday evening when a new batch of votes from Republican-leaning Monmouth County increased Murphy’s lead and closed the door to a Ciattarelli comeback.
Ballots remaining to be counted included a significant number of votes from predominantly Democratic Essex County, along with mail-in votes spread across other counties. Murphy has won the mail-in vote by a wide margin even in Republican leaning counties like Monmouth.
Ciattarelli spokesperson Stami Williams disputed the call because of the close margin, calling it “irresponsible.”
Murphy delivered a brief speech in Asbury Park's boardwalk convention hall, nodding to the race's narrow margin by saying he would work for both those who voted for and against him. But there was no trace he planned to scale back the left-leaning positions he's taken during his first term. 
“We shall be judged in the long run not by how we fared in elections, but by what we did as an administration,” Murphy said, quoting Brendan Byrne, the last Democratic governor to be reelected in the state. “Those words will always remind us to always, always, always keep moving forward.” 
Ciattarelli waged a formidable campaign in heavily Democratic New Jersey, his spending nearly equaling  the governor’s and outpacing the GOP’s performance four years ago. But Murphy’s advantages, including 1 million more registered Democrats, proved too much for the Republican to overcome. 
The victory gives Democrats a silver lining after GOP businessman Glenn Youngkin defeated Terry McAuliffe in Virginia’s gubernatorial race - exacerbating worries that President Joe Biden’s sagging approval ratings are hurting the party. This year’s elections were the first major tests of voter sentiment since Biden took office and pointed to a potentially painful year ahead for Democrats as they try to maintain thin majorities in Congress.

description:
(2 Nov 2021) Faith leaders and activists across the world are increasingly joining the fight against climate change driven by a moral imperative to preserve creation for future generations.
"We have definitely seen a big increase in the faith based communities joining with indigenous peoples," said Chief Shirell Parfait-Dardar of the Grand Caillou and Dulac Band of Biloxi-Chitimacha-Choctaw Indian Tribe, who lives in the costal region of southern Louisiana. She said they're "standing up and saying, 'wait a minute, God creator blessed us with this planet we should be doing what's responsible.'
The Rev. Kristina Peterson is one of those faith leaders who has partnered with Chief Parfait-Dardar and others in the region to help start initiatives that will reduce the effects of climate change.
"The gospel is not about production and growth, or success," said the Rev. Peterson, "it's about care and love and that connection with the earth and caring for your earth and all that dwell in it."
One of their current projects, which has been temporarily halted by Hurricane Ida, is to refill canals that have for decades been cut and widened by oil companies. 
"There's a lot of canals, 10,000 miles of canals that have been cut over the years, since about 1950," said the Rev. Peterson. "And so what we're doing is working with a buddhist friend, Jean Turner, whose a professor at LSU. Working with him and working with three tribes to bring that knowledge together of the fishers who are on the water, his knowledge, the knowledge of other folks who have done mapping with how the landscape has changed to see where the most logical place is to refill canals."
Donald Dardar, of the Pointe-au-Chien Indian Tribe, has been shrimping along these same bayous for decades and provides his lived experience to help the community combat further land erosion. 
"We're heading down Pointe-au-Chien bayou. This side of the bayou is Lafourche and this side is Terrebonne," said Dardar pointing from a small fishing boat. "I don't know must be at least 80, 80 something feet wide," he said showing a canal that has drastically changed over the years.
He and other advocates, including his wife and the Rev. Kristina Peterson, have also created living shorelines, another project that utilizes oyster shells to help combat land erosion.
"You can see the oyster bag right here. We did the whole shoreline here," Dardar said. "We had to put that there to protect, otherwise this would all be probably all washed in the water already if we didn't put them bags."
"We do many things to try and save our community and our burial grounds and all because everything is out of the levy system" said Dardar's wife, Theresa Dardar of the Pointe-au-Chien Indian Tribe, "if we don't do anything it will eventually all wash away."
Many, like the Rev. Peterson, say they're not going to wait for world leaders to take action on the climate crisis, "we're doing it now," she said.
And even after her home was destroyed and projects were put on hold due to Hurricane Ida, which made landfall in late August, Chief Parfait-Dardar continues to join in the climate efforts, fighting to save the community she hopes will be around for her grandchildren. "I want them to remember that I fought for them, for their home. For their way of life," she said.
___

description:
(3 Nov 2021) World leaders have been meeting for 29 years to try to curb global warming, and in that time Earth has become a much hotter and deadlier planet.  
Statistics show trillions of tons of ice have disappeared over that period, the burning of fossil fuels has spewed billions of tons of heat-trapping gases into the air, and hundreds of thousands of people have died from heat and other weather disasters stoked by climate change.
More than 100 world leaders descended on Rio de Janeiro in 1992 for an Earth Summit to discuss global warming and other environmental issues.
That set up the process of international climate negotiations that culminated in the 2015 Paris accord and resumed Sunday in Glasgow, Scotland, where leaders will try to ramp up efforts to cut carbon pollution.
Earth has warmed more in the last 29 years than in the previous 110. Since 1992, the world has broken the annual global high temperature record eight times.  
The yearly global temperature has increased almost 1.1 degrees Fahrenheit (0.6 degrees Celsius) since 1992, based on multi-year averaging, according to the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. 
Climate scientist Gerald Meehl says even a small increase in the global average affects temperature extremes.
"We're twice as likely to set a record high maximum than a record low minimum," said Meehl, a senior scientist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research. "That's kind of what climate change is, it's kind of shifting the odds towards certain outcomes."
In the early 2000s, Meehl and his colleagues predicted that heat waves in the 21st century would hit normally temperate regions that had not yet adapted for extreme heat events.
"We looked in the future in a warming climate with increasing greenhouse gases, and we saw these changes in the patterns of future heat waves," Meehl said.
That's exactly what happened in the Pacific Northwest in June.  
"It's been estimated that there were over 600 excess heat related deaths in Washington and Oregon alone in one week," said Dr. Renee Salas of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
Salas says heat is one of the most visible ways climate change affects health.
"Extreme heat can cause damage to the brain, worsen mental health impacts," she said. "It can affect heart and lung disease, kidney disease."
And people who are more exposed to heat and less able to adapt are the most vulnerable to those effects.
That includes children and the elderly, who may be more susceptible, as well as workers who frequently labor in the sun and families without air conditioning or access to green spaces.
"In many areas that are low wealth, those communities may not have trees," said Sacoby Wilson, an environmental health scientist at the Univeristy of Maryland, College Park. "Those committees may have older buildings, so they may not have air conditioning, and those communities may have a lot of concrete, a lot of asphalt."
Both materials absorb then release heat. Trees and other greenery bring area temperatures down. 
Unless top-polluting countries reverse course, heat waves are likely to become more frequent and intense.
"Those kinds of changes are ones that we kind of expected to happen and they have happened," Meehl said. "And they're going to continue to get worse as we go forward."
___
The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content.

description:
It’s easy to blame the other side. And for many Democrats, it’s obvious that Republicans are thwarting progress toward a more equal society.

But what happens when Republicans aren’t standing in the way?

In many states — including California, New York and Illinois — Democrats control all the levers of power. They run the government. They write the laws. And as we explore in the video above, they often aren’t living up to their values.

In key respects, many blue states are actually doing worse than red states. It is in the blue states where affordable housing is often hardest to find, there are some of the most acute disparities in education funding and economic inequality is increasing most quickly.

Instead of asking, “What’s the matter with Kansas?” Democrats need to spend more time pondering, “What’s the matter with California?”

Subscribe: http://bit.ly/U8Ys7n
More from The New York Times Video:  http://nytimes.com/video
----------
Whether it's reporting on conflicts abroad and political divisions at home, or covering the latest style trends and scientific developments, New York Times video journalists provide a revealing and unforgettable view of the world. It's all the news that's fit to watch.

Disturbing details continue to emerge from rapper Travis Scott's Astroworld music festival, which is now considered one of the deadliest concert tragedies in the United States. 

Eight people died after the crowd surged toward the stage during Scott's performance, including two victims aged 14 and 16 years old. But there are also reports that suggest Scott, despite his own efforts to stop the concert, continued to perform for 37 minutes after police and firefighters responded. 

Jennifer Johnson has the latest details on what may have triggered the panic.

description:
Drone footage released by the La Palma local government on Tuesday showed a lava stream from the Cumbre Vieja volcano reaching Los Guirres beach after falling from a cliff.

Los Guirres beach, in the town of Tazacorte, is between the delta of lava in the ocean and another stream that has stopped its way into the ocean.

Authorities said it was unclear whether the recent lava stream on the beach was going to create a new delta of lava or if it would join the existing one.

Local authorities said seismicity and the emission of sulphur dioxide from volcano are continuing their downward trend.

Lava has destroyed more than 2,000 properties on the island since the Cumbre Vieja volcano began erupting in mid-September and thousands more have fled their homes as a precaution, prompting the government last month to pledge 225 million euros in aid.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8258090/la-palma-volcano-lockdown-lava/

description:
Polish riot police reinforced Poland’s eastern border on Tuesday, a day after hundreds of migrants tried to storm across the razor-wire border fence from Belarus into the European Union. Thousands of migrants still remained camped out on the Belarusian side and Polish authorities feared the tense standoff could escalate.

Polish authorities were bracing for further clashes after some migrants used logs, spades and other implements on Monday to try to break down a border fence, escalating a months-long crisis that has prompted calls for tighter sanctions on Minsk.

Poland and other EU member states accuse Belarus of encouraging illegal migrants from the Middle East, Afghanistan and Africa to cross the border into the EU in revenge for sanctions already slapped on Minsk over human rights abuses.

"The Belarusian regime is attacking the Polish border, the EU, in an unparalleled manner," Polish President Andrzej Duda told a news conference in Warsaw.

Meanwhile, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko accused the Polish side of trying to intimidate Belarus by moving large military forces closer to the border.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8360546/poland-belarus-border-migrants-police/

description:
A kidnapped North Carolina teenager was rescued by police last week after signalling for help using a hand gesture she learned on TikTok. 

The 16-year-old used the hand signal, originally meant as a nonverbal cue to help victims of domestic abuse, to signal distress to a passing motorist. Created in 2020, the signal spread across social media as a way to alert others to trouble at home. 

As Caryn Lieberman reports, the driver recognized the symbol and alerted authorities in Kentucky, who were then able to rescue the teen. 

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8358147/teen-girl-escapes-kidnapping-hand-signal-tik-tok/

description:
Cleanup is underway in parts of Vancouver, British Columbia, on Sunday after a possible tornado touched down in the area on Saturday. 

Meteorologists with Environment Canada are still investigating to determine what caused the damage in parts of the community, toppling trees and power lines, and are warning another powerful storm is on its way. 

The agency says a tornado did touch down over the ocean near the airport, but there are still questions whether a funnel touched down on land. 

Kamil Karamali reports on the damage and why some people say it felt like they were in a movie.

Tens of thousands of Ethiopians rallied on Sunday to denounce the U.S. and other foreign nations and support Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's government amid the ongoing conflict in the northern part of the country.

Some demonstrators criticized the U.S., which is among the foreign powers calling for a ceasefire as the year-long conflict intensified amid rebel advances last weekend. Others railed against the call by the U.S. for the government and the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) to begin talks.

On Sunday, Global Affairs Canada said it was withdrawing family members of diplomats and non-essential staff from the country, and urging people to consider leaving the country if they can do so safely.

Ahmed's government has pledged to keep fighting, even as nine groups opposing the government formed an alliance this past Friday.

description:
Toxic foam covered parts of the Yamuna river flowing through India's capital of New Delhi on Tuesday, which according to a local activist, is mostly attributed to illegal dumping of industrial waste and untreated sewage water.

The influx of toxic foam comes as Hindu devotees bathe themselves in the Yamuna to mark the Chhath Puja, a religious festival to thank the Sun God for bestowing bounties of life on the earth. Women were seen bathing and praying amongst clouds of foam.

According to activist Varun Gulati, the denim industries, most of which are illegally set up in residential areas in the capital city are discharging more polluted water into sewage treatment plants than allowed and the violations continue unmonitored.

The New Delhi government's Water Supply Board blamed industrial waste and untreated pollutants from neighbouring Haryana and Uttar Pradesh states for the Yamuna's worsening pollution.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8352108/india-diwali-air-pollution/

description:
Following the Astroworld concert stampede, where a "crowd rush" left eight dead and hundreds of people injured, Houston lawyer Tony Buzbee addressed media on Monday about his clients' son, 21- year-old Axel Acosta, who died at the concert during rapper Travis Scott's performance. 

Buzbee revealed Acosta's cause of death, stating the young man died of compressive asphyxiation due to the weight of the crowd pushing, and he then collapsed due to cardiac arrest and was trampled on. "The air was literally slowly squeezed out of him," said the lawyer. 

He did not clarify if the cause of death was determined by an autopsy.

Buzbee added his firm will be filing a lawsuit on behalf of 35 plaintiffs — and that number is “growing” — following the tragedy. Parties getting sued involve the promoters of the festival, the security company and more.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8357701/travis-scott-drake-sued-astroworld-deaths/

description:
Four astronauts splashed down off the coast of Florida in a SpaceX capsule on Tuesday after a six-month stay aboard the International Space Station (ISS) and a day-long flight home. 

The Dragon vehicle, dubbed Endeavour, parachuted into the sea as planned following a fiery re-entry descent through Earth’s atmosphere. 

Eyewitness videos showed the capsule streaking across the night sky over New Orleans as it made its way back to Earth.

Applause was heard from the flight control centre as the four main parachutes inflated and it drifted down toward the Gulf of Mexico, slowing its speed to just 24 km per hour, before dropping into the sea. 

Comprising the crew were two NASA astronauts, mission commander Shane Kimbrough and pilot Megan McArthur, as well as Japanese astronaut Akihiko Hoshide and mission specialist Thomas Pesquet, a French engineer from the European Space Agency.

It was the third crew launched into orbit under NASA’s fledgling partnership with SpaceX, the rocket company formed in 2002 by billionaire Elon Musk.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca

description:
After undergoing a biopsy, British Columbia Premier John Horgan has confirmed the growth in his throat is cancerous. "My prognosis is good and I expect to make a full recovery. In the next couple of weeks I will need to start radiation treatment, which will conclude toward the end of December," said the 62-year-old in a statement. 

In 2008, Horgan was diagnosed with bladder cancer. He was later declared cancer-free after surgery and treatment. Keith Baldrey looks at the treatment ahead for Horgan and the critical message he is sending to the general public.

description:
A B.C. woman is reminding people to always keep an eye on their surroundings after a too-close-for-comfort wildlife encounter.

Melanie Porter was sitting in her back yard in Quesnel on Thursday browsing TikTok when she saw movement out of the corner of her eye.

What she thought at first was been a cat turned out, in fact, to be a bear.

"It was just so surreal. I'm not an outdoorsy kind of girl, never been around any bears," she said.

"It was just sheer panic, so I froze. It was like an adrenaline rush, holy Hannah what do I do."

As Porter froze, the bear approached her from the side. It then did something she said she'll never forget.

description:
Nearly two years since the U.S.-Canada border was closed because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the United States is preparing to reopen its land border to fully-vaccinated Canadian travellers. Ross Lord takes a look at the relief, the reluctance, and the red tape that remains on the eve of the reopening.

Meanwhile in the U.S., more disturbing details are emerging from rapper Travis Scott's Astroworld music festival, which is now considered one of the deadliest concert tragedies in that country. Eight people died after the crowd surged toward the stage during Scott's performance, including two victims aged 14 and 16 years old. Jennifer Johnson has the latest details on what may have triggered the panic.

In Iraq, security forces in Baghdad are on high alert after Prime Minister Mustafa Al-Kadhimi survived an assassination attempt at his own home. The attack involved the use of explosive-laden drones swooping into his house. Mike Drolet looks at the country's political upheavals that may have led to the attack.

According to a report published in 2018, Canada's health-care sector accounts for just under five per cent of the country's emissions. It's an amount that's not "massive," but still significant, according to Fiona Miller, a professor of health policy and director of the Centre for Sustainable Health Systems at the University of Toronto. So how could Canada's health-care system become greener? Jamie Mauracher has more.

Although multi-billionaires like Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos are seeing their fortunes rapidly expand, the ultra wealthy are often taxed in the United States at lower rates than the average person. As Jackson Proskow reports, the idea of a special wealth tax is now gaining momentum, and it's aimed at the country's richest people.

Back in Canada, the Indigenous population in Toronto continues to face disturbingly low levels of COVID-19 vaccinations. Almost half of that group over the age of 15 have not been fully-vaccinated. Kayla McLean looks into why.

And with Remembrance Day fast approaching, it now has special significance for one Winnipeg family, thanks to some diligent detective work in Calgary. As Gil Tucker shows us, it all starts with a chance discovery in the back of a thrift store.

description:
Grieving family and friends of 27-year-old Danish Baig hailed him as a hero as they laid the Texas resident to rest, just two days after he was killed during a stampede at rap star Travis Scott's Astroworld music festival in Houston.

Basil Mirza Baig, Danish's younger brother, vowed to seek justice as he remembered his brother, who he said died trying to protect his fiance from the crush of the crowd.

"Travis Scott's team, everybody who was associated with this should be held accountable for the lives that were lost today and the day of," He added.

At least two investigations and one civil lawsuit were underway into the deadly stampede that killed at least eight people and injured dozens.

description:
Edward Rogers' attempt to reshuffle the boardroom at Rogers Communications without shareholder approval is valid, a B.C. Supreme Court judge has ruled.  Paul Johnson explains the court's decision.

Are the kids alright? The concern for young Canadians, who now account for the majority of new COVID-19 cases in the country and aren't eligible for a vaccine. Abigail Bimman has the warnings ahead of flu season. 

Could antiviral drugs be the new weapon in the fight against COVID-19? Jamie Mauracher compares the different pills by Pfizer and Merck.

 Plus, the grim future facing Afghan families hiding from the Taliban in safe houses, now that money has run out to fund them. Jeff Semple reports.

Ottawa's pandemic benefits were meant to help Canadians, particularly seniors and other vulnerable people.

description:
Editor's Note: The name keys for Graham Webb and Daniel Blaikie were swapped in the story by David Akin at 17:46. Global News regrets this error. 

Sexual misconduct cases within the Canadian Armed Forces have festered and gone unpunished for years. Now, new Defence Minister Anita Anand says allegations of misconduct within the military should be handled by the civilian justice system. Abigail Bimman reports on Anand's plans to follow recommendations by retired Supreme Court justice Louise Arbour.

Backlash is mounting in Quebec and Ontario, where COVID-19 vaccine mandates for health-care workers have been ditched. The provinces believe the rules could result in staff shortages. But would health-care systems really be at risk? Eric Sorensen has a reality check.

Meanwhile, parts of Newfoundland and Labrador's health system are recovering after a crippling cyberattack cancelled thousands of medical appointments and critical procedures. Ross Lord explains why the crisis for the province's patients is not over yet and why the rest of the country should pay attention.

After undergoing a biopsy, British Columbia Premier John Horgan has confirmed the growth in his throat is cancerous. Keith Baldrey looks at the treatment ahead for Horgan and the critical message the 62-year-old is sending to the general public.

Also, Canada is now among at least 20 countries pledging to stop funding international fossil fuel projects, as world leaders continue to hash out action plans at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow, Scotland. But as Crystal Goomansingh reports, a few key countries are snubbing the goal.

And Ottawa's pandemic benefits were meant to help Canadians, particularly seniors and other vulnerable people. But as David Akin explains, that much-needed money has now dried up for some of the population.

description:
Three people were seriously injured in a knife attack on an express train between the southern German cities of Regensburg and Nuremberg on Saturday, police said.

A 27-year-old man of Syrian nationality had been taken into custody in relation to the incident, according to authorities.

“The background or motive for what happened today is still completely unclear. But our investigations are currently being conducted on suspicion of one or more attempted homicides," Oberpfalz police spokesperson Florian Beck said.

Officials said the attack happened in the district of Neumarkt and the train was stationary at Seubersdorf southeast of Regensburg. A Red Cross spokesperson said between 200 and 300 people were removed from the train and were being taken care of at a nearby location.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8355153/german-knife-attack-train/

description:
Security forces in Baghdad are on high alert, after Iraq's Prime Minister Mustafa Al-Kadhimi survived an assassination attempt at his own home on Sunday.

The attack involved the use of explosive-laden drones swooping into his house, with handout photos showing the damage, including smashed windows and doors blown off their hinges. Though Al-Kadhimi was unharmed, a number of his guards were injured. 

Canada is among the nations condemning the attack and calling for calm in that country. Mike Drolet looks at Iraq's political upheaval that may have led to the attack.

description:
At least five people have been killed after days of unexpectedly heavy rainfall pounded the southern India state of Tamil Nadu, state Disaster Management Minister K. K. S. S. R. Ramachandran said on Tuesday.

The victims were killed either by lightning or collapsed buildings, he said, while over 500 mud and thatch houses and four brick houses had also been destroyed so far.

Floods unleashed by days of heavy rain also killed 12 people in Sri Lanka, the disaster management agency said. In the town of Kurunagala, a girl died after a house was damaged by a landslide.

The meteorological department said it expects the rain to ease in the next two days but stressed people should remain vigilant, while Tamil Nadu has issued a red alert in Chennai until Thursday. Local weather authorities have predicted light to moderate rainfall and extremely heavy rainfall in isolated pockets.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca

description:
Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner gave remarks Saturday on the "mass casualty incident" that occurred during rapper Travis Scott's concert at the Astroworld festival in the city on Friday, saying eight people had died with the youngest victim being 14 years old.

He said in addition to the 14-year-old, one is 16, two are 21, two are 23, one is 27 and the eighth's age is unknown at this time.

The incident occurred, according to police, when fans attending the show appeared to surge towards the stage, triggering panic in the crowd of tens of thousands. Police said it started causing some injuries.

According to authorities, 25 people had been sent to hospital, with 13 still hospitalized, including five under the age of 18. Four people have been discharged.

Police Chief Troy Finner also spoke about rumours that had been circulating, asking people not to spread information that has not been provided by authorities.

description:
Scores of colourful hot air balloons filled the skyline of Turkey's ancient Cappadocia region on Sunday.

A timelapse video captured the balloons as they painted over the unique volcanic-rock landscapes. The clear blue sky led viewers to enjoy the scenery in one of the country's most popular tourist destinations.

Tens of hot air balloons, carrying tourists, take off every morning from Cappadocia to catch the sunrise over the famous fairy chimneys.

Watching the cone-shaped valley formations and historic cave dwellings from the sky make hot air ballooning a top attraction for visitors.

description:
Passengers at London Heathrow Airport were excited and relieved to be able to travel to the United States after the country ended its international travel ban and began allowing fully-vaccinated tourists on Monday.

In France, people were also excited to see their families for the first time since the travel restrictions were brought in 2020, when the pandemic hit.

From Monday, travellers who can show official proof of vaccination against COVID-19 and have had a recent, negative viral test can fly to the United States.

The U.S. announced in October the lifting of the travel ban, which has been in place for 18 months, for international travellers, including European citizens, who have both COVID-19 vaccine doses or who have a negative PCR test 72 hours before their departure.

description:
For the first time, Global Affairs Canada has revealed a full country-by-country list of where Canadians have been murdered abroad, with almost 200 reported as having been killed while travelling outside the country in the past five years.

Cases range from drug-related shootings to extortion kidnappings and the opportunist killings of innocent tourists drawn to the tropics, with more deaths having occurred in Mexico in the past five years than in any other country. 

As Sean Previl reports, Global News is the first to release the data, but Canada is still not providing more specifics like the exact towns and cities the deaths occurred in - and the information only comes after an access-to-information appeal to the Office of the Information Commissioner of Canada.

A joint task force investigating criminal activities that may have happened at one of Canada’s longest-running residential schools began the first phase of its search on Tuesday.

description:
The United States finally reopened its land border to non-essential travel on Monday for the first time in nearly two years. As Mike Le Couteur reports, pressure is growing on Ottawa to scrap its requirement for anyone entering Canada to present a negative PCR COVID-19 test.

Meanwhile, as MPs get back to work on Parliament Hill, there's talk of a potential deal between the Liberals and the NDP, so Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's minority government can stay in power. David Akin explains how Conservative Leader Erin O'Toole is slamming the idea and how O'Toole is facing criticism as well.

Also, with the deadline to join a class-action lawsuit against the Canadian Armed Forces over sexual misconduct fast approaching, the number of claimants is ballooning. As Abigail Bimman reports, people are still being urged to step forward.

Plus, the second and final week of the COP26 climate summit is underway in Glasgow, Scotland, where world leaders are hashing out the finer details of how new commitments will be met. But as Redmond Shannon reports, poorer countries are calling for more action on sharing the burden, as richer nations are blamed for the most emissions.

The supply chain shortage is frustrating customers and merchants around the world, with everything from cars to toys low in stock. So why are climate researchers glad to see the problem in the spotlight? Eric Sorensen explains why harmful emissions can start with our shopping habits.

And during the First World War, hundreds of Black Canadians eagerly signed up for duty. But the military rejected them because they weren't white, so they went on to form the only all-Black battalion in the history of the Canadian Armed Forces. Ross Lord explains this unit's critical role in the war and the long overdue apology coming from Ottawa.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8357912/covid-19-coronavirus-pcr-test-land-border-canada-us/

description:
NFT.NYC is showcasing more than 500 speakers ranging from Reddit co-founder, Alexis Ohanian to filmmaker, Quentin Tarantino at a series of in-person festivals in New York this week.

In midtown Manhattan is the Dreamverse NFT (Non-Fungible Token) Festival, featuring the work of more than 150 NFT artists, as curated by 10 NFT artists, TIME and crypto-exclusive fund, Metapurse.

Among the artists who are having their work featured include Jose N. Silva, who credits the pandemic for the rise of digital art and the rise of the NFT community.

"Everyone was at home... we didn't have a lot of in-person interaction... I think that's kind of like what catapulted this whole idea of the Metaverse, because a lot of people were meeting up, you know, daily on online forums," he said. "For all of that to culminate into an in-person thing where people can actually see the art... is a big moment in the space."

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca

title: NYC NFT: Dreamverse festival brings digital art to life

description:
At least eight people are dead and dozens of others were injured after fans attending the Astroworld music festival in Houston, Texas, on Friday rushed toward the stage.

Rapper Travis Scott, who founded the festival, was performing at the time. By the time he was able to stop the concert, more than 20 people had to be taken to hospital. Among the victims are a 14 year old and 16 year old. 

Houston police say they have opened a criminal investigation, with both their homicide and narcotics units involved.

Jennifer Johnson has the reaction from witnesses as investigators work to determine what led to the tragedy.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8355240/travis-scott-houston-show-death/

description:
Canada's economy added 31,000 jobs in October with the unemployment rate falling to 6.7 per cent, the fifth month in a row of improving joblessness in the country as the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic continue to decrease.

But employers in many industries say the labour market remains difficult, with finding new employees still difficult resulting in some having to cut back hours at a time when revenue remains desperately needed.

As Anne Gaviola explains, the issue appears to be revolving around the issue of "ghosting," in which job candidates are not showing up for interviews and in some cases, not even showing up for the job they were hired to do.

description:
The funeral for former U.S. Secretary of State Gen. Colin Powell was held Friday afternoon at the Washington National Cathedral.

President Joe Biden and first lady Jill Biden attended along with former presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama. Former secretary of states Hillary Clinton and Madeleine Albright also attended.

Powell’s family said the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff died due to complications from COVID-19.

Powell, who was the first Black secretary of state, was a mainstay in American politics for decades, and was named to senior posts by three Republican presidents and reached the top of the U.S. military during his career.

Powell served as U.S. national security adviser under then-president Ronald Reagan from 1987 to 1989. A four-star general, he chaired the Joint Chiefs of Staff under then-president George H.W. Bush during the 1991 Gulf War that saw U.S.-led forces expel Iraqi troops from neighbouring Kuwait.

A moderate Republican, Powell did consider a bid to become the first Black president in 1996, but his wife Alma’s worries about his safety steered him away. In 2008, he broke with his party to endorse Democrat Barack Obama, who became the first Black president in U.S. history.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8273451/colin-powell-dead-covid-19-complications/

As Abigail Bimman reports, people are still being urged to step forward.

description:

Gaige Grosskreutz, who was shot by Kyle Rittenhouse during the protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin on Aug. 25, 2020, said Monday during testimony that he thought the teenager was an "active shooter" and was trying to disarm him when a bullet from the teen's semi-automatic rifle struck him in the arm. 

Grosskreutz said at one point, he had drawn his Glock pistol but did not intend to use it, however at that time he told prosecutors he thought he "was going to die."

The testimony from Grosskreutz was seen as the only chance for lawyers from both sides to question a survivor from that night and get testimony on his mindset and actions, which could be crucial to determining whether Rittenhouse had reason to fear for his life, as he has maintained.

The supply chain shortage is frustrating customers and merchants around the world, with everything from cars to toys low in stock.  

But climate researchers say it's about time supply chains are in the economic spotlight, because so much of what the globalized economy produces contributes to greenhouse gases. 

From how materials are shipped, all the way to how products are manufactured and used, every link in the supply chains expands the carbon footprint and affects the climate. Eric Sorensen explains why harmful emissions can start with our shopping habits.

description:
An alliance of nine anti-government factions have formed an alliance aimed at dismantling Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's government, either “by force or by negotiations.”

Spokespersons for the alliance signed an agreement in Washington, D.C. on Friday, piling pressure on Ahmed as rebel forces advance toward the capital of Addis Ababa.

The alliance includes political, military and diplomatic cooperation and expands an existing agreement between the forces from the northern region of Tigray and the Oromo Liberation Army (OLA), one of the organizers told Reuters. 

The conflict in Ethiopia’s north started a year ago when forces loyal to the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) seized military bases in Tigray. In response, Ahmed sent troops to the northern region.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8349521/ethiopia-conflict-ceasefire-tigray/

description:
Scientific activist group Arctic Basecamp shipped a 4,000-kilogram iceberg from Greenland to melt at the COP26 climate change summit in Glasgow.

The founder of the group, Professor Gail Whiteman, said the move is to highlight the importance of Arctic ice to global weather systems to those negotiators trying to reach a deal to halt ever-warming temperatures in the meeting rooms nearby.

The Arctic is in crisis and that's not just bad news for the polar bear," Whiteman said. "That's bad news for countries and societies everywhere."

The group is also presenting the COP with what they call a "bottled warning", which is a bottle of clear melted ice water.

"70 million of these bottles a second are melting off the Greenland ice sheet, based on the research that's been done. And what else can we say? This is a bottled warning and they can't ignore this so that's why we've brought the iceberg and the water to Glasgow," Whiteman said about the bottle. 
 
For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8338716/cop26-summit-glasgow-2021-opens/

title: COP26: Iceberg weighing 4,000 kg shipped from Greenland to melt in Glasgow

The second and final week of the COP26 climate summit is underway in Glasgow, Scotland, as world leaders hash out the finer details on how new commitments will be met. 

Former U.S. President Barack Obama was also at the summit recently, pleading with other countries to try harder. "Most nations have failed to be as ambitious as they need to be," said Obama at the summit. "The escalation, the ratcheting up of ambition that we anticipated in Paris six years ago has not been uniformly realized."

description:
Ontario Premier Doug Ford discussed the construction of the Bradford Bypass on Monday, saying that his government is fully funding the construction of the new four-lane freeway that will connect Highway 400 and Highway 404.

Ford made the announcement in Bradford, Ont. alongside Ontario Transport Minister Caroline Mulroney and Ontario Finance Minister Peter Bethlenfalvy.

"This new bypass will help get people where they need to go much faster, and we also know it will help get goods to the market faster, Ford said, adding that the project would generate 700 jobs per on average year during construction, and that the highway would not be tolled.

Ford's government released a fall economic statement last week, that included boosting funding for the healthcare sector and building highways and roads.

description:
Projet Montreal’s Valérie Plante emerged victorious late Sunday night, winning a second term as mayor of Montreal in the Quebec municipal election.

Plante took an early lead straight out of the gate. By 9:30 p.m., her lead over main competitor, Ensemble Montréal’s Denis Coderre, had surpassed 11,000 votes — good enough for Global News to project her the winner.
 
Plante declared herself the night’s winner in a tweet around the same time, in which she thanked Montrealers.

She wasted no time making history again — also announcing that Dominique Ollivier would be the city’s executive committee chair, marking the first time two women lead the city.

Some of Plante’s campaign priorities included adding more social housing, fighting climate change and improving public security.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8353745/quebec-municipal-election-result-montreal-mayor/

description:
Speaking to reporters on Monday after the U.S. House passed President Joe Biden’s signature $1-trillion infrastructure bill over the weekend, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said the bill “sells itself,” adding that communities “never needed to be persuaded” to upgrade local infrastructure.

Buttigieg said his department has been “gearing up hoping this bill would pass” and said while some infrastructure projects could be implemented on a short timeframe, in other cases the administration would have to “stand up” entirely new projects to be implemented on a longer timeframe. 

Buttigieg also explained how changes spurred by the new bill would help the government ease supply chain issues, especially at U.S. ports.

description:
Three thousand and seventy-one unvaccinated health-care workers in B.C. remain on unpaid leave, officials revealed Tuesday.

Health Minister Adrian Dix said this number includes 1,032 casual staff, 989 full-time staff, 819 part-time staff and 16 people whose job status is unknown.

Breaking it down further, Dix said 28 are in emergency medicine, 105 in general medicine, 246 care aides and community assistants, 19 from internal medicine, 906 nurses, 86 paramedics and 10 resident doctors.

Meanwhile, B.C. is expecting a shipment of Johnson & Johnson vaccine soon, provincial health officer Dr. Bonnie Henry said.

Unvaccinated health workers will be offered this one-dose vaccine first, Henry said, because it might be a better option for people who are more vaccine-hesitant but want to keep working.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8361041/bc-live-covid-update-unvaccinated-health-care-workers/

description:
Children under 12 are now leading the country in new COVID-19 infections as they await approval for vaccination, Canada’s chief medical officer of health Dr. Theresa Tam said during a Friday news conference.

In new national data released Friday, Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) officials said that during the fourth wave, infections in that age group surpassed those of all other age groups for the first time in the pandemic.

The trend comes as vaccination increases in older age groups, while children under 12 await approval for a jab.

Officials added that the majority of cases among children do not involve severe illness. In fact, fewer than one per cent of children and youth up to 19 years of age with COVID-19 have been severely sick. To date, more than 350,000 cases have been reported in that age range.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8352439/children-covid-19-infections-canada-phac/
