description:
(9 Nov 2021) An historic First World War soldier's house in Belgium has been able to stay open despite the COVID-19 pandemic, amid a crowdsourcing campaign to help keep it running. 
Talbot House is an institution in so-called "remembrance tourism", a Western Front meeting house where Commonwealth soldiers gatheered to escape the battle in Flanders fields. 
For generations since, people found history, solace, wisdom and an understanding at Talbot House about why the motto of this region in western Belgium is "Never into war again." 
But for months last year, a COVID-19 lockdown closed the club.
Going from as many as 500 guests a day, Talbot House manager Simon Louagie sometimes found himself alone. 
But speaking to The Associated Press, Louagie said that when funds were running low and doors were closed, only one thought ran through his head: "Not on my watch." 
"We cannot disappoint all those generations before us by letting it close down," he said. 
Crowdfunding was the answer for Louagie. 
Last year, a 98-year-old World War II veteran raised money by walking from a war graves cemetery to Talbot House, cheered on by locals who pulled money out of their wallet when they were not applauding. When a local died, the family asked that instead of flowers, mourners donate money to Talbot House.
"It became very emotional when I saw how many people cared so deeply," Louagie said.
Since the end of World War I in 1918, millions of visitors - from as far away as the United States New Zealand, and South Africa - have flocked to memorials in northern France and Belgium to pay tribute to the fallen.
Now, closing in on two years of the pandemic and travel restrictions, the tourist industry welcoming them is crippled. Lockdowns and travel restrictions, of which many remain in place, are keeping foreign visitors away.  
Another Armistice Day beckons on November 11 and the outlook remains bleak. 
Nick Benoot, who runs the small Hooge Crater Museum not far from Poperinge could not believe it when at the end of 2019, schools started to cancel trips because of reports of a virus in Wuhan, China. 
Like Louagie, he had plunged money into the business to keep it going amid the pandemic, and needed any income he could get.
From 65,000 paying visitors in 2017 to just 3,000 last year, the numbers demonstrated how remembrance tourism slumped throughout the region. 
"It was like we went bankrupt. We had to close everything down," he said. 
Even as his income dwindled in the middle of the pandemic, Benoot understood that the message of "the war to end all wars" still needed to be passed on to younger generations. 
Now, as virus measures are being eased after Belgium's COVID-19 vaccination campaign, the managers of institutions like Louagie's and Benoot's are hoping they will see a return of the tourists. 
"We don't do what all the rest does. So I think we have a way to survive," Benoot said. 
Even the Last Post ceremony in nearby Ypres - a daily, mournful bugle call harking back to 1928 that had only briefly stopped during World War II - was at risk of being silenced. The tradition has the bugle playing under the Menin Gate where some 55,000 names of soldiers whose remains were never found are engraved.
Yet it pulled through. Volunteers refused to stop and pulled strings all the way up to the top political posts to ensure its continuation even if it had to be scaled down. 
"During COVID, there was only one bugler and the names of 55,000 soldiers," said Benoit Mottrie, the head of the Last Post Association.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) Hundreds gathered on Monday at a goldmine where 18 people died after a collapse in Niger's Dan Issa township. 
Authorities in Niger said the people were killed when the mine partially collapsed on Sunday in the region located in the south of the country, near the border with Nigeria. 
Governor of Maradi region Aboubacar Chaibou visited the site on Monday, telling The Associated Press that authorities were going to "review governor of Maradi region" in order to improve conditions.
Local authorities said that thousands have been arriving at the place to work on the recently discovered mine.
According to Mayor of Dan Issa Adamou Guero there have been difficulties in controlling and organizing the work at the site. 
Niger is one of the world's poorest countries, also affected by violence that has caused the internal displaced of thousands fleeing from extremist groups operating in the country.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
British defence company Ultra Electronics unveiled a working prototype of a mind-controlled drone at the Three Counties Defence and Security Expo (3CDSE) in Malvern, England, on 4 November.
All the pilot has to do is to focus their attention and eyes on specific circles on a computer screen.

STORY-LINE:
This drone takes off, spins and lands without a remote control.
The person sitting behind the laptop controls its movements by thought only.
This new technology was developed by Ultra Electronics, a British company working in the defence and security industry.
The drone and the brain sensor were already available on the market, so Ultra Electronics designed a software to make the two devices work together.
Although the laptop does have a webcam, it is not used to look at the user — the focus of the mind on the circles instructs the drone what to do via the brain sensor worn on the users head. 
"So what happens is that we create some icons, we call them tags, and they have like a signal within them," explains Tony White, CTO of land systems at Ultra Electronics.
"And when you stare at that, your eye responds to it in a particular way. The way in which the eye response occurs is a signal that we pick up on the visual cortex of the brain, at the back of the brain. So the sensor is looking for the signals we create here that come through the eyeball through the brain and then onto the visual cortex. Once we've got it there as a signal, we can grab that, we understand what that signal looks like and we can turn that into a command for whatever we're trying to control."
There are four circles on the computer screen in total: two big ones for take-off and landing, and two small ones for spinning left and right.
The advantage of this technology is to reduce the number of hand-held controllers for soldiers.
"So this device is all about providing control of other devices the soldier might carry. And when you think about what a soldier does, most of his time he wants his hands on a weapon. And each time I've got to take my hands off the weapon to do something, I may, may, be vulnerable. So by having this device, it allows him to be in control of things once he's still got his hands on the weapon," says White.
The prototype was designed in partnership with Neuro8, a neuroscience consultancy company founded by Ellen Kay.
She led trainings for Ultra Electronics employees and helped the drone project by helping the pilots focus.
"So what happens is, is that having gone through the training, the organisation had a much better understanding of the individual and how the brain and body communicate. And from a soldier's wellbeing and welfare that's just as important as them optimising their performance. So how this worked for us is that they developed the technology and I used all of the techniques that I've learnt through the training and through the coaching to use the technology to show how the human can improve their performance and reduce their cognitive burden, to use this technology better," explains Kay. 
The drone was demoed at the Three Counties Defence and Security Expo (3CDSE) in Malvern, England, on 4 November.
This mind controlling is an example of a brain-computer interface (BCI), meaning a technology that is able to understand the brain and translate what the user thinks into actions.
On stage and in front of an audience, the drone was also used by a person who had never used it before.
After a 2-minute calibration process, the new pilot was able to control the drone, make it take off and land on a table, and rotate it in the air.

description:
(6 Nov 2021) A second day of heavy floods in the surburbs of Sarajevo wrought more havoc on the Bosnian capital on Saturday, despite water levels decreasing. 
The Zeljeznica and Tilava rivers in southern Sarajevo burst their banks and flooded hundreds of homes in the area. 
Civil protection teams and local residents struggled to put up sand bag barriers.
On Friday, heavy rain caused severe flash flooding prompting evacuations, power outages and submerged roads.
z
Hundreds of homes in the Sarajevo suburbs, along the rivers Bosnia, Tilava and Zeljeznica, and in the southwest part of the country, around the town of Konjic, had to be evacuated under unrelenting heavy downpours.  
Rain started late on Thursday and forecasts say it will continue to fall until Sunday, raising fears of a repeat of record flooding that affected about a third of the population in 2014.
It followed days of unseasonably warm weather with temperatures over 20 degrees Celsius.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) Israeli President Isaac Herzog on Monday welcomed his Colombian counterpart Ivan Duque to begin a three-day visit to Israel.
Colombia is to open a trade office in Jerusalem, a move seen by Israel as support for its claim of sovereignty over the city. Colombia's embassy is in Tel Aviv.
Herzog hailed Colombia's accession to the Board of Governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency and urged the country to use its role in the world body to pressure Iran into giving up its nuclear program.
"I hope that this position will allow you to promote diplomatic efforts to fight the Iranian nuclear program," Herzog said.
Duque is to meet with Prime Minister Naftali Bennett during the day and will lay a wreath at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Remembrance Centre in Jerusalem.

description:
(7 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Art is not widely practised in culturally conservative Somalia, which has suffered decades of conflict.
In a country where women are still marginalised in many aspects of daily life, 21-year-old painter Sana Ashraf Sharif Muhsin is making an impact. 
She believes that through her paintings, she can help rebuild her country. 

STORY-LINE:
21-year-old painter Sana Ashraf Sharif Muhsin lives in Mogadishu, Somalia.
She wants to help her country - which has been ravaged by civil war on and off over decades - through her paintings.
Art in many countries still suffering a shadow war, is seen by dictatorial and violent regimes as an expression of dissent.
Artists are rare in Somalia, a once-taboo profession which managed to only just survive through conflicts and Islamic extremism.
Years of insecurity marked by devastating attacks by the al-Qaida-linked al-Shabab extremist group have plagued the country.
Sana Ashraf Sharif Muhsin has suffered more opposition than most.
She lives and works amid the rubble of her uncle's building that was partially destroyed in Mogadishu's years of war.
"As a Somali woman and artist I love my country and since we have passed through 30 years of destruction, and the people only see bad things, having in mind bloodied with destruction and explosions. I believe that I can change that through my arts to let them see something beautiful and build their morale," she says. 
Despite the challenges, that include the belief by some Muslims that Islam bars all representations of people, and the struggle to actually get hold of materials to produce the paintings, Sana is optimistic. 
"I love my work and believe that I can contribute to the rebuilding and pacifying of my country," she says.
Sana, a civil engineering student, began drawing at the age of 8, following in the footsteps of her maternal uncle, Abdikarim Osman Addow, a well-known artist.
She started off using charcoal on the walls of her house, then progressed to forming a sketchbook with depictions of household items like a shoe or a jug of water.
But as her work brought her more public attention over the years, some tensions followed.
"I fear for myself sometimes," she says, and recalled a confrontation during a recent exhibition at the City University of Mogadishu. 
A male student began shouting "This is wrong!" and professors tried to calm him, explaining that art is an important part of the world.
Many people in Somalia don't understand the arts, Sana says, and some even criticize them as disgusting. 
At exhibitions, she tries to make people understand that art is useful and "a weapon that can be used for many things."
A teacher once challenged her skills by asking questions and requiring answers in the form of a drawing, she says.
"Everything that's made is first drawn, and what we're making is not the dress but something that changes your internal emotions," Sana says. 
"Our paintings talk to the people."
Her work at times explores the social issues relevant to Somalia, including a painting of a soldier looking at the ruins of the country's first parliament building. 
It reflects the current political clash between the federal government and opposition, she says, as national elections are delayed. 
Another painting reflects abuses against vulnerable young women "which they cannot even express." 
A third shows a woman in the bare-shouldered dress popular in Somalia decades ago before a stricter interpretation of Islam took hold and scholars urged women to wear the hijab.
But finding role models at home for her profession doesn't come easily.

tags: 4351710, 963a6bdd09ef4a569a9c70cd7e5d2dab, AP Archive, Abdi Mohamed Shu'ayb, Arts and entertainment, East Africa, General news, HZ Somalia Female Artist, Mogadishu, Sana Ashraf Sharif Muhsin, Social affairs, Somalia
title: Female artist promotes images of peace in Somalia

description:
(8 Nov 2021) Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on Monday criticised the United States for calling into question the results of Nicaragua's presidential election.
In a statement released around the close of voting on Sunday, President Joe Biden called the election process “rigged” and said the US would use the tools at its disposal to hold the Nicaraguan government accountable.
"The White House announced its refusal to recognise it and called on other countries to do the same. We consider it unacceptable and firmly condemn such a policy," Lavrov told reporters at a joint press conference with his Venezuelan counterpart Felix Plasencia at the Russian Foreign Ministry.  
Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega sought a fourth consecutive term in elections Washington has called a "pantomime" following the jailing of his top rivals and the country's opposition has urged voters to boycott. 
  
Lavrov also said recent NATO drills in the Black Sea were about pursuing a policy of  "containment" towards Russia.
Moscow has repeatedly voiced concerns over the deployment of NATO forces near Russian borders, describing it as a threat to its security. 
Russia and the alliance also have continuously accused each other of dangerous and provocative manoeuvres at sea and in the air. 
Plasencia told reporters his country was thankful to Russia for its support during the coronavirus pandemic.
Venezuela ordered 10 million doses of the Russian-developed Sputnik V jab in December 2020. 
Sputnik V is not among the seven vaccines cleared by the World Health Organization in the fight against COVID-19.

description:
(7 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Led by their riders, horses performed to the beat of traditional Egyptian songs at a dressage competition in Giza. 
In dressage, human rider and horse perform a series of movements at different paces - a walk, trot and canter - set to music to demonstrate their artistic and technical prowess.

STORY-LINE:
To the sound of music and applause from cheering fans, horses regaled a crowd in Egypt with dressage performances on Friday.  
With their riders leading the way, the horses trotted along, harmonizing their moves with the rhythm of the songs blasting in the background. 
The performances were part of the third edition of Egypt's International Championship for Horse Taming.  
With each move calculated and carefully rehearsed, the performances showed the horses' flexibility and their riders' mastery. 
The Egyptian version of dressage is regularly featured as a form of entertainment in rural weddings and other gatherings. 
The horses have to be at least three years old before they can learn dressage moves. 
They also have to have the right muscular build and spirit, says Mohamed Akl, the manager of the venue where the contest was hosted. 
There were around 45 Arabian horses performing in the show including 30 registered horses.  
A jury judged the performances and gave each participant a score, before winners were announced. 
The first place winner for the registered horses won a prize worth 50,000 Egyptian pounds ($3,180), while the prize for the unregistered horse was worth 25,000 pounds (around $1,590). 
As part of their training, horses first learn how to perform dressage moves on their own. 
Afterwards, they learn how to carry out the steps prompted by their riders.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) The European Commission on Tuesday estimated about 2,000 migrants were stuck at the border between Poland and Belarus amid a tense standoff.
Spokesperson Dana Spinant said European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen urged Belarus to stop the "instrumentalization of migrants for political purposes", saying they have been encouraged to go to the EU's eastern frontier.
Von der Leyen also asked EU member states to approve extended sanctions against Belarusian authorities.
Polish riot police reinforced the border at Kuznica on Tuesday, a day after hundreds of migrants tried to storm across the razor-wire border fence.

description:
(6 Nov 2021) European Union officials on Friday continued their observation as Venezuela's election campaigns got underway.
The EU observer mission was in Venezuela at the invitation of the government, and the urging of the opposition.
The team of 44 observers, that arrived in Venezuela on October 24, was deployed throughout the country to examine the electoral process from the campaigning to the November 21 election day.
On Friday they observed a 68-year-old voter trying out a new electoral machine that was installed at a public square in Los Teques city in Miranda state –36 kilometers (22 miles) east of Caracas. 
Noris García said the observers were welcome in Venezuela, as she tried out the machine.
"It is good that they are here and that they bring the truth about Venezuela to the world so that it is not misrepresented."
Xabier Meilan, the Deputy Chief Observer of the EU Election Observation Mission, said the officials were not in Venezuela for the purpose of "legitimizing or delegitimizing (the government)."
The EU, which did not recognize the country's legislative elections last year, has not sent observers to a Venezuelan election since 2006.
"We understand that if after 15 years (of not coming to Venezuela to observe an election) we are here (again), they have called us to come back, it must be for a reason," said Meilan.
The European mission will carry out an independent, technical evaluation of the entire electoral process and will make recommendations for future elections, he said.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto and his visiting Latvian counterpart on Monday discussed the increasing pressure of illegal migration on the external borders of the European Union.
Latvia's Edgars Rinkevics was in the Hungarian capital to mark the 100th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the two countries. 
"There has never been a situation like this in Europe in terms of migration," said Szijjarto.
"Our continent is under direct pressure from three directions: on the southern Mediterranean sea route, on the south-eastern western Balkan land route and from the eastern direction."
Since the summer, Poland and Lithuania have faced the pressure of migrants from the Middle East and Africa trying to cross into the EU. 
Poland has sought to block the attempts or send those they catch back into Belarus. 
Warsaw and the EU say it’s an organized action by the Belarusian government aimed at destabilizing the bloc in retaliation for Western sanctions.
Poland on Monday increased security at its border with Belarus, on the European Union’s eastern border, after a large group of migrants in Belarus appeared to be congregating by the frontier, seeking to try to force their way into Poland, officials said.
Rinkevics said migration was being used as a "hybrid weapon to attack the borders of the European Union", notably on the Latvian, Lithuanian and Polish borders with Belarus. 
Szijjarto and Rinkevics called on the EU to provide financial assistance to member states in their efforts to protect the border.

description:
(10 Nov 2021) The Pentagon says it is closely watching "unusual military activity," including a buildup of troops, inside Russia, near Ukraine's borders.
"It's unusual in its size and scope," said spokesman John Kirby in a briefing Wednesday with reporters, adding, "We remain concerned about that."
Ukraine's Defense Ministry said last Wednesday that about 90,000 Russian troops are stationed not far from the border and in rebel-controlled areas in Ukraine's east. 
Russia has cast its weight behind a separatist insurgency in Ukraine's east that erupted shortly after Moscow's 2014 annexation of Ukraine's Crimean Peninsula and has left more than 14,000 people dead. Russia has repeatedly denied any presence of its troops in eastern Ukraine.
Earlier this year, a massive buildup of Russian troops in the Russia's west raised concern in Ukraine and in the West, fueling fears of an escalation of large-scale hostilities.
Russian officials said the troops were deployed for maneuvers, casting them as part of measures to counter security threats posed by the deployment of NATO forces near Russian borders. Russia and the alliance also have blamed each other for conducting destabilizing military exercises near the borders.
Kirby said the U.S. urges Russia "to be transparent with the international community about what this means, what they're doing and to respect the international community's will about Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity."

description:
(10 Nov 2021) STORYLINE: 
A top Taliban official on Wednesday urged former Afghan military pilots to remain in the country, saying they were protected by a national amnesty and would not face arrest.
The comments by chief government spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid came amid reports that more than 140 U.S.-trained Afghan pilots and crew members left Tajikistan in a U.S.-brokered evacuation Tuesday, three months after they sought refuge there from a Taliban takeover of Afghanistan. The Associated Press could not immediately confirm the reports independently.
Afghan air force pilots played a key role, alongside their U.S. counterparts, in the 20-year war against Taliban insurgents that ended with the departure of foreign troops in late August. 
The airstrikes inflicted heavy casualties among the Taliban and repeatedly drove them from positions they had seized in different parts of the country.
As the U.S.-backed Afghan government collapsed and the Taliban took over in mid-August, dozens of Afghan pilots fled to Central Asian countries, including Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. 
It's not clear how many military pilots and crew members remain in Afghanistan, what level of risk they face or to what extent Taliban assurances can be trusted. 
Over the past three months, there have been some reports of revenge killings by the Taliban, but not on a large, organized scale.
In a news conference Wednesday, Mujahid was asked about the most recent evacuation of pilots and crew members who, according to The New York Times, were flown to the United Arab Emirates. 
The military personnel had reportedly been in detention during their stay in Tajikistan.
Mujahid said Afghanistan needs pilots and that all is forgiven.
"My message is, there is no security problem for them (Afghan pilots) in Afghanistan, there is no plan of arresting them, national amnesty is announced," he said. 
He said the pilots, whether in the military or in civil aviation, "can be at the service of their country." 
"It is regrettable that a number of pilots have gone, or they are going," he added.
Separately, a spokesman for the Taliban intelligence service told the news conference that the agency has arrested close to 600 members of the militant Islamic State group in connection with violent attacks over the past three months.
The spokesman, Khalil Hamraz, said that among the detainees are key IS figures, including financial supporters.
At least 33 IS members have been killed in gunbattles with Taliban security forces, he said. 
He said several cars rigged with explosives and suicide vests were seized before they could be detonated.
Islamic State is an enemy of the Taliban. The two groups share a hard-line interpretation of Islam and over the years engaged in some of the same violent tactics, such as suicide bombings. 
However, the Taliban have focused on seizing control of Afghanistan, while IS adheres to global jihad.
In recent weeks, IS militants carried out a series of bombing and shooting attacks, trying to undercut a claim by the Taliban that they could restore security in Afghanistan.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive

description:
(10 Sep 2003) 

1. Wide exterior of Denpasar court  
2. Close up policeman 
3. Police standing in front of court
4. Police manning barricade 
5. Various people having bags checked 
6. Policeman going through suitcase, opening bags
7. Man being screened 
8. Wide of courtroom as judges enter and sit 
9. Defendant Imam Samudra escorted into courtroom, sits on chair.
10. UPSOUND (Bahasa Indonesia) Samudra shouting "God is Great"  
10. Wide of court in session

STORYLINE:

An Islamic militant accused of masterminding last year's deadly nightclub bombings on Bali island entered a court on Wednesday to hear the final verdict in his trial.

Imam Samudra, an Afghan-trained fighter who has said he wants to die as a martyr, raised his fist defiantly as he entered the courtroom, crying "God is Great" four times.

The five-judge panel was expected to take several hours to read out the charges, witness statements and defence responses before giving its final verdict.

Samudra faces a possible death sentence under tough anti-terrorism laws passed after the October 12 nightclub attacks, which killed 202 people, mostly foreign tourists.

Prosecutors say Samudra, 33, commanded the group that carried out the attacks. He selected the recruits and helped fund the attacks, they say. 

Last month, his co-conspirator Amrozi bin Nurhasyim was sentenced to death for his role in the bombings. 

He was the first of more than 30 defendants arrested in the case to face justice.

A handful of foreign observers watched the court proceedings, including friends and relatives of victims caught in the twin blasts.

Security around the Denpasar courtroom was stepped up.

The Bali attack is blamed on Al-Qaida-linked Jemaah Islamiyah network said to operate throughout Southeast Asia. 

The network's commander, Riduan Isamuddin Hambali, was captured last month in Thailand and handed over to
U.S. custody.

(7 Nov 2021) West African leaders gathered Sunday for a summit in Ghana's capital, Accra. 
The leaders - members of the ECOWAS bloc - met to discuss political unrest in several countries in the region.
Opening the gathering, Ghana President Nana Akufo-Addo expressed sympathy with Niger and Sierra Leone following events of the past week.
Niger saw 68 people lose their lives during an attack by a jihadist group, while around 100 people died in Sierra Leone when an oil tanker exploded.
They also discussed September's coup in Guinea, and the military takeover in Mali over a year ago.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4352207

Four astronauts returned to Earth on Monday, riding home with SpaceX to end a 200-day space station mission that began last spring.
  
Their capsule parachuted into the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Pensacola, Florida, in darkness. Recovery boats quickly moved in with spotlights. 
  
Their homecoming - coming just eight hours after leaving the International Space Station - paved the way for SpaceX's launch of their four replacements as early as Wednesday night. 
  
The newcomers were scheduled to launch first, but NASA switched the order because of bad weather and an astronaut's undisclosed medical condition. The welcoming duties will now fall to the lone American and two Russians left behind at the space station.
  
Before Monday afternoon’s undocking, German astronaut Matthias Maurer, who’s waiting to launch at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center, tweeted it was a shame the two crews wouldn’t overlap at the space station but “we trust you’ll leave everything nice and tidy.” His will be SpaceX's fourth crew flight for NASA in just one-and-a-half years.
  
NASA astronauts Shane Kimbrough and Megan McArthur, Japan's Akihiko Hoshide and France's Thomas Pesquet should have been back Monday morning, but high wind in the recovery zone delayed their return.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
A Polish veterinary student is using his entire university scholarship to develop a method for printing 3D, individually-fitted prostheses for lame dogs.
His first patient is 4-year-old Sonia, who was disabled in an accident at just eight months old.

STORY-LINE:
As a puppy Sonia was hit by a truck and lost part of her right hind leg.
Ever since she has been learning to walk with just three limbs, but it's affecting her posture and her owner Karolina Popecka is concerned for her future welfare.
Popecka and her dog are now looking forward to the future because Sonia is to be fitted with her new prosthesis.
She says: "I'm counting on her being able to walk in this prosthesis because I would like her to take some of the weight off her hind leg. I can see she gets tired sometimes. She's not like regular dogs, she will not jump on the bed or run faster after a duck, right?"
The asymmetry left by her accident is having negative effects on Sonia's body.
"The prosthesis is needed to help her hips work the right way, because I can already see that the right leg, the one that's missing, goes down very much and the hip is also shifting right, too.  And this is not healthy for the dog, because when she gets older, her joints can simply fail," says Popecka.
Sonia is getting her new prosthesis thanks to this veterinary student in in Wroclaw.
Maciej Szczepanski is making individually fitted 3D printed prostheses for dogs in the same predicament as Sonia.
He believes the unequal distribution of weight on three legs of a dog causes the limbless joint to atrophy and people are wrong to believe animals can live normally despite losing a limb.
"Yes, there is this opinion that dogs can cope very well on three legs and they do manage, because, in fact, they have to manage somehow. But, in fact, there are many cases of degeneration if a dog distributes its weight on only three limbs and not on four, as it should be. So degeneration of joints occurs, restructuring of the muscles atrophy of muscles in the unused limb.  So the whole animal suffers," says Szczepanski.
He believes his devices are better suited for the needs of individual animals and, at up to 3,000 zlotys ($750) they are much cheaper than traditional endoprostheses which are attached surgically.
After making a mould of the dog's stump, Szczepanski takes a digital scan of it at his university's digitization centre. 
At home he has a 3D printer he uses to make the leg.
"My prostheses are, first of all, created individually for a specific animal, that's what makes them so good. Because they respond to the needs of a specific animal. They perfectly fit the stump, they are perfect in terms of size and their height is also adjustable, which is definitely a big advantage," says Szczepanski.
According to the student: "(3D prostheses) are cheaper than endoprostheses, for example, due to the fact that this printing process is a relatively cheap method, it is also quite widely available and can be made quickly."
Eventually he hopes to set up a business making the prostheses.
The lockdown during the pandemic gave him the time and opportunity to work out the smallest details of the process.
According to Szczepanski although the 3D printer method is used in other countries, it is still relatively new in Poland where he is based.
Sonia is getting a fitting with her prosthesis today, there's no knowing how long it will take before she is able to walk normally again, but Popecka is hopeful.

title: Student 3D prints legs for limbless dogs

description:
(7 Nov 2021) The Taliban-run Afghan public health ministry has announced the start of a four-day nationwide polio vaccination campaign aimed at inoculating children under the age of 5.
For the past three years before taking control of Afghanistan, the Taliban had barred U.N.-organized vaccination teams from doing door-to-door campaigns in parts of the country under their control. 
The group apparently was suspicious the team members could be spies for the previous government or the West. 
Because of the ban and ongoing fighting, some 3.3 million children over the past three years have not been vaccinated. 
The Taliban's reported agreement now, after becoming the rulers of Afghanistan, appeared aimed at showing they are willing to cooperate with international agencies to re-open the door for international aid to rescue the crumbling economy
The Taliban made the announcement Sunday and the program begins Monday.

description:
(7 Nov 2021) US and Mexican parishes from the border city of Juarez on Saturday celebrated a mass for migrants who died attempting to cross the desert that separates the two countries. 
The mass was held as part of the Day of the Dead celebrations at El Punto, a shrine for migrants valued by locals as the point where Pope Francis paid tribute to those migrants. 
As many as 557 migrants have died so far this year on the border, according to human rights organizations. 
Marco Raposo, Minister of the Diocese of El Paso, Texas, said US policies contributed to the deaths as they pushed migrants away from cities and into the desert. 
In the religious tribute, an altar to the dead was set up, where photographs and belongings of migrants were placed. 
The mass was attended by a large number of migrants who now reside in Ciudad Juarez.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) nlike many of her European colleagues, Leonore Gewessler arrived Monday for this year's U.N. climate conference with a clean conscience.
Austria's environment minister and her entourage alighted at Glasgow Central Station having crossed half the continent in the time it takes some VIPs to circle the globe
"Wherever possible I try to choose the climate friendly option," said Gewessler.
Since taking office last year, the Green Party politician has pushed to revive Europe's once-extensive night train network, which has suffered heavy cuts due to competition from low-budget airlines.
Gewessler said she stopped over in Brussels to meet other European officials and used her 2,000-kilometer (1,240-mile) journey to prepare for the climate talks that are reaching their final phase this week.
"Trains and night trains are the future of short- and medium-distance travel in Europe," she said.
Gewessler also recently launched a nationwide 'climate ticket' that allows Austrians to travel the length and breadth of the Alpine nation on any form of public transport for 1,095 euros ($1,269) a year - or 3 euros ($3.50) a day.
Almost 130,000 people have bought a climate ticket in the last few weeks, beating the government's best expectations, she said.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) Former US president Barack Obama has held talks with emerging climate youth leaders on the sidelines of the COP26 climate talks in Glasgow. 
Obama met with 15 people from around the global, may of them alumni of the Obama Foundation's program to support emerging leaders.
During the meeting, Obama encouraged young people to engage in politics despite their frustrations. 
"There are times where people get frustrated and their conclusion is, well, we're just going to opt out of politics or work around politics," he said, but warning "you can't."
Last Friday, Greta Thunberg branded the U.N. climate talks in Glasgow so far "a failure," accusing leaders of actively creating loopholes in the rules and greenwashing their countries' emissions.
Speaking at a rally outside the conference venue, Thunberg called for tougher rules to clamp down on polluters instead of what she termed "distant, non-binding pledges."

description:
(9 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4352365

Now that eccentric real estate heir Robert Durst has been indicted for murder in the death of his first wife, who vanished nearly four decades ago, her family has some questions. Namely, what took so long?
Kathie Durst's brother, James McCormack, and a lawyer for her family held a press conference Tuesday to urge the suburban New York prosecutor who secured Durst's indictment to also investigate why he wasn't charged sooner.
In their first public comments since Durst's Nov. 1 indictment, McCormack and lawyer Robert Abrams outlined their concerns with the drawn-out criminal probe, including whether evidence was ignored and whether Durst's family wealth was an influence.
"Why did a series of district attorneys in Manhattan and Westchester County appear to decide to protect Robert Durst all of these years?," McCormack said. Why did former DA Jeanine Pirro commence an investigation only to abandon it at the last minute?"
In a letter Monday, Abrams requested that Westchester County District Attorney Mimi Rocah to "acknowledge and correct the mistakes made by your predecessors" and asked her to launch an investigation into what he said was an effort by Robert Durst's family and allies to hide Kathie Durst's killing.
Durst was indicted for Kathie Durst's death just weeks after he was sentenced in California to life in prison for killing a confidante who helped him cover up the slaying. Durst was hospitalized on a ventilator with COVID-19 after the Oct. 14 sentencing and has since been transferred to a state prison hospital.
Abrams said he would start releasing information next month that he said would expose people involved in the coverup. He accused former Westchester County District Attorney Jeanine Pirro, of punting the investigation after a private meeting with Robert Durst's brother, Douglas, in 2003.
Rocah's spokesperson declined comment.
A message for Pirro seeking comment was left with Fox News, where she hosts a weekly program, "Justice with Judge Jeanine."

2-نساء نازحات مع أطفالهن
3-لقطات متنوعة لمحمد شوي، نازح مؤخرا من مخيم روضة جهم ينصب خيمة
4-مقتطف صوتي (بالعربية) محمد شوي، نازح يمني
5-خيام نصبت حديثا وأخشاب
6-نازح يسير بعصا
7-لقطات متنوعة لأمتعة جلبها نازحون
8-مقتطف صوتي (بالعربية) محسن السوري، رئيس مخيم الطوارئ في مديرية الوادي بمحافظة مأرب
9-أطفال يدخلون مخيما
10-سيارة تسير مع حشى فوقها
11-لقطات متنوعة لنازحين وصلوا مؤخرا
المقدمة:
فر آلاف اليمنيين وسط تجدد القتال بين المتمردين الحوثيين والقوات الموالية للحكومة المعترف بها دوليا في اليمن.
القصة:
استمر اليمنيون في الفرار من القتال قرب مدينة مأرب بين المتمردين الحوثيين والقوات الموالية للحكومة اليمنية المعترف بها دوليا.
نحو 3 آلاف أسرة أو ما يصل إلى 17 ألف فرد فروا من مخيم روضة جهم قرب سد مأرب ووصلوا إلى مخيم أقيم حديثا في مديرية الوادي في مأرب، وفقا لأحد مسؤولي المخيمات.
فر الكثيرون أكثر من مرة، وسافروا لمسافات طويلة مع أمتعتهم.
مقتطف صوتي (بالعربية) محمد شوي، نازح يمني.
مقتطف صوتي (بالعربية) محسن السوري، رئيس مخيم الطوارئ في مديرية الوادي بمحافظة مأرب.
الأسبوع الماضي، قال مسؤولو أمن إن 200 مقاتل على الأقل قتلوا في اشتباكات بين قوات الحكومة اليمنية والحوثيين في محافظة مأرب الاستراتيجية وما حولها خلال يومين.
معظم الضحايا في صفوف الحوثيين الذين طردوا مؤخرا من معظم مديريات مأرب الأربعة عشر، وفقا لمسؤولين اشترطوا كتمان هوياتهم لأنهم غير مخولين بإبلاغ وسائل الإعلام.
حاول الحوثيون لسنوات السيطرة على مأرب الغنية بالنفط لاستكمال اجتياحهم للشطر الشمالي من اليمن.
وصعد الحوثيون هجماتهم على المحافظة خلال الأسابيع الأخيرة، بينما زادوا الهجمات عبر الحدود على السعودية.
تقود المملكة تحالفا عسكريا يقاتل في صفوف الحكومة ضد الحوثيين منذ 2015.
ويشهد اليمن حربا أهلية منذ 2014 بعد اجتياح الحوثيين صنعاء العاصمة ومعظم شمال البلاد، ما أجبر الحكومة على الفرار إلى الجنوب ومنه إلى السعودية.
بالرغم من حملة جوية لا تهدأ وقتال على الأرض، وصلت الحرب إلى مرحلة جمود وخلقت أسوأ أزمة إنسانية في العالم.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya called on the European Union to be consistent in putting pressure on Lukashenko's regime, as tensions rise in migrant standoff at Poland-Belarus border.
During a three-day visit to Berlin she said: "I want to only remind that we shouldn't look at migration crisis separately from the political crisis in Belarus because migration crisis is symptoms of the illness, core of the problem, and we don't have to shift the focus from human rights abuses in Belarus to the migration crisis because we understand that we may solve the migration crisis, you know, somehow, but without changing the regime we will not solve the whole problem."
Poland reinforced its border with Belarus with more riot police on Tuesday, a day after groups of migrants tried to storm through a razor-wire fence on the eastern frontier where thousands have camped on the Belarusian side in the tense standoff.
The European Union accuses Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko of using the migrants as pawns in a "hybrid attack" against the bloc in retaliation for imposing sanctions on the authoritarian government for a brutal internal crackdown on dissent.
Thousands were jailed and beaten following months of protests after Lukashenko won a sixth term in a 2020 election that the opposition and the West saw as rigged.

description:
(6 Nov 2021) Hundreds of protesters rallied outside a prison in Georgia on Saturday in support of jailed former president Mikheil Saakashvili.
They demanded that Saakashvili, who's on hunger strike, be transferred to a private clinic because he's getting weaker. 
The former president was jailed at the start of October on his return to Georgia, having been convicted in absentia of charges relating to abuses of power. 
While outside the country, he had been working to bolster opposition forces ahead of nationwide municipal elections.
Supporters contend that Saakashvili's health has seriously deteriorated while in prison.
But Georgian authorities say that his vital signs are normal, and that he's been consuming cereal and fruit juice. 
During Saturday's protest, opposition politician Khatia Dekanoidze - a former education minister - accused the government of violating Saakashvili's human rights by keeping him in the prison's medical wing.
Saakashvili's supporters have erected tents in front of the jail where he's being held, and have said they won't leave until he's been moved to a private hospital.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) LEAD IN :
Music, food, and bazaars filled with arts and crafts from across Pakistan have been showcased at the country's biggest festival called "Lok Mela".
The event celebrates the diverse traditions and crafts of the country.

STORY-LINE:
Traditional sounds flow through Islamabad's Folk Festival of Pakistan. 
There's a wealth of talent on display, from folk music performers to artisan craftsmen. They've come here from almost every corner of the country.
Locally the event is popularly known as "Lok Mela."
Newlywed Ameer Taimor who is here with his wife.
"I got a nice chance to visit this festival and saw the whole of Pakistan in one place. We visited all the pavilions, we especially enjoyed seeing the folk dances over here," he says. 
The annual event aims to promote and preserve the arts, crafts, culture, folk music and traditional skills of Pakistan.
There are pavilions representing all the country's provinces. They celebrate the unique cultural aspects of each region.
Lal Bukhsh along with his wife and daughter are netting thread into traditional Charkah and making shawls, lungi (a type of sarong) and bedsheets. 
"Our profession is 200 years old, our ancestors' profession. Now I am teaching my children, so it is our job. I am thankful to Allah that people like our products," Bukhsh says.
Traditional mouth-watering Pakistani cuisines are available at stalls installed throughout the venue.
Foreigners and diplomats are also seen at the festival including Saudi Arabian and Palestinian envoys and USA diplomats.
One Turkish visitor, Handen Simseak, says:
"The food is very nice. I bought paintings, very nice art work, very nice paintings, Mashallah, very nice festival."
The Annual festival is organised by the National Institute of Folk and Traditional Heritage (Lok Virsa).
The aim is to promote different musicians, artists and artisans and show off their talents.
Organisers say artists are too often neglected and their skills are not appreciated as much as other workers.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) More than 20 children were killed and dozens injured when a fire broke out in a school in Niger's second largest city on Monday morning, according to authorities in Maradi.
Three school classrooms made with straw were consumed by the fire, killing children aged between three and eight, local media reported. 
The cause of the fire and where it started was not immediately known and an investigation was launched, the Regional Direction of National Education confirmed. 
Straw huts are often used to make room for students in overcrowded schools in Niger.
In April, a fire fueled by high winds swept through an elementary school on the outskirts of Niger's capital, Niamey, killing 20 children. 
Since then, teachers and parents said that the deaths highlight the dangers of temporary classrooms set up outside.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) Vaccinators knocked on doors in Kabul on Monday to administer the polio vaccine to children under the age of five.
The Taliban-run Afghan public health ministry announced Sunday the start of a four-day campaign across Afghanistan aimed at inoculating young children. 
For the past three years before taking control of the country, the Taliban had barred UN-organized vaccination teams from going door-to-door in parts of the country under their control. 
Because of the ban and ongoing fighting, some 3.3 million children had missed out on a polio vaccine over the last three years.
Afghanistan and neighboring Pakistan are the only countries in the world where the disease remains endemic.

description:
(9 Sep 2003) 
1. Samudra, handcuffed, being escorted by police 
2. Journalists shout out questions including one asking him if he has a message for Australia 
3. UPSOT: (English) Samudra
"Australia go to hell, and Jews, and (inaudible) go to hell. Islam will win, Islam will win." 
4. Police surround him as he is taken inside 
5. Media outside 
6. Soldiers 
7. Samudra is brought out and hurriedly put into back of van by police as media shove and push them
8. Police van drives off 

STORYLINE:

On the eve of his sentencing,  the alleged Bali bombing mastermind, Imam Samudra declared that Australia and Jews could 'go to hell.'

Shouting out at journalists as he was escorted by police, he also said that Islam would win.

Samudra is due to be sentenced on Wednesday . 

Imam Samudra is accused in connection with the nightclub bombing on the island with killed 202 people, mostly foreign tourists, on 12 October last year.

The 33-year-old computer expert has already admitted to taking part in the blasts, but the state prosecutor claims Samudra was the planner of the attacks.

Indonesian state prosecutors on Monday demanded the death penalty for Samudra.

description:
(6 Nov 2021) The once crystal-clear waters of River Katari, which springs from the glaciers in the Andes, are now a source of pollution and problems for the Aymara Indigenous communities and local authorities in the Bolivian town of Pucarani. 
A recent cleaning campaign involving soldiers and Indigenous farmers from the surrounding communities fell short of clearing the river of plastic waste, just one part of the pollutants. 
The task proved to be bigger than expected. 
Juan Carlos Lopez, the Environmental and Water Secretary of Pucarani Municipality said the water of River Katari was "practically acidic."
"It's practically non-drinkable. From what we've seen, the mercury is high, and it also contains a lot of sediment."
According to municipal authorities, the native vegetation that once filled the area and served as forage for their livestock has long been depleted by pollution. 
Indigenous farmers from the area have expressed their concerns over the situation and are demanding the government to act to stop the pollution.
On Friday, Mauricio Flores, one of the Indigenous farmers with communal access to the lands, described his fears for their livestock and crops.
"We are asking for it (pollution) to stop. We want clear water," said Flores.
Josue Gonzales, an expert in water management with the Bolivian Ministry of Environment, said pollutants enter the river as its multiple branches cross through various municipalities, with industries and huge populations. 
Gonzales said over a million people live and deliver waste to the river. 
The water of the Katari River with all the waste and pollutants ends up in Lake Titicaca, shared by Bolivia and Peru.  
In 2015 Bolivia lost its second-largest lake, the Poopó, to an extended drought.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) UK PUBLISHER BEGINS APPEAL OVER MEGHAN PRIVACY LAWSUIT
A British newspaper publisher on Tuesday (9 NOVEMBER 2021) began its court appeal against a judge's ruling that it invaded the privacy of the Duchess of Sussex by publishing parts of a letter she wrote to her estranged father, arguing that she knew the letter would potentially be published. 
Publisher Associated Newspapers is fighting back against Meghan Markle, 40, who sued it for invasion of privacy and copyright infringement over five February 2019 articles in the Mail on Sunday and on the MailOnline website that reproduced large portions of a letter she wrote to her father, Thomas Markle. The letter was written after the American's 2018 marriage to Prince Harry.
A High Court judge sided with Markle in February, ruling that the paper's publication of the letter was “manifestly excessive and hence unlawful.” 
On Tuesday, lawyer Andrew Caldecott countered that the letter was not written as an “intimate communication for her father's eyes only.”
“The letter was crafted specifically with the potential of public consumption in mind because the claimant appreciated Mr. Markle might disclose it to the media,” the lawyer told the Court of Appeal.
The publisher was ordered in March to print a front-page statement stating it had infringed the duchess's copyright, but the statement has not been published pending the outcome of the appeal. 
Three senior judges preside over the appeal, which is expected to last three days. A ruling is due at a later date. 
Meghan, a former star of the American TV legal drama “Suits,” married Harry, a grandson of Queen Elizabeth II, at Windsor Castle in May 2018. 
Meghan and Harry announced in early 2020 that they were quitting royal duties and moving to North America, citing what they said were the unbearable intrusions and racist attitudes of the British media.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) About 800 bodies are waiting to be buried or cremated in the largest cemetery in the Sicilian city of Palermo.
Hundreds of coffins are piled one on top of the other in a storage room, others in two tents outdoors, exposed to the elements.
Distressed relatives tell of having to climb over other coffins to reach the coffins of their loved ones. 
"There are some coffins, close to that of my father, which give off a bad smell and are opening," said one Palermo resident who had come to leave flowers on his father's coffin.
Sometimes the stench is so strong that it's impossible to enter the makeshift storage area, even for a quick prayer. 
Every day more coffins arrive at the Santa Mari dei Rotol" cemetery, but there are no spaces available, either among the niches or in the ground.
In any case cremations are impossible - the crematorium has been out of service for more than a year.  
There have been capacity issues at the cemetery since the 1980s, but over the years plans to solve the situation have either been abandoned midway, or never got off the ground. 
According to a city councilman, Igor Gelarda, the responsibility falls on the municipal administrations of the last 40 years, which have not expanded the cemetery.
He said plans to open a new crematorium there had to be abandoned after the project designers failed to include a sewage system in the plans.
He says the only solution is to build a new cemetery.

description:
(10 Nov 2021) LEAD IN: 
The receding water levels in the reservoir of Dohuk Dam in northern Iraq have revealed an old village the dam was built on some 40 years ago.

STORY-LINE: 
The record low water levels in Dohuk Dam's reservoir, in northern Iraq, has revealed a village that the dam was built on 40 years ago. 
Qasri village was one of several villages that were submerged under water during the construction of Dohuk Dam from 1980 to 1988.  
Remains of the buildings in the village showed up this year because of the significant receding of water in reservoir. 
Scarcity of rainfall this year has caused severe drought in the region. 
Dohuk Dam was built mainly to provide drinking and irrigation water for the city of Dohuk. 
Its main sources are rainwater and small water streams formed by melting snow. 
The reservoir has a capacity to store 52 million cubic meter (about 1.8 billion cubic foot) of water. 
But this season "there is 20 million cubic meter (7.06 million cubic foot) of water in it, compared to 34 million cubic meter (1.2 billion cubic foot) of water at the same time of last year," said the director of the dam, Farhad Mohammed.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) LEAD IN:
Thousands of Yemenis flee amid continued fighting between Iran-backed rebels and forces loyal to Yemen's internationally recognized government.

STORY-LINE:
Yemenis continued fleeing the fighting near the city of Marib between Iran-backed rebels and forces loyal to Yemen's internationally recognized government.
Around 3,000 families, or nearly 17,000 individuals, have fled the Rawdat Jehm camp near the Marib Dam and arrived at the newly set up Al-Sima camp in Marib's Al-Wadi district, according to one camp official.
Many have fled more than once, traveling long distances with their belongings.
"When this new fighting started, we fled again. And here we are in this tent with eight children," said Mohammed Showi, who was setting up a tent at Al-Sima camp.
"The situation is deplorable. There's lack of all the basic needs, including water and water distribution points, shelters, food and sanitation," said the headman of the camp, Mohsen al-Suri.
Last week, security officials said at least 200 fighters were killed in clashes between Yemen's government forces and Houthi rebels in and around the strategic central province of Marib over two days.
Most of the casualties belonged to the Houthi forces, who have recently wrestled from their rivals most of Marib's 14 districts, according to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to brief the media.
The Houthis have for years attempted to take oil-rich Marib to complete their control over the northern half of Yemen.
The Iran-backed Shiite Houthis have stepped up their push in the oil-rich province in recent weeks, while also escalating cross-border attacks on Saudi Arabia.
The kingdom is leading a military coalition that has been fighting on the government side against the Houthis since 2015.
Yemen has been convulsed by civil war since 2014 when the Houthis captured the capital, Sanaa, and much of the north of the country, forcing the internationally recognized government to flee to the south, then to Saudi Arabia.
Despite a relentless air campaign and ground fighting, the war has deteriorated largely into a stalemate and spawned the world's worst humanitarian crisis.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) Livestock ranchers in Argentina, one of the world's top meat exporters, have been pushed to join the reduction of emissions to limit global warming.
Feedlot producers have started to look into the problem of methane emission, while environmentalists warn that it won't be enough without a change in consumption patterns.
As part of their digestion, cattle release methane, a potent greenhouse gas that worsens climate change.
In order to limit the temperature rising to a maximum of 1.5-2 degrees, as set by the Paris Climate Agreement, researchers worldwide agree the livestock industry should reduce its emissions drastically.
Total emissions from global livestock per year represent 14.5 percent of all anthropogenic greenhouse emissions, and 44 percent of livestock emissions are in the form of methane, according to the UN Food and Agricultural Organization.
To curb emissions, food companies have developed some additives.  In September, Chile and Brazil started using one of these supplements for livestock food, aiming to reduce methane emissions by 30 percent.
In Argentina, feedlots are just beginning to look into the problem.
Fernando Storni, General Manager of the Argentine Feedlot Chamber, acknowledged the problem and warned that in the near future commercial agreements could include certain greenhouse certifications for producers.
Guillermo del Barrio, owner of El Trébol feedlot, with some 10,000 head of cattle tightly packed in various corrals, said he sees some change is coming.
However, Walter Pengue, agricultural engineer and ecology professor at General Sarmiento National University, said the feed additives and other technologies to reduce emissions are not enough.
"The consumption patterns must be changed," he said. "We need to look at what's behind the meat, that is the soil that is rapidly degrading, there is the water, which is in a tremendously serious limit."
Argentina has some 53 million head of livestock, of which almost 14 million is slaughter cattle, according to Argentina's Agriculture, Cattle raising and Fishing Ministry.

title: Cattle ranchers in Argentina join climate efforts

description:
(10 Nov 2021) After the long-awaited reopening of the border between Mexico and the United States, the hopes of many migrants camped close to the crossing at Tijuana are still waiting to be realised.
More than 1,200 people remain in a makeshift camp at the border, wishing to be able to cross into southern California.
The land crossing reopened on Monday after more than 19 months of restrictions due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Mayra Gutiérrez has been in the camp for six months with her 10-year-old daughter after they fled violence from her home in Lazaro Cardenas in Michoacan state.
"We're all looking forward to making it to the United States. That is the only thought we have," she said. "Everyone is sad and desperate. That's what we feel here."
Flor Deli Mejía Zamora, 29 and a mother of six, fled Guerrero because of violence and the harassment of her teenage daughters.
"We all had hopes that when they opened (the border) they were going to also open up asylum opportunities," she said. "But they haven't told us anything."
Jose Maria Garcia Lara, the coordinator of the Tijuana Migrant Alliance, estimates some 3,000 people are waiting in the city for the chance to present their asylum case.
"They have faith that at any moment there could be again that openness for the aid that the U.S. government was providing to the people seeking asylum or humanitarian aid," Garcia Lara said.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

description:
(10 Nov 2021) German Chancellor Angela Merkel asked Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday to intervene with Minsk over the escalating migrant situation on Belarus' border with Poland.
Groups of migrants made bold attempts this week to cross into European Union territory, which the bloc alleges has been enabled by Belarusian authorities.
The chancellor's spokesman Steffen Seibert said Merkel spoke with Putin by phone and underlined the exploitation of migrants by Belarusian authorities was  "inhuman" and "completely unacceptable." 
Merkel asked the Russian president "to exert his influence on the regime in Minsk," Seibert said.
Russia is a close ally of the government in Belarus. 
Germany is a favoured destination for migrants who manage to enter the EU.
The readout of the call released by the Kremlin said Putin "proposed to establish a discussion of the problems that have arisen in direct contacts of representatives of the EU member states with Minsk." 
It also said that Putin and Merkel "agreed to continue the conversation on the issue.". 
Poland's Defence Ministry and local police reported Wednesday that multiple groups of migrants tried to enter the country late Tuesday and early Wednesday but that all the people who made it were detained. 
Hundreds of migrants have been camping since Monday on the Belarus side of the border, across from the Polish village of Kuznica. 
EU leaders accuse the regime of Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko of opening up a new migration route to Europe to create instability in retaliation for sanctions the bloc imposed on Lukashenko's authoritarian government. 
The EU imposed the sanctions over a brutal crackdown on domestic dissent following Lukashenko's disputed election to a sixth term in August 2020.

description:
(9 Nov 2021) Four astronauts returned to Earth on Monday, riding home with SpaceX to end a 200-day space station mission that began last spring.
  
Their capsule parachuted into the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Pensacola, Florida, in darkness. Recovery boats quickly moved in with spotlights. 
  
Their homecoming - coming just eight hours after leaving the International Space Station - paved the way for SpaceX's launch of their four replacements as early as Wednesday night. 
  
The newcomers were scheduled to launch first, but NASA switched the order because of bad weather and an astronaut's undisclosed medical condition. The welcoming duties will now fall to the lone American and two Russians left behind at the space station.
  
Before Monday afternoon’s undocking, German astronaut Matthias Maurer, who’s waiting to launch at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center, tweeted it was a shame the two crews wouldn’t overlap at the space station but “we trust you’ll leave everything nice and tidy.” His will be SpaceX's fourth crew flight for NASA in just one-and-a-half years.
  
NASA astronauts Shane Kimbrough and Megan McArthur, Japan's Akihiko Hoshide and France's Thomas Pesquet should have been back Monday morning, but high wind in the recovery zone delayed their return.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) A tourist bus carrying humanitarian aid left Berlin on Monday bound for the border region between Poland and Belarus, following reports that a large group of migrants in Belarus was heading for a crossing point.
German humanitarian organisations Seebrücke Deutschland (SeaBridge Germany) and LeaveNoOneBehind organised boxes of supplies, including winter clothes and medical aid, to be sent to the border area to support the work of local Polish movements and NGOs. 
The groups say also they want to bring back a number of migrants to Germany but that the German government has not so far authorised such a move.    
"But it would be also an opportunity for Angela Merkel to set a humanitarian signal at the end of her time in government," said Tareq Alaows, an activist with Seebrücke Deutschland (SeaBridge Germany).
Poland is stepping up security at its border with Belarus, on the European Union's eastern border, officials said Monday.
Polish Defence Minister, Mariusz Blaszczak, said on Twitter that that more than 12,000 soldiers have been deployed on the border, up from the 10,000 soldiers that were there recently. 
He added that a volunteer Territorial Defence force was put on alert.
Since the summer, Poland has been under increasing pressure of migrants from the Middle East and Africa trying to cross into the EU. 
Poland is blocking these attempts or sending those who cross back into Belarus. 
Warsaw and the EU say it's an organised action by the Belarusian government aimed at destabilising the bloc in retaliation for Western sanctions. 
"The Belarusian regime acts as a trafficker. It is 'instrumentalising' refugees and migrants in a politically and humanely reprehensible way," Steffen Seibert, German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, said on Monday.
Poland's Border Guard has reported incidents of hostile behavior and threats by Belarusian forces directed across the border at Polish forces.

description:
(7 Nov 2021) Security has been ramped up in Baghdad following the failed assassination attempt on the Iraqi prime minister on Sunday.
In a statement, the government said an explosives-laden drone tried to hit Mustafa al-Kadhimi’s home. 
Residents of Baghdad heard the sound of an explosion followed by heavy gunfire from the direction of the Green Zone, which houses foreign embassies and government offices.
More troops have been deployed in the wake of the drone attack.
Baghdad locals condemned the attack suggesting it could destabilise the political situation within the country. 
"We, as the Iraqi people, completely reject this attack," said one local. 
The Iraqi government confirmed al-Kadhimi had survived the assassination attempt  and is unharmed.
Two Iraqi officials told The Associated Press that seven of al-Kadhimi's security guards were injured in the attack by two armed drones which occurred in Baghdad's heavily fortified Green Zone area. 
They spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to give official statements.
The PM later appeared on Iraqi television, seated behind a desk in a white shirt, looking calm and composed. 
There was no immediate claim for the attack. 
It comes amid a stand-off between security forces and pro-Iran Shiite militias whose supporters have been camped outside the Green Zone for nearly a month after they rejected the results of Iraq’s parliamentary elections in which they lost around two-thirds of their seats.

description:
(7 Aug 2003) 

PICTURE QUALITY AS INCOMING

1. Wide exterior of Nari Graha Court in Denpasar, the provincial capital  
2. Various of police guarding court building 
3. Various of journalists and cameramen queueing to have their equipment searched 
4. Various of journalists being checked by police 
5. Various of boxes of equipment being searched 
6. Newspaper vendor called Munggis, standing beside road 
7. Close-up of headline about bombing suspect Amrozi bin Nurhasyim, who faces a possible death sentence 
8. Various of vendors selling newspapers to motorists 
9. SOUNDBITE: (Indonesian) Munggis, newspaper vendor: 
"I think Rozi should be sentenced to death. Because of him, our profits from selling newspapers has gone down." 
10. Wide of vendors on road 

STORYLINE: 

Security was tight around a courthouse in Indonesia on Thursday where a verdict is expected in the trial of Amrozi bin Nurhasyim, a key suspect for last October's Bali bombings. 

Amrozi faces a possible death sentence.

Last year's twin nightclub blasts in Bali, a tourist hotspot, killed 202 people, mostly foreign tourists. 

Amrozi is among more than 30 people accused of being involved in the attack, but his will be the first verdict. 

Amrozi was dubbed the "Smiling Bomber" after he appeared giggling before TV crews after his arrest.

The suspect smiled and joked his way through three months of court hearings, to the upset of survivors, relatives of the victims and many Indonesians.

Only last Monday, he angered judges when he glibly claimed not to know his younger brother, Ali Imron, who is also accused in the attack.

And on Wednesday, he told judges: "I don't think I need to say anything because tomorrow I need to be sentenced anyway."

Anything less than life imprisonment will likely be met with outrage, especially in Australia, home to 88 of the victims, and could raise questions about the ability of Indonesia's legal system to tackle Islamic militancy.

Amrozi's trial, which began in May, has been quicker than predicted.

The baby-faced 41-year-old former repairman has admitted in court to buying the minivan used in the attack and driving it to Bali. 

Judges have also seen forensic evidence allegedly linking him to the vehicle.

His lawyers say that Amrozi had nothing to do with the planning of the attack - something they hope will mean he can escape the death penalty. 

The blasts have been blamed on Jemaah Islamiyah, an al-Qaida linked Southeast Asian terror group that allegedly wants to set up a regional Islamic state.

On Thursday, journalists and cameramen queueing to enter Nari Graha Court in Denpasar, the provincial capital of Bali, had their equipment thoroughly searched by the police. 

On Wednesday, Indonesian police revealed that they carried out a raid last month that netted seven alleged members of Jemaah Islamiyah. 

Police said they seized documents showing terrorists were planning to target the area around Jakarta's
Marriott Hotel, where a powerful car bomb this week killed at least 10 people and injured nearly 150. 

The revelation came as Indonesian and Australian authorities warned that more terror strikes were possible in Indonesia in the coming days. 

Jemaah Islamiyah is a shadowy group said to be fighting to install a pan-Islamic state in Southeast Asia.

title: Preparations for verdict in trial of Bali bomb suspect Amrozi

description:
(6 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4351891  

Hundreds of activists gathered in front of Paris City Hall Saturday to protest against what they called climate inaction by the world's top ten polluting nations.
They displayed large banners carrying images of world leaders including the French, U.S. and Chinese presidents, alongside one reading "Climate inaction = crime against life."
The protest in the French capital was one of several demonstrations across the world marking the Global Day of Action for Climate Justice, as negotiations continue at the U.N. climate summit in Glasgow.
Inside the conference venue Saturday, negotiators knuckled down for a seventh day of talks to finish draft agreements that can be passed to ministers for political approval next week.
Among the issues being haggled over at the talks by almost 200 countries are a fresh commitment to the goal of capping global warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius, getting countries to review their efforts more frequently, and financial support for poor nations.

description:
(8 Nov 2021) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4352019

British Airways and Virgin Atlantic jets took-off simultaneously from London Heathrow on Monday bound for the U.S. as the coronavirus travel ban was lifted between the two nations.
The rival airlines departed at approximately 0850 GMT for New York's JFK airport.
Foreign travellers flying to the U.S. are required to demonstrate proof of vaccination before boarding, as well as proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken within three days of flight.
Airlines hailed the U.S. decision as a lifeline for the struggling industry.

description:
Thousands gathered in Warsaw on Thursday for an annual Independence Day march carrying Polish and nationalist group flags, an event the far-right organizers dedicated to uniformed "protectors of the border" amid an escalating migrant crisis at the country's eastern border.

Warsaw authorities had secured a court ban on the event that runs separately from official celebrations and has a history of occasional violence, but Poland's nationalist administration helped challenge the ban.

Marchers, including families with children but also representatives of nationalist groups like National Radical Camp (ONR), fired red flares and chanted "Viva, viva border guard" and "God, Honour, Homeland" as they walked through Warsaw.

March leaders warned against what they said were Western attempts to turn Poles into "pariahs," and condemned liberal Western political and cultural influences.

Critics say in lending its hand, the Law and Justice government is giving overt support to the far-right and fomenting anti-migrant sentiment at a time when Poland faces unprecedented pressure from thousands of migrants trying to cross into the European Union via its border with Belarus.

The European Union accuses Minsk of manufacturing the crisis in revenge for earlier sanctions by helping people fleeing conflict-torn regions make it to Belarus and then try to cross into Poland and its other EU neighbours.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8366302/belarus-poland-migrants-explained/

Subscribe to Global News Channel HERE: http://bit.ly/20fcXDc

description:
WARNING: Video contains disturbing content. Viewer discretion is advised.

Prosecutors say former Las Vegas Raiders wide receiver Henry Ruggs III is facing upwards of 50 years in prison for a fatal crash that killed a 23-year-old woman in Las Vegas on Nov. 2. 

Ruggs, who did not appear in court for his arraignment Wednesday morning, was formally charged with five counts in a fiery crash that claimed the life of Tina Tintor and her dog Max. 

Prosecutors say Ruggs' blood-alcohol content was twice the legal limit, and he was speeding at 156 miles per hour in the early hours of Nov. 2 when his Corvette slammed into the back end of a Toyota Rav4 driven by Tintor. The Rav4 burst into flames and Tintor and her dog were trapped inside. 

Ruggs and his girlfriend Rudy Washington, who have a 1-year-old daughter together, were both injured in the crash as well.

Global's Steve Autio provides more details on the charges.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8360274/saskatchewan-motorcycle-collision-edmonton-huskies/

description:
As tensions ramp up at the Belarus-Poland border, Polish authorities stood guard at a fence on Sunday with heavy equipment and water cannon, where Belarusian migrants were trying to cross. 

Plus, the Belarusian State Border Committee has released a video on Sunday showing a group of people caught between barbed wire fencings, guarded by unidentified servicemen.

According to the committee's statement, migrants had become stuck in the fences at the checkpoint Kuznitsa on the Polish side.

Thousands of migrants have travelled to Belarus with the hope of crossing into the European Union, only to find themselves trapped at the border in freezing conditions.

description:
Cpl. Francis Pegahmagabow, known as "Peggy,"  is the most decorated Indigenous soldier in Canadian history and the deadliest sniper of World War One.

A hundred years ago, when Indigenous people weren’t allowed to volunteer to fight in the war, Canadian Forces began to suffer significant losses and only then was Pegahmagabow to enlist. 

Over the next four years, he fought in the most horrific battles of the war, including Passchendaele, Somme and the second battle of Ypres when the Germans used chlorine gas. 

“He won the military medal three times, and is one of 38 Canadians to ever do this and those are awarded by the Battalion Brigade Commander,” notes author and historian Timothy Winegard.

 So how is it that Pegahmagabow’s exploits are not taught in Canadian history?

Mike Drolet reports.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8366135/great-war-hero-cpl-francis-pegahmagabow/

#GlobalNews #RemembranceDay

title: Remembrance Day 2021: The story of Canada's most decorated Indigenous soldier

description:
Tens of thousands of people took to the streets in the Sudanese capital Khartoum on Saturday to protest against a military takeover, despite security forces firing tear gas and bullets to disperse them.

As protesters began to gather in the early afternoon around the capital, security forces moved quickly to try to disperse them, firing tear gas and chasing demonstrators down side streets to try to prevent them reaching central meeting points, witnesses said.

Two more protesters have been killed during demonstrations against military rule in Sudan, the Central Committee of Sudanese Doctors said, after reporting one death earlier in the day.

The demonstrations come two days after military leader Abdel Fattah al-Burhan announced the formation of a new ruling council that excludes the civilian coalition the military had been sharing power with since 2019.

Sudanese pro-democracy groups condemned the move and vowed to continue their campaign of civil disobedience and protests against the Oct. 25 coup.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8371596/sudan-coup-protests/

description:
You may think expensive cars would be harder for thieves to steal than less costly ones, but that’s not necessarily the case. 

Global News has exclusive video of a couple of recent driveway thefts that show just how quickly locked cars could be opened, started and stolen. 

In one case, a Toronto man shows us exclusive video of a thief making off with his expensive Range Rover in a matter of seconds. We've called him "Max" in order to protect the man from possible retaliation from the alleged thieves.

And he's not the only one - increasingly, the owners of fine cars are starting to wonder just how secure these expensive investments are, and why it's so easy in some cases to steal these supposedly-secure automobiles. 

Sean O’Shea reports.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/toronto

description:
An explosive device that blew up a taxi in Liverpool on Sunday was carried on board by a passenger and the blast is being treated as a “terrorist incident,” police said Monday.

The taxi exploded outside Liverpool Women's Hospital, killing the passenger and injuring the driver, who received medical treatment but has since been released from hospital.

Assistant Chief Const. Russ Jackson of Counter-Terrorism Policing Northwest said they believed they knew the identity of the passenger who was killed by the explosion, but could not disclose it.

Three men aged 29, 26 and 21 were arrested on Sunday, and Jackson said another 20-year-old man had been arrested Monday.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to hold a meeting of the government's emergency committee on Monday to discuss the explosion.

For more info, please go to https://globalnews.ca/news/8374146/liverpool-taxi-terrorist-attack-womens-hospital/
